Act Score By State"},{"article":"Although we do not want to have to plan for the passing of our loved ones, it is recommended that you plan financially due to the high cost of a funeral. Funeral costs can range based on your location and final wishes of your loved one.\r\n\r\nCosts to factor into a funeral are the hearse, funeral home service fee, casket, headstone, burial plot, viewing and staff fees for any services. If the deceased wished to be cremated, there are separate feeds associated with those services. Funeral costs can be planned for be setting aside a fund or taking out an insurance policy.\r\n\r\nThe average funeral cost is between $7,000 and $9,000, with the median cost being $7,360. Some funerals can cost much higher or lower than the average costs. \r\n\r\nMany families tend to overspend on funerals due to the emotional impact of a loved one passing clouding their best judgment or due to a lack of time and experience. It is important to take the time to research and contact multiple services to see which is right for you and your family and to see what services are within your price range.\r\n\r\nAdditionally, you should know and understand your rights. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) introduced the âFuneral Ruleâ in 1984 which gives you the right to only buy the goods and services you want, be given an itemized statement of all goods and services, be told price information over the phone, and other rights related to your funeral. \r\n\r\nMaine has the highest average funeral cost of $8,675. Florida has the lowest average funeral cost of $5,875.\r\n\r\nBelow is a list of the average funeral cost in each state.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Average Cost of a Funeral","field":"funeralCost","format":"moneyWithCurrency"},"population"],"sortField":"funeralCost","showAllStates":true,"chloroMap":{"field":"funeralCost"},"relatedArticles":["average-act-score-by-state","average-funeral-cost-by-state","average-height-by-state","average-temperatures-by-state",{"link":"average-iq-by-state","title":"Average IQ by State"},"average-internet-speed-by-state"]},"customData":[{"funeralCost":6675,"state":"Arizona"},{"funeralCost":6250,"state":"California"},{"funeralCost":5875,"state":"Florida"},{"funeralCost":6250,"state":"Georgia"},{"funeralCost":6875,"state":"Idaho"},{"funeralCost":7650,"state":"Illinois"},{"funeralCost":8675,"state":"Maine"},{"funeralCost":6450,"state":"Minnesota"},{"funeralCost":6325,"state":"Nebraska"},{"funeralCost":6250,"state":"North Carolina"},{"funeralCost":7450,"state":"Ohio"},{"funeralCost":7700,"state":"Pennsylvania"},{"funeralCost":6425,"state":"Tennessee"},{"funeralCost":6375,"state":"Texas"},{"funeralCost":6650,"state":"Washington"}]},"sources":[{"name":"How Much Does a Funeral Cost?","link":"https://www.lhlic.com/consumer-resources/average-funeral-cost/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"average-funeral-cost-by-state","name":"Average Funeral Cost By State"},{"article":"The average height in the United States is 5 feet 4 inches (162.56 centimeters) for women and 5 feet 9 inches (175.26 centimeters) for men. This makes the United States the 40th tallest nation in the world. \r\n\r\nMultiple factors contribute to oneâs overall height. Genetics account for 60-80% of oneâs height and nutrition and exercise account for the remaining percentage. Childhood nutrition is believed to be a large factor in adult height. Race plays a large role in average heights in populations. White men (average height of 5 feet 10 inches) and black men (5 feet 9 inches) tend to be taller than Asian (5 feet 7 inches) and Hispanic (5 feet 7 inches) men. Alabama is one of the tallest states in the US and has a population that is 96% black or white. \r\n\r\nTo determine the average height in each of the 50 states, information as pulled from the Center for Disease Controlâs (CDC) [Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System](https://www.cdc.gov/brfss/index.html) (BRFSS). This is an annual survey of more than 450,000 people conducted by the CDC to gather data about health and wellness in the United States, including health-related risk behaviors, chronic health conditions, and the use of preventative services. The BRFSS tracks weight and obesity, healthy eating, physical activity, and height. \r\n\r\nThe tallest states based on average height for men and based on average height for women are different. The tallest women tend to be clustered in the northern plains states with the tallest living in South Dakota. The tallest men live in Iowa and Alabama.\r\n\r\nThe tallest states in the United States based on the average height for men (179 centimeters or above) are:\r\n\r\n-\tAlabama\r\n-\tIowa\r\n-\tKentucky\r\n-\tMontana\r\n-\tNebraska\r\n-\tNorth Dakota\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tTennessee\r\n-\tUtah\r\n-\tWest Virginia\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nThe tallest states in the United States based on the average height for women (164 centimeters or above) are:\r\n\r\n-\tDistrict of Columbia\r\n-\tIowa\r\n-\tMinnesota\r\n-\tMontana\r\n-\tNebraska\r\n-\tNorth Dakota\r\n-\tOregon\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tUtah\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nHawaii has the shortest average height among both men and women. This can be attributed to the race factor previously mentioned. Hawaiiâs population is less than one-third black or white. \r\n\r\nBelow is a table of each stateâs average height for men and women. The data is self-reported, therefore heights tend to be over-reported about 2.7 centimeters for men (1 inch) and about 1.5 centimeters for women.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"note":"* Data is self-reported, so it is not 100% correct. Height By State"},{"article":"Internet speed refers to how much data and information can be transferred over the web on a single connection. \r\n\r\nInternet speed is important because it determines what individuals can and cannot do online. Internet speed is important when surfing the web, playing online games, downloading movies, TV shows, or music, video chatting, or sending any kind of communication. Internet speed also determines how many devices can be connected at once.\r\n\r\nBandwidth measures the total number of frequencies that a network connection can handle at any given moment. Broadband tells you how fast your Internet connection is. Internet speed is measured in bits per second (bps) or megabits per second (Mbps). \r\n\r\nInternet speed is extremely important for entrepreneurs and business owners. A faster Internet can handle more devices at once and help a business run more efficiently.  According to HighSpeedInternet.com, the following Mbps allow users to efficiently do certain tasks:\r\n\r\n-\t5 Mbps: browsing, streaming music; ideal for a single user\r\n-\t10 Mbps: streaming HD videos, casual gaming; ideal for 1-2 people\r\n-\t20 Mbps: Ultra HD streaming, frequent gaming; ideal for 2-4 people\r\n-\t40+ Mbps: steaming multiple shows in HD, simultaneous gaming; ideal for 4+ people\r\n\r\nEvery U.S. state sees significant increases in average Internet speed each year as U.S. telecoms work consistently to provide faster networks. Rural states overall tend to have slower Internet speeds while more densely-populated states tend to have faster internet speeds.\r\n\r\nHighSpeedInternet.com [analyzed one million speed tests](https://www.highspeedinternet.com/tools/speed-test) taken on their site to find out which states and the fastest and slowest average Internet speeds. \r\n\r\nMaryland has the fastest average Internet speed of 65.02 Mbps. Marylandâs fast Internet speeds make it an ideal location for tech businesses, multi-person streaming, and gaming. The next four fastest states are New Jersey (59.58 Mbps), Delaware (59.08 Mbps), Rhode Island (56.77 Mbps), and Virginia (55.98 Mbps). New Jerseyâs fastest city is Somerset, which has an average Internet speed of 97.6 Mbps. Virginiaâs fastest city, Sterling, has an average Internet speed of 96.9 Mbps. \r\n\r\nAll of the five fastest average Internet speeds are located on the East Coast. Because of cheaper costs of living and better Internet speeds, these states provide potentially better start-up environments for businesses than Silicon Valley. \r\n\r\nAlaska has the slowest average Internet speeds of 17.03 Mbps. Speeds under 20 Mbps take longer periods for downloads and only works best for single-user streaming. Following Alaska for the slowest Internet speeds in the country are Mississippi (24.77 Mbps), Idaho (25.30), Montana (25.70), and Maine (26.05). These states are okay for a couple of people to stay connected but are not ideal for businesses or those who are serious gamers. \r\n\r\nAverage Internet speeds and providers for any zip code can be checked on [HighSpeedInternet.com](https://www.highspeedinternet.com/). [FastMetrics](https://www.fastmetrics.com/internet-connection-speed-map-usa.php) also provides information on each stateâs average peak Internet speeds. \r\n\r\n\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["average-act-score-by-state","average-funeral-cost-by-state","average-height-by-state","average-temperatures-by-state",{"link":"average-iq-by-state","title":"Average IQ by State"},"average-internet-speed-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"average-internet-speed-by-state","name":"Average Internet Speed By State"},{"article":"When talking about intellect and abilities of the mind, the IQ test is a measurement that tends to be brought into the conversation. As one of many controversial topics in the world, the IQ test is something that people are very divided on, seeing as it is viewed as a way of defining the intelligence levels of people based on one test. \n\nThe argument against the IQ test is that one test cannot accurately predict the intellect of every single person who takes it because people are so different. The thought behind opponents of the IQ test is that there is far too much variety amongst people across the globe, and comparing everyone against the of one test is too simplistic to fully capture people's individual intellect levels. \n\nOn the other side of the controversial topic, many people do believe that the IQ test accurately and appropriately detects people's intelligence levels across the board. So what in the world is an IQ and how do each of the states in the USA compare, based on the average IQ of their citizens? Let's find out! \n\n## The Definition of an Intelligence Quotient\n\n[Intelligence quotients](https://www.dictionary.com/browse/intelligence-quotient) are a measurement in psychological parameters that defines a person's intellect based on their mental age and their actual age. From there, the value that is found after dividing the person's mental age by the person's actual age since birth needs to be multiplied by a value of one hundred. \n\nYou may be wondering how the IQ scores were calculated. How could anyone possibly collect the IQ score of every resident in each of the fifty states and then take the average of each population's total value? That might not be impossible, but it would certainly be time-consuming. So, instead of trying to be precise and inclusive of every age group in a state, researchers actually took a look at the average IQ test scores of anyone in the state who had previously sat through an IQ test in 2015.\n\nThere are online sources that provide interactive IQ test for people to take just for the sake of testing their own IQ scores. Many people take IQ tests when they are considering to apply for Mensa, which is a community of people who fall into the ninety-eighth percentile of intelligence scores on formal, administered intelligence tests. Mensa is a community of people who all share an IQ score that is greater than ninety-eight percent of IQ scores around the world. \n\nBut when it came to the study conducted by the Washington Post, the researchers also took SAT scores, ACT scores, and the estimated number of people who graduated college in each state into consideration. The SAT Is an exam that high school students sit for prior to applying to higher education, as is the ACT. If you have not yet noticed, all of the variables that researchers paid attention to when determining the average IQ of a state had a lot to do with a certain level of education. This is due to the fact that people who are educated tend to score higher on IQ tests than people who never received an education or who stopped attending classes before reaching college. \n\n## States in Order of Average IQ Scores\n\nTo be completely fair and transparent, the intelligence quotient is not the most accurate way of determining someone's intelligence. After all, it is nearly impossible to fully calculate someone's intellect because it is not a variable that is numerically represented. Instead, IQ scores are a way of trying to put a number on someone's intelligence. That disclaimer aside, let's take a look at the values that have been calculated for the average IQ scores of each of the fifty states in America. \n\nFrom the state with the highest intelligence quotient on average to the US state with the lowest IQ score across the board, here is a list of the fifty states in America in order of [average IQ scores](https://www.al.com/news/2016/06/50_states_ranked_by_intelligen.html)...\n\nAs you can see, the highest-ranking state in terms of average IQ is Massachusetts, with an average IQ score of 104.3 and a population of just under seven million people. The state with the lowest IQ score turns out to be Mississippi, with the IQ score of residents coming to about 94.2 on average. There is a difference of 10.1 IQ points between Mississippi and Massachusetts, which is not as drastic of a discrepancy as you might predict thereâd be among fifty states. Income By State"},{"article":"Because of the size of the United States and its varying degrees of latitudes and various geographic features, the country experiences a wide range of climates. Generally, overall temperatures are warmer as one travels further south and the air becomes drier as one moves further west until hitting the west coast. \r\n\r\nThe Southwest region of the U.S. has a hot desert climate at lower elevations. This region experiences high temperatures and dry air and has many vast desert areas. The Southeast region of the country experiences a somewhat sub-tropical climate that includes hot, humid summers (temperatures above 100 are not uncommon) and mild winters. The Northwest is characterized by a diverse climate with bitter, cold winters and somewhat humid, hot summers. The West Coast of the U.S. experiences cool, wet winters and dry, warm summers (with chilly evenings), specifically the further north one goes. The Midwest has humid summers, but winters are long and generally harsh, with temperatures below zero being common, especially in the northern states. \r\n\r\nThe average temperature in the contiguous United States in 2019 was 52.68 degrees Fahrenheit (Â°F).  The [KÃ¶ppen climate classification](https://www.britannica.com/science/Koppen-climate-classification) is used in this article to describe state climates. \r\n\r\n## Coldest States in the U.S.\r\n\r\n#### 1. Alaska\r\nAlaska is the coldest state in the U.S. with an average temperature of 26.6Â°F. Alaska has a subarctic climate. During the winter months, Alaskaâs temperatures can drop as low as -.30Â°F. The Fairbanks area of Alaska experiences an extremely wide range of temperatures throughout the year ranging from -50Â°F in the winter to highs of 90Â°F in the summer. \r\n\r\n#### 2. North Dakota\r\nNorth Dakota is the U.S.âs second-coldest state. The eastern half of North Dakota experiences a humid continental climate and the western half experiences a semi-arid climate. The average temperature in North Dakota is 40.4Â°F, with average temperatures around 24Â°F in the winter. January is North Dakotaâs coldest month when temperatures range from 2Â°F in the northern parts of the state to 17Â°F in the southern parts. \r\n\r\n#### 3. Maine\r\nThe third-coldest state in the United States is Maine, where the average temperature is 41Â°F. Maineâs climate classification is humid continental, as is the majority of New England states. In the winter, the average temperature is 12Â°F. Maine has abundant snowfall in the winter with an average accumulated snowfall of 10 to 80 inches. The most northeastern city in the United State, Caribou, receives even more snowfall and harsher winter temperatures. \r\n\r\n#### 4. Minnesota\r\nMinnesota is the fourth-coldest state in the country. Minnesotaâs humid continental climate is greatly influenced by its proximity to Canada to its north and Lake Superior to its northeast. The average temperature in Minnesota is 41.2Â°F, with temperatures dropping as low at -30Â°F in the northern parts of the state in the month of January. \r\n\r\n#### 5. Wyoming\r\nWyoming is the fifth-coldest state in the United States with an average temperature of 42Â°F. Wyoming has a mostly semi-arid climate. During the winter, the average minimum temperatures range from 0Â°F to 15Â°F. Winds are typically in the 30 to 40 mile per hour range, with gusts up to 50 to 60 miles per hour, significantly reducing the temperature. Additionally, Wyomingâs highlands and mountaintops can receive up to 200 inches of snow per year and lowlands can receive up to 50 inches of snow. \r\n\r\n## Hottest States in the U.S. \r\n\r\n#### 1. Florida\r\nFlorida is the hottest state in the U.S. with an average annual temperature of 70.7Â°F. As the southernmost contiguous state in the U.S., Florida has a sub-tropical climate in its northern and central parts and a tropical climate in its southern parts. Florida has mild winters and extremely hot summers, especially during its hottest month of July, where temperatures reach average highs of 90Â°F to 92Â°F and it is not uncommon for temperatures to hit or go above 100Â°F.\r\n\r\n#### 2. Hawaii\r\nHawaii is the second-hottest state in the United States with an average annual temperature of 70.0Â°F. Hawaii experiences four different KÃ¶ppen climate zones: tropical, arid, temperate, and polar. In the summer, temperatures in Hawaii peak around 84Â°F and typically do not rise above 90Â°F. In the winter, high temperatures are usually around 79Â°F and lows rarely drop below 65Â°F. Hawaii has never recorded a temperature below freezing (32Â°F). \r\n\r\n#### 3. Louisiana\r\nWith an average annual temperature of 66.4Â°F, Louisiana is the third-hottest state in the United States. Louisiana has a subtropical climate with long, hot, and humid summers and short, mild winters. August is Louisianaâs hottest month, where average highs range from 89Â°F to 94Â°F. Louisianaâs position on the Gulf of Mexico gives it a considerable wet season and high humidity that can make the heat feel like 120Â°F.\r\n\r\n#### 4. Texas\r\nTexas is the fourth-hottest state in the United States with an average annual temperature of 65.3Â°F. Texas has arid and semi-arid climates in its west and humid and sub-tropical climates in its east. August is Texasâs hottest month, where average high temperatures are in the 93Â°F to 101Â°F range. In January, Texasâs coldest month, temperatures the average high temperatures are between 52Â°F and 71Â°F. \r\n\r\n#### 5. Georgia\r\nLocated just north of Florida, Georgia is the fifth-hottest state in the United State with an average annual temperature of 63.5Â°F. In its northeast, Georgia has an oceanic climate and a humid subtropical climate in the rest of the state. Temperatures By State"},{"article":"Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is the percent of alcohol in a personâs bloodstream. BAC can be measured by a breathalyzer test, blood test or urine test.\r\n\r\nBAC is affected by several factors:\r\n\r\n-\tThe number of standard drinks consumed\r\n-\tAmount of time in which the drinks are consumed\r\n-\tBiological sex\r\n-\tBodyweight\r\n-\tMedications\r\n-\tFood (less important)\r\n\r\n A âstandard drinkâ is one 12 ounces regular beer (4.5% alcohol), one 7 ounce malt liquor (7% alcohol), one 5 ounce glass of wine (12% alcohol), one 1.5 ounce shot of hard liquor (40% alcohol), or .5 ounces of Everclear (95% alcohol). \r\n\r\nThe higher oneâs BAC is, the more intoxicated the individual becomes. A BAC between 0.00% to 0.05% causes mild impairment, where speech, coordination, and balance may be off and relaxation or sleepiness may set in. Between 0.06% and 0.15%, a person will experience increased impairment including increased relaxation, decreased coordination, balance, memory, or speech ability, memory impairments, and significant impairment in all driving skills. A BAC level between 0.16% and 0.30% causes severe impairment to the individual, including increasingly worse speech, coordination, and memory, poor judgment and decision-making, loss of consciousness, and signs of alcohol poisoning such as vomiting. Between 0.31% and 0.45%, a personâs BAC level becomes life-threatening and will show signs of severe alcohol poisoning, loss of consciousness, and risk of death. \r\n\r\nThere are different BAC limits to know and some vary by state. The federal BAC limit to legally drive in the United States is a BAC of 0.08%, meaning that a person is intoxicated under the law (âper seâ BAC limit).  States also have âzero toleranceâ BAC limits, which refer to the level of intoxication considered illegal for drivers under 21. A âzero toleranceâ BAC of 0.00% is sometimes referred to as a ânot-a-dropâ law. In some states, a driver under 21 with a BAC between 0.02% and 0.08% will face a different type of DUI and penalties. Enhanced penalty BAC is the BAC level at which an intoxicated person will face worse penalties (increased penalties). \r\n\r\nIn addition to these BAC limits, every state has an implied consent law where motorists are assumed to have given their consent to have their BAC tested. Lastly, most states have an âactual physical controlâ law that states that a person does not need to be actually driving to be in physical control of the vehicle; therefore, a person can still receive a DUI if in the driverâs seat, behind the steering wheel, in possession of the ignition key, and in a position that he or she is physically capable of starting the vehicle and putting the vehicle in motion. \r\n\r\nThe information presented here is for informational purposes only. To learn about BAC limits and DUI penalties in your state, it is best to consult a DUI attorney. \r\n\r\n## BAC Limits by State\r\n\r\n#### Alabama\r\nIn Alabama, the per se BAC is 0.08%, with increased penalties at 0.15%. The BAC limit is decreased to 0.04% if the licensee is driving a commercial vehicle and the âzero toleranceâ level is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### Alaska\r\nAlaskaâs per se BAC is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The âzero toleranceâ is 0.00%; therefore, any level of BAC is considered to be illegal for drivers under 21. \r\n\r\n#### Arizona\r\nArizonaâs per se BAC 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. Arizonaâs âzero toleranceâ limit is 0.00%; therefore, any level of BAC is considered to be illegal for drivers under 21. \r\n\r\n#### Arkansas\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Arkansas is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. For drivers under the legal drinking age of 21 years old, Arkansasâs âzero toleranceâ limit is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### California\r\nCaliforniaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.16%. California has a âzero toleranceâ limit of 0.02% for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21. \r\n\r\n#### Colorado\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Colorado is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.17%. Colorado has a DWAI (driving while ability impaired) which refers to a driver having a BAC of more than 0.05% and less than 0.08%. Coloradoâs âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under 21 is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### Connecticut\r\nConnecticutâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.16%. The legal BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. The âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers in Connecticut under 21 is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### Delaware\r\nDelawareâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The âzero toleranceâ limit in Delaware is 0.02% for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21.\r\n\r\n#### District of Columbia\r\nThe per se BAC limit in D.C. is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The legal BAC limit in D.C. decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. D.C. also has a ânot-a-dropâ law meaning that any driver under the age of 21 is considered intoxicated with any measurable amount of alcohol (BAC above 0.00%).\r\n\r\n#### Florida \r\nFloridaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The legal BAC limit decreases in Florida if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle to 0.04%. The âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under the legal drinking age is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### Georgia\r\nGeorgiaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. The âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21 is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### Hawaii\r\nHawaiiâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The Hawaii BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. The âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21 is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### Idaho\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Idaho is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.20%. The BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle and will be subject to more severe penalties. The âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under 21 is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### Illinois\r\nIllinoisâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.16%. The âzero toleranceâ limit in Indiana is 0.02% for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21 years old. \r\n\r\n#### Iowa\r\nIowaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. Michiganâs âzero toleranceâ limit for drivers under 21 is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### Minnesota\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Minnesota is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.16%. The âzero toleranceâ limit in Mississippi is 0.02% for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21, which will result in a separate offense for an underage DUI. \r\n\r\n#### Missouri \r\nThe per se BAC limit in Missouri is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The BAC limit for operating a commercial vehicle is 0.04% and the limit for drivers under 21 is 0.02%.\r\n\r\n#### Pennsylvania\r\nPennsylvaniaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08%. BAC levels of more than 0.08% and less than 0.10% are considered general impairment DUIs; levels more than 0.10% and less than 0.16% are considered to be high rate DUIs, and levels more than 0.16% are considered to be the highest rate DUIs. The threshold is lowered to 0.04% for commercial drivers and to 0.02% for drivers under 21.  \r\n\r\n#### Rhode Island\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Rhode Island is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. The BAC limit is 0.04% for those operating a commercial vehicle. Any detectable amount of alcohol for drivers under 21 (0.00% or more) is considered to be a DUI in Texas.\r\n\r\n#### Utah\r\nUtah is the only state where the per se BAC limit is no 0.08%; it is 0.05% in Utah. Increased penalties will result in BAC levels of 0.16% or more. Utah has a ânot-a-dropâ law for drivers under 21, where any detectable amount of alcohol is considered to be intoxicated.\r\n\r\n#### Vermont\r\nVermontâs per se BAC limit is 0.08%. The BAC limit decreases to 0.04% for commercial drivers and 0.02% for bus drivers. Virginiaâs âzero toleranceâ law states that the BAC limit for drivers under 21 years old is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### Washington\r\nWashingtonâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. For commercial drivers operating a commercial vehicle, the limit is 0.04%. The âzero toleranceâ law in Washington for drivers under 21 is 0.02%. \r\n\r\n#### West Virginia\r\nWest Virginiaâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with increased penalties at 0.15%. The limit is 0.04% for those operating commercial vehicles and 0.02% for drivers under the legal drinking age of 21. Offenders under the age of 21 with BAC levels more than 0.02% but lower than 0.08% face reduced fines and jail time. \r\n\r\n#### Wisconsin\r\nThe per se BAC limit in Wisconsin is 0.08%. Fines will double for a driver with a BAC of more 0.17% and below 0.199% and fines will triple for a driver with a BAC of 0.20% and above. The BAC limit is lowered to 0.04% for those operating a commercial vehicle in Wisconsin. The âzero toleranceâ law in Wisconsin prohibits any BAC level above 0.00% for drivers under 21. \r\n\r\n#### Wyoming\r\nWyomingâs per se BAC limit is 0.08% with penalties increasing at 0.15%. The BAC limit decreases to 0.04% if the driver is operating a commercial vehicle. Drivers under the legal age of 21 have their BAC limit decreased to 0.02% and can face a special DUI charge if their level is over 0.02% and below 0.08%. \r\n","lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"bac-limit-by-state","name":"Bac Limit By State"},{"article":"Ban-the-Box laws prohibit questions about past criminal convictions on job applications. The âboxâ in âban-the-boxâ initially referred to the checkbox on a job application where candidates would have to answer whether or not they have a criminal history, but these regulations have expanded to indicate when an employer is permitted to ask about criminal history.\n\nThe purpose of a ban-the-box law is to help those adults with a criminal past receive a fair chance of finding work. Employers are encouraged to assess a candidateâs qualifications and skills fairly against other candidates before denying employment. Some employers are exempt from ban the box laws, such as security jobs, and those working with children and the elderly.\n\nBefore these laws, a typical job application had a set of questions that included the question, âHave you ever been convicted of a crime? Check yes or no.â For the 30% of adults who do have a criminal history, checking this box usually meant that their application was automatically rejected by the employer without evaluation of their crime or any of their qualifying skills or work history.\n\nA total of 35 states and the District of Columbia have adopted a ban the box law of some kind. Thirteen of these states have extended their law to private employers. 150 cities and 18 counties have also adopted some type of ban-the-box law, some of which are in states that have not adopted such laws. This sets 258 million people in the US in a jurisdiction with a ban-the-box or fair-chance law. There is currently no federal ban-the-box law.\n\nSome states have ban-the-box laws with additional requirements. Some laws only apply to employers of a specific size, and some require employers to wait until a later point in the hiring process to ask about criminal histories, such as after a conditional offer is made.\n\nBelow is a list of all 35 Ban-the-Box states and their regulations. Some municipalities that have separate ban-the-box laws have been included. Many counties and cities have separate ban-the-box laws, in states with and without them, which have not been included in this list. You should always check your local municipalityâs ban-the-box laws. \n\n## Arizona\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of Arizona applies to businesses with more than 15 employees. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until an interview or a conditional job offer if there is no interview. Employers are only able to ask about criminal history in the last seven years. \n\n## California\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of California applies to any employer (public and private) with five or more employees. A criminal background inquiry is prohibited until after a conditional job offer. \n\nIn Compton, the ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city. A background check is allowed after a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Los Angeles, the ban-the-box law applies to any employer with 10 or more employees. Criminal history questions are prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Richmond, the ban-the-box law applies to private employers with 10 or more employees that contract with the city.\n\n## Colorado\n\nEffective September 1, 2019, the ban-the-box law for the state of Colorado applies to private employers with 11 or more employees. The law will apply to all employers starting on or after September 1, 2021.\n\n## Connecticut\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of Connecticut applies to all employers, and any criminal history questions on initial job applications are banned with very limited exceptions.\n\nIn Hartford and New Haven, the ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city, and background checks are only permitted after a conditional job offer.\n\n## Delaware\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of Delaware applies to public employers. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until a conditional offer of employment.\n\n## District of Columbia\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the District of Columbia applies to all employers (public and private) with more than 10 employees. Background checks are only permitted after a conditional job offer.\n\n## Georgia\n\nThe ban-the-box law in the state of Georgia applies to public sector employers. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited on job applications and employers can inquire during interviews.\n\nIn Atlanta, the ban-the-box law applies to public sector employers as it does in the state. Employers may only inquire into criminal history after the candidate completes a second interview or is deemed qualified.\n\n## Hawaii\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to all private employers. Criminal history inquiries are not permitted until after a conditional job offer.\n\n## Illinois\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers with 15 or more employees. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until prior to a job interview or until after a conditional job offer if no interview occurs.\n\nIn Chicago and Cook County, the law applies to private employers with less than 15 employees, and criminal inquiry conditions are the same as the state.\n\n## Indiana\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of Indiana applies to public sector positions in the stateâs Executive Branch. Initial applications will not inquire about criminal history or convictions unless of a particular crime that precludes that person from employment in that specific position. A background check may be conducted later in the hiring process.\n\nIn Indianapolis, the law applies to contractors doing business with the city. Criminal history questions are not permitted until after the first interview.\n\n## Kansas\n\nThe ban-the-box law for the state of Kansas applies to executive branch departments, agencies, boards and commissions under the Office of the Governor. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited on the initial employment application, and a criminal history may not automatically disqualify a candidate.\n\n## Kentucky \n\nThe ban-the-box law in the state of Kentucky applies to public sector positions in the stateâs Executive Branch. Employers are prohibited to inquire about criminal history until after contacting the applicant to offer an interview.\n\nIn Louisville, a ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city. The city of Louisville prefers vendors that âban the boxâ on job applications and may terminate contracts with those who do not. \n\n## Louisiana\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Louisiana applies to public sector employers for the State of Louisiana. Employers may only make criminal history inquiries after the first interview or a conditional job offer if there is no interview.\n\nIn New Orleans, the ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city. City contractors are prohibited to ask criminal history questions on initial job applications.\n\n## Maine\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Maine applies to only state government employers. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited on application forms. \n\n## Maryland\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Maryland applies to public employers for the State of Maryland. Criminal history inquiries are not allowed until after the employer has provided the applicant an opportunity for an interview.\n\nIn Baltimore, the ban-the-box law applies to all employers with 10 or more employees. Criminal record checks and inquiries are prohibited until a conditional job offer has been made\n\nIn Montgomery County, a ban-the-box law applies to any employer with 15 or more employees in the county. Criminal history questions and background checks are prohibited until after the first interview.\n\nIn Prince Georgeâs County, a ban-the-box law applies to any employer with 25 or more full-time employees in that county. \n\n## Massachusetts\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers. Criminal history inquiries are banned on initial applications, and inquiries about certain types of crimes are prohibited as well later in the hiring process.\n\nIn Boston, Cambridge, and Worcester, the law applies to contractors and vendors doing business with the city.\n\n## Michigan\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Michigan applies to public employers for the State of Michigan. The initial job application can only ask for affirmation of good character. Criminal history inquiries may only be made after an initial interview or a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Detroit, a ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city when the contract is $25,000 or more. Criminal conviction questions are prohibited until the applicant is interviewed or the contractor determines the applicant is qualified.\n\nIn Kalamazoo, a ban-the-box law applies to contractors providing a service to the city for more than $25,000 or those seeking tax abatement. The contractors must show a commitment that they do not use criminal history as a means of discrimination in employment\n\n## Minnesota\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited on initial job applications, and exceptions are limited.\n\n## Missouri\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Missouri applies to public sector employers in the executive branch for the State of Mississippi. Criminal history inquiries are not allowed on the job application form.\n\nIn Columbia, a ban-the-box law applies to all employers within the city limits. Criminal history questions are prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Kansas City, a ban-the-box law applies to employers with six or more employees. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until after a job interview.\n\n## Nebraska\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Nebraska applies to public sector employers of the State of Nebraska and its cities and counties. Employers may not inquire about criminal history until after the applicant is determined to have met minimum employment qualifications.\n\n## Nevada\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Nevada applies to all public employers. Criminal history inquiries are not permitted until after either a final in-person interview, a conditional offer of employment, or (if applicable) the applicant is certified by the administrator, whichever occurs first.\n\n## New Jersey\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to any employer with 15 or more employees over 20 calendar weeks. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until after the completion of the initial employment process.\n\n## New Mexico\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers. Employers may inquire and consider an applicantâs criminal history after reviewing the application and discussing employment with the applicant.\n\n## New York\n\nThe ban-the-box law in New York applies to public sector employers, agencies, and licensing authorities for the State of New York. Criminal history inquiries can only be made after the first interview.\n\nIn Buffalo, a ban-the-box law applies to private employers with 15 or more employees and contractors doing business with the city. Criminal history questions are prohibited on the initial job application.\n\nIn New York City, a ban-the-box law applies to all employers with four or more employees. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Rochester, a ban-the-box law applies to all employers with four or more employees and contractors doing business with the city. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited until after an initial job interview or after a conditional job offer. \n\nIn Syracuse, a ban-the-box law applies to city contractors. Criminal history inquiries and background checks are prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n\n## North Dakota\n\nThe ban-the-box law in North Dakota applies to public sector employers, excluding school districts. Criminal history inquiries can only be made after a candidate is selected for an interview.\n\n## Ohio\n\nThe ban-the-box laws in Ohio apply to public sector employers for the State of Ohio, including cities and counties. Criminal history inquiries can only be made after a conditional job offer.\n\n## Oklahoma\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Oklahoma applies to state agency employers for the State of Oklahoma. Inquiring into criminal history on the job application is prohibited unless a felony conviction would render an applicant unqualified.\n\n## Oregon\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers. It is unlawful to exclude an applicant from the job interview process solely because of a past criminal conviction.\n\nIn Portland, the ban-the-box law applies to employers with six or more employees. Criminal history questions or assessment is prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n\n## Pennsylvania\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Pennsylvania applies to public sector employers for the State of Pennsylvania that are hiring for non-civil service positions. Criminal history inquiries are not permitted on the job application.\n\nIn Philadelphia, the ban-the-box law applies to all employers with at least one employee in the city. Criminal background checks are prohibited until a conditional job offer.\n\nIn Pittsburgh, the ban-the-box law applies to contractors and vendors doing business with the city. The law bans criminal history inquiries until the applicant is deemed otherwise qualified for a position\n\n## Rhode Island\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to employers with four or more employees. Criminal history inquiries are prohibited on initial job applications.\n\n## Tennessee\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Tennessee applies to public sector employers for the State of Tennessee. Criminal history inquiries are not permitted on job applications.\n\n## Utah\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Utah applies to public sector employers for the State of Utah, including municipalities and counties. Criminal history inquiries can only be made during the interview or later, or after a conditional job offer if there is no interview.\n\n## Vermont\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employees. Criminal history questions are prohibited on initial job applications.\n\n## Virginia\n\nThe ban-the-box law in Virginia applies to the public sector employers â all agencies, boards, and commissions â within the executive branch of the government. Criminal history inquiries can be made only after an applicant is deemed otherwise eligible and is being considered for a position.\n\n## Washington\n\nThe ban-the-box law applies to private employers. No arrest or conviction questions (or background checks) are allowed before a job applicant is deemed otherwise qualified.\n\nIn Seattle, the ban-the-box law applies to any employer with one or more employees. Employers need a âlegitimate business reasonâ to automatically exclude applicants with an arrest or conviction history.\n\nIn Spokane, the ban-the-box law applies to private employers (as it does for the state). Criminal history questions are prohibited before a job interview.\n\n## Wisconsin\n\nThe ban-the-box law for Wisconsin applies to public sector employees for the State of Wisconsin. Criminal history inquiries can only be made after the applicant is certified for the position.\n\nIn Madison, the ban-the-box law applies to contractors doing business with the city where the contract is more than $25,000. Criminal history inquiries and background checks are prohibited until after a conditional job offer.\n","sources":[{"name":"Ban the Box Laws by State and Municipality","link":"https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/state-and-local-updates/xperthr/pages/ban-the-box-laws-by-state-and-municipality-.aspx"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"ban-the-box-states","name":"Ban The Box States"},{"article":"The United States is the worldâs largest producer of beef, primarily high-quality, grain-fed beef. \r\n\r\nThe U.S. beef industry is roughly divided into [two sectors](https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/animal-products/cattle-beef/): cow-calf operations and cattle feeding. The focus of the cow-calf operation is to maintain a herd of beef cattle to raise calves. The cattle feeding sector focuses on preparing cattle for various means of production. \r\n \r\nBeef cattle are raised in all 50 U.S. states. All cattle and calves in the United States totaled 94.4 million as of January 1, 2020. In 2020, the projected beef production is 27.48 billion pounds. \r\n\r\nThe number of cattle in every state is a good indicator of how much beef each state produces.  Thirty states have over 1 million head of cattle, fourteen of those states have over 2 million, and nine of those states have over 3 million. \r\n\r\n## States with the Most Cattle\r\n\r\n#### 1. Texas\r\nTexas has about 13 million head of cattle, about 13.77% of the total cattle in the United States. Texas has the second-largest economy in the nation behind California, with agriculture being one of its most important sectors. Unsurprisingly, cattle are the stateâs top commodity, accounting for over half of the stateâs total market value of all commodities. Since 1967, Texas has had 11 million head of cattle or more every year with the highest being 16.6 million head.\r\n\r\n#### 2. Nebraska\r\nNebraska has the second-highest number of cattle in the U.S. of 6.8 million head. This comprises about 7.20% of the total headcount in the United States. Nebraskaâs beef industry has a $12.1 billion contribution to its economy and the state has about 4,570 cattle feeding operations statewide. Nebraska consistently has more cattle in the state than it does people. \r\n\r\n#### 3. Kansas\r\nKansas is home to 6.83% of the United State cattle or 6.45 million heads. The beef cattle sector is the single largest sector in the Kansas agriculture industry. According to the [Kansas Department of Agriculture](https://agriculture.ks.gov/docs/default-source/ag-growth-summit/january-2018-documents/beef-sector.pdf?sfvrsn=143c80c1_20), beef cattle farming and ranching has a direct output of approximately $6.3 billion and employs over 34,000 Kansas residents. Beef and beef product exports from Kansas account for about 18-26% of total U.S. beef exports. \r\n\r\n#### 4. California\r\nCalifornia has the fourth-highest number of cattle in the United States of 5.2 million. This is about 5.51% of the total U.S. cattle. California is the nationâs top agricultural state overall. In 2017, cattle and calves generated about $3.2 billion in revenue and the state was home to 13,694 cattle ranches. \r\n\r\n#### 5. Oklahoma\r\nOklahoma also has about 5.2 million cattle, tied with California as having the fourth-highest number. Even with such a large number of cattle, about 97% of operations are family-owned and operated. The beef industry is the stateâs largest agriculture segment and is valued at approximately $4.8 billion.\r\n\r\n#### 6. Missouri\r\nMissouri has the sixth-highest number of cattle in the United States with 4.35 million head. This is about 4.61% of the total U.S. cattle. Missouri is also one of the top states for herd expansion. Missouriâs beef industry directly provides over 45,000 jobs and supports over 72,000 jobs (directly, indirectly, or induced). \r\n\r\n#### 7. Iowa\r\nIowa has the seventh-highest number of cattle with 3.9 million, about 4.13% of the total U.S. cattle. In 2017, Iowaâs cattle industry contributed over $6.8 billion in business activity to the stateâs economy. Jobs directly and indirectly related to the cattle industry and jobs induced by the cattle industry total 33,147. In 2018, Iowaâs beef and beef variety exports totaled 2.983 billion pounds. \r\n\r\n#### 8. South Dakota\r\nSouth Dakota ties with Iowa as having the seventh-highest number of cattle with 3.9 million head. There are about 17,000 ranch and cattlemen that produce these 3.9 million head of cattle, with the majority of them are in family businesses. The direct impact of the beef industries in South Dakota is $2.284 billion and over 12,500 full-time jobs. \r\n\r\n#### 9. Wisconsin\r\nWisconsin has a total of 3.45 million head of cattle, comprising about 3.65% of the United Stateâs total. Wisconsinâs beef industry provides 35,100 jobs and contributes $2.1 billion in total income to the stateâs economy. Additionally, the beef industry allows more than $200 million to be provided annually to state and local governments through income, sales, and property taxes.\r\n\r\n#### 10. Colorado\r\nFinishing the top ten beef producers is Colorado, which has 2.8 million head of cattle or 2.97% of the U.S. total. There are about 11,267 beef cattle farms in Colorado, 91% of which are family or individually owned. Colorado is the fourth-largest exporter of fresh and frozen beef in the United States. Coloradoâs leading producer of beef is Weld County. \r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["beef-production-by-state","corn-production-by-state","oil-production-by-state","wine-production-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"beef-production-by-state","name":"Beef Production By State"},{"article":"Whether youâre a soon-to-be college student trying to figure out your next move after high school graduation or you have children in your household, thereâs one thing that both have in common: the desire to find the best schools.\n\nA great school system is a selling point for homes on the market, and college students are willing to pay extra money to attend out-of-state schools. Education"},{"article":"If you live in the United States and have some access to the news, you know that gun control is a hot topic due to the rising number of school shootings and other mass shootings. While there are citizens and politicians that are very vocal about increasing gun control and even banning guns completely, there are also many citizens that believe that everyone in the United States has the right to bear arms as outlined in the Second Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. \n \nGun laws are not determined by the federal government. Instead, each state determines the requirements for obtaining a gun, as well as the requirements for open and concealed carry. While there arenât any states that have banned gun ownership, there are states that have âmay issueâ policies that make it difficult for average citizens to obtain and own a gun. \n \nIn this article, however, weâre going to focus on the states that donât have such strict laws regarding owning or carrying a gun. These are considered the best states for gun owners. \n \nAlaska: Does not require a permit, purchase permit, or registration. There are no background checks on private fun sales, and open carry is allowed without a permit. \n\nArizona: No permit, purchase permit, or registration is required in this state. There are no background checks performed for private gun sales. Open carry is legal in Arizona. There are also no restrictions on magazine size in this state. \n\nIdaho: In Idaho, residents of the state do not need a permit. However, non-residents are required to have a permit for concealed carry within Idahoâs cities. No purchase permits or registrations are required. Open carry is allowed, and there are no magazine size restrictions. Idaho also does not require a background check for private sales. \n\nKansas: There is no carry permit, purchase permit, or registration required in Kansas. Open carry is allowed without a permit. No background checks for private gun sales or magazine size restrictions apply in this state. \n\nMaine: Maine does not require carry permits, purchase permits, or firearm registration. Open carry is permitted, while there is not a requirement to run a background check for a private sale. Magazine sizes are also not restricted. \n\nMississippi: No carry permit is required if a gun is carried in a holster, satchel, purse, handbag, or sheath. Mississippi does not require purchase permits, registration, or background checks on private sales. Open carry is legal, and there are no restrictions on magazine sizes. \n\nMissouri: No carry permit is required although residents can obtain a permit to be exempted from laws passed by local authorities. Missouri does not require purchase permits or registration, and background checks do not have to be performed during a private sale. This state allows open carry and does not restrict magazine size. \n\nNew Hampshire: This state doesnât require a carry permit, registration, or purchase permit. Open carry is allowed, but long guns located in vehicles canât be loaded. A background check is not required for a private sale. Magazine size is not restricted. \n\nVermont: This state does not issue or require carry permits. It also does not require purchase permits or registration. Vermont does, however, require ales only through licensed dealers unless the sale is to a family member. Open carry is allowed in Vermont. Vermont does put restrictions on magazine size. \n\nWest Virginia: This state does not require carry permits, purchase permits, or registration. Open carry is allowed. There are no restrictions on magazine size. There are also no laws that require background checks on private sales. \n\nWyoming: Residents are not required to get a carry permit. However, non-residents must get a permit to conceal carry. The state does not limit the size of magazines, does not require background checks for private sales, and doesnât require purchase permits or registration. Open carry is allowed in this state. \n\n","data":{"states":["Alaska","Arizona","Idaho","Kansas","Maine","Mississippi","Missouri","New Hampshire","Vermont","West Virginia","Wyoming"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["best-states-for-gun-owners","concealed-carry-states","concealed-carry-reciprocity-states","constitutional-carry-states","gun-deaths-by-state","gun-deaths-per-capita-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","gun-ownership-by-state","gun-violence-by-state","guns-per-capita","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","open-carry-states"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Best States for Gun Owners (2018)","link":"https://www.gunsandammo.com/editorial/best-states-for-gun-owners-2018/327233"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"best-states-for-gun-owners","name":"Best States For Gun Owners"},{"article":"Being an educator is one of the most important jobs a person can hold. After all, without teachers, children wouldnât gain the crucial skills and knowledge they need to become successful adults.\n\nHowever, in many states across the nation, teachers have low salaries, no support from school administrators, and work high-pressure jobs. A study from the National Center for Education Statistics shows that nearly one-fifth of teachers donât last more than one year in their job due to the high stress and low pay. The study further indicates that almost half donât make it to five years.\n\nFortunately, though, there are states that recognize the value of educators. Several studies have been conducted to find the best states for teachers. In terms of income, the top state is New York, which pays teachers an average of over $76,000 per year. Alaska comes in behind New York as the state with the second-highest salary for teachers. Connecticut, California, and Massachusetts also have high average salaries for educators.\n\nHowever, this doesnât show the full picture. Many of these states, including Alaska and New York, have a cost of living that is higher than the national average. Even though these teachers are making more money, the price of everything from housing to utilities and groceries is much higher than in other states.\n\nTo get a more comprehensive look at the best states for teachers, we can take a look at a [study conducted by WalletHub](https://wallethub.com/edu/best-and-worst-states-for-teachers/7159/). This study looked at 22 indicators including safety and income growth potential to determine which states are the most teacher-friendly.\n\nTeacher salaries are based on [data from the 2017-2018 school year](https://www.businessinsider.com/teacher-salary-in-every-state-2018-4#6-new-jersey-46). \n\n## 10 Best States for Teachers\n\n#### 1. North Dakota\nNorth Dakota is the best state for teachers in the United States according to WalletHubâs findings. North Dakota ranked 11th for âOpportunity \u0026 Competitionâ and third for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environment.â North Dakota has the second-lowest pupil-to-teacher ratio of any state, which is important because it allows teachers to better manage their classes and provide individual attention to each student. The average teacher salary in North Dakota is $54,421 per year. \n\n#### 2. New Jersey\nNew Jersey is the second-best state for teachers in the nation, ranking first for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environment.â New Jersey has the third-lowest pupil-to-teacher ratio and the fourth-highest public school spending per student, spending about $21,866 per student. New Jerseyâs public school systems are also ranked second in the U.S. The average teacher salary in New Jersey is $69,917, the sixth-highest in the country. \n\n#### 3. Pennsylvania\nPennsylvania is the third-best state for teachers in the U.S. Pennsylvania ranks second for âOpportunity \u0026 Competitionâ and 10th for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environment.â Pennsylvania has the ninth-highest teacher salary of any state of $67,398, which is the second-highest when adjusted for cost of living. Pennsylvania teachers believe the state needs to work on teacher starting salaries and pensions as areas of improvement. \n\n#### 4. Wyoming\nWyoming is the fourth-best state overall for teachers, ranking fourth for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environmentâ as well. The state has the sixth-best pupil-to-teacher ratio among all 50 states and the seventh-highest amount of public funding per student. Additionally, Wyoming teachers have the highest average starting salary for new teachers and one of the lowest staff turnover rates. The average teacher salary in Wyoming is $58,578.\n\n#### 5. Connecticut\nConnecticut ranks fifth for the best states for teachers. Connecticut ranks second for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environmentâ and ranks third for the best school systems behind New Jersey and Massachusetts. The state is also known for having small class sizes, some of the best-paid teachers, and full retirement benefits that are favorable enough to incentivize about 55% of teachers to continue working until they qualify for a pension. The average teacher salary in Connecticut is $73,113 \n\n#### 6. Illinois\nIllinois is the sixth-best state for teachers in the U.S. overall and also ranks sixth for âOpportunity \u0026 Competition,â with the second-best income growth potential for teachers among all 50 states. Additionally, Illinois school systems rank 12th for public school spending per student. The average teacher salary in Illinois is $65,776.\n\n#### 7. Minnesota\nMinnesota is ranked both seventh-best overall for teachers and seventh for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environment.â Minnesotaâs public schools are ranked as some of the best in the country, with the second-highest math and highest median SAT scores of any state. The average teacher salary in Minnesota is $57,782 per year. \n\n#### 8. Massachusetts\nThe eighth-best state for teachers in the United States is Massachusetts. Massachusetts is ranked fifth for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environment.â Massachusetts has the best public school systems in the U.S. The state is also the fifth-biggest spender per student. Massachusetts is also the most educated state in the country. The average teacher salary in the state is $79,710. \n\n#### 9. Utah\nUtah is the ninth-best state for teachers in the U.S. Utah is ranked eighth for âOpportunity \u0026 Competition.â Despite being one of the best states for teachers, Utah has the second-lowest public school spending per student and the third-highest pupil-to-teacher ratio, which is likely because the state has a teacher short of about 1,600. The average annual teacher salary in Utah is $47,604, the fourth-lowest in the country.\n\n#### 10. New York\nNew York finishes the ten best states for teachers. New York is ranked sixth for âAcademic \u0026 Work Environmentâ with the fourth-lowest projected teacher turnover. New York has the highest public school spending per student of $23,091. States For Teachers"},{"article":"What is the best state to live in? If someone asks you what the best state to live in is, youâll probably say your state or a state youâve lived in before. If you ask your neighbor, a friend, or a relative, their answer may be different. Everyone has a different opinion of the best states based on different factors. One person may like one state because it isnât densely populated. Someone else may enjoy another state because of its weather. Because we all have opinions on what makes something the âbest,â itâs hard to determine exactly what state is the best to live.\n\nHowever, some publications and organizations have done their research, looked at various factors, and have created lists of the best states in the United States. One of the most comprehensive records is the Best States Ranking by U.S. News \u0026 World Report. \n\nThis list looks at multiple points of data to determine the best states in the nation. Metrics include health care, education, the economy, infrastructure, quality of life, state fiscal stability, crime and corrections (public safety), and natural environment to determine the best states. The full methodology used to determine the best states can be found [here.](https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/articles/methodology)\n\nHere is a list of the top ten best states to live in the United States:\n\n#### 1. Washington\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 4th  \n\u003e **Education**: 4th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 3rd  \n\u003e **Crime**: 15th  \n\nWashington state ranks first as the best state to live in. Washington ranked fourth for health and education, third for the economy, and second for infrastructure. Additionally, residents wonât pay state income tax, enjoy a thriving job market and global business relationships, and have many higher education opportunities. Washington is also one of the most environmentally-friendly states and has beautiful scenery to match. \n\n#### 2. New Hampshire\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 16th  \n\u003e **Education**: 5th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 13th  \n\u003e **Crime**: 1st  \n\nNew Hampshire is the second-best state to live in in the United States. New Hampshire ranks first for opportunity and crime \u0026 corrections as well as fourth for the natural environment and fifth for education. New Hampshire is one of the safest and healthiest states in America. The job market is strong, specifically in Portsmouth, where has one of the lowest unemployment rates out of 372 metropolitan areas in the United States and has been rated among the 50 best job markets. \n\n#### 3. Minnesota\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 10th  \n\u003e **Education**: 17th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 18th  \n\u003e **Crime**: 16th  \n\nMinnesota is the third best state to live in. Minnesota ranks third for natural environment and opportunity. Minnesota has a strong economy and the affordability to live and play in a state full of art, culture, and entertainment. Minnesotaâs busy big cities are among the cleanest and greenest in the nation, coupled with some of the friendliest people.\n\n#### 4. Utah\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 9th  \n\u003e **Education**: 10th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 2nd  \n\u003e **Crime**: 12th  \n\nThe fourth-best state to live in is Utah. Utah ranks second for the economy, third for infrastructure, and fifth for fiscal stability. Utah residents enjoy a high quality of life and low crime rates, as well as a beautiful landscape with five of Americaâs national parks. Utah is also more affordable than its neighbor state, Colorado.\n\n#### 5. Vermont\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 11th  \n\u003e **Education**: 8th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 29th  \n\u003e **Crime**: 2nd  \n\nVermont ranks as the fifth-best state in America. Vermont ranks second for crime \u0026 correction, seventh for the natural environment, and eighth for education. Residents enjoy a high quality of life and friendly neighbors and are surrounded by a pristine environment. Outdoor enthusiasts, skiers, and snowboarders will find Vermont to be a paradise. \n\n#### 6. Maryland\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 8th  \n\u003e **Education**: 13th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 26th  \n\u003e **Crime**: 22nd  \n\nThe sixth-best state in America to live in is Maryland. Situated right next to the nationâs capital, Maryland allows residents all the perks of Washington D.C. without the expensive cost of living. Marylandâs economy is continually one of the strongest in the nation and the state is home to some of the best hospitals, including John Hopkins Hospital, the number one hospital for 21 years on U.S. News \u0026 World Reportâs annual list. \n\n#### 7. Virginia\n\n\u003e **Healthcare**: 18th  \n\u003e **Education**: 7th  \n\u003e **Economy**: 25th  \n\u003e **Crime**: 9th  \n\nVirginia is the seventh-best state in America. Northern Virginia is also right near Washington D.C., giving residents access to the jobs and attractions there. Virginia itself also has a strong job market and a highly educated population. Virginia has beautiful natural environments, sizable cities, and small towns to fit a wide range of preferences. \n\n#### 8. Massachusetts ranks first for education, second for health care, and fourth for crime and corrections. people that settle down to have a family want to find the best place to raise their children. Some people move from the busy city to the more relaxed suburbs or rural areas. Others move from states with high costs of living to ones that are more affordable in terms of cost-of-living and college tuition prices. \n \nThere isnât a universal way to determine which states are the best for raising a family. After all, you could probably find people from all 50 states that would tout the benefits of raising a family within their own states. However, a new study from MoneyRates.com examines a few different factors to determine which states are the highest ranked for raising a family. \n \nThis study took a look at different factors including college tuition expenses, the overall cost of living, as well as access to child-friendly amenities such as parks and libraries. \n \nAccording to this study, Utah is the best state to raise a family. This is primarily due to its low college tuition costs, which are the third lowest in the nation. Utah is also one of the safest states due to a low occurrence of violent crimes, and the state is home to a variety of family-friendly amenities. \n \nComing in second is the state of Wyoming, which has the cheapest public college tuition rates in the entire nation for in-state students. This state also has a low rate of violent crime and a general low cost of living. \n \nNew Jersey, despite its high cost of living, is the third best state for raising a family based on this study. New Jersey has many family-friendly neighborhoods and amenities and excellent school systems. \n \nVirginia is also near the top of the list at fourth place. Even though its college tuition rates are higher than many other states, factors including low rates of violent crime, quality childhood education, and childrenâs health programs make this one of the best states for raising a family. \n \nIn fifth place in the study is Idaho. This state is one of the safest for raising children and also offers low tuition rates for college. However, one thing to note is that there arenât as many family-friendly amenities as there are in other top-ranking states. \n \nThese are the top five states for raising a family in the United States. States to Raise a Family","link":"https://wallethub.com/edu/best-states-to-raise-a-family/31065/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"best-states-to-raise-a-family","name":"Best States To Raise A Family"},{"article":"Many of us look forward to the day that we retire. All of the years of hard work will be behind us, and weâll be able to begin to enjoy the fruits of our labors. Some of us have even planned where we will retire. Maybe itâs a state known for warm sunshine or beautiful beaches. Perhaps itâs a state with rolling fields and beautiful countryside. Perhaps you want to retire in a beautiful condo in the middle of all of the action.\n\nWhether retirement is many years away or youâre counting down the days, itâs never too early or too late to begin researching your options for retirement â starting with the states that are ranked as the best for retirement.\n\nItâs important to note that there is no definitive measure of the best state for retirement. However, some publications and think tanks have used several factors to compile their lists of the best states for retirement.\n\nKiplinger created one list. The factors used to determine the ranking of all 50 states include living expenses, health care costs, poverty rates, and the economic wellness of the state.\n\nBelow are the ten best states for retirement.\n\n#### 1. South Dakota\n\nSouth Dakota ranks as the best state for retirement in the United States. The average cost of living in South Dakota is 4% below the national average, including healthcare costs. South Dakota has one of the highest numbers of arts, entertainment, and recreation businesses per capita. The average annual spending for a comfortable retirement is about $60,998.  Additionally, South Dakota is the third-most tax-friendly state in the U.S. with no state income tax, which means Social Security benefits and other retirement income are not taxed.\n\n#### 2. Hawaii\n\nHawaii is the second-best state for retirement in the country. Although Hawaii has the highest cost of living in the United States, the average household income for people ages 65 and older is 33.8% above the national average at $71,997 and healthcare costs are 11.4% below the national average. Hawaii also has a beautiful landscape that many retirees consider to be their ideal retirement location.\n\n#### 3. Georgia\n\nGeorgia is the third-best state for retirement. Georgiaâs cost of living is about 7% below the national average and has the sixth-lowest average cost for a retired couple in the U.S. Georgia also has favorable tax conditions. Social security is exempt from state taxes in Georgia, as well as up to $35,000 of most types of retirement income for those between 62 and 64, and up to $65,000 per taxpayer 65 and older ($130,000 per couple). Combine all of that with warm summers and mild winters and Georgia is an ideal retirement state. \n\n#### 4. North Dakota\n\nNorth Dakota is the fourth-best state for retirement in the U.S. The cost of living in North Dakota is just 1% above the national average, but average healthcare costs for a retired couple are below average at $414,455. The annual spending for a comfortable retirement in the state is about $61,222 and it is considered to be tax-friendly with state income tax ranging from 1.01% to 2.9% and property taxes are 1.01%.\n\n#### 5. Tennessee\n\nTennessee ranks fifth for the best states to retire, especially for budget-conscious retirees. Tennesseeâs cost of living is 12% below the U.S. average and the state does not levy state income taxes, helping retirement income go further. Tennesseeâs annual spending for a comfortable retirement is $55,425, the seventh-lowest in the country. \n\n#### 6. Alabama\n\nAlabama is the sixth-best state for retirement in the United States. Alabama has mild winters, beaches, and golf topped off by a cost of living that is 13% below the national average. Alabamaâs highest state income tax rate is only 5%, and Social Security benefits and income from traditional pension plans are exempt from income tax. Additionally, Alabama has the second-lowest property taxes in the U.S. at a rate of 0.42% and all homeowners 65 or older are exempt from state property taxes.\n\n#### 7. Virginia\n\nThe seventh-best state for retirement is Virginia. The beautiful scenery and charm of Virginia, unfortunately, come with a cost of living 7% above the U.S. average; however, the average income for households 65 and older is $59,869 to cover it. Additionally, healthcare costs for a retired couple are below average at $408,950. Virginia does not tax Social Security benefits and those 65 and older can deduct up to $12,000 per person. \n\n#### 8. Florida\n\nFlorida is the eighth-best state for retirement. Florida has the highest share of seniors of any state in the U.S. comprising 19.1% of the population. Florida has warm winters, miles of beaches, and a cost of living that is about average. Florida has no state income tax, estate tax, or inheritance tax and the state does not tax Social Security or other retirement income. \n\n#### 9. New Hampshire\n\nNew Hampshire ranks ninth for the best state for retirement. New Hampshire has a cost of living that is 18% above the national average; however, this is partially balanced out by the tax situation. New Hampshire does not tax Social Security benefits or other retirement income and does not levy any sales tax. Additionally, New Hampshire ranks fifth in the country for the best senior healthcare. \n\n#### 10. Utah\n\nUtah finishes the top ten list of best retirement states. Utah is a great state for retirees who love to be outdoors and stay active with five national parks, five national forests, and 43 state parks. Utah ranks second out of all 50 states for the overall health of its senior population. While the cost of living is slightly above average (4% above) and Utah isnât tax-friendly, it has the third-lowest poverty rate in the U.S. for people 65 and older. \n","data":{"states":["South States To Retire"},{"article":"The Bible Belt is a region located in the southern United States. This informal term is used to describe an area with conservative Protestant values. This region also has attendance numbers at Christian churches that exceed the national average.\n\nThe term âBible Beltâ was first coined in 1924. Journalist H.L. Mencken used the word in an article appearing in the Chicago Daily Tribune. Later, Mencken claimed to be the inventor of the term.\n\nThe number of religious citizens living in the Bible Belt region is dramatically higher when compared to other areas of the U.S. For example; the most non-religious citizens reside in Vermont. Thirty-seven percent of people that live in Vermont state they are non-religious. Compare this to Alabama, the Bible Belt state with the highest percentage of residents identifying as non-religious at just 12%.\n\nWhile there are a few definitions of what states make up the Bible Belt, itâs accepted that the following states are included:\n\n- Alabama\n- Arkansas\n- Georgia\n- Kentucky\n- Louisiana\n- Mississippi\n- North Carolina\n- Oklahoma\n- South Carolina\n- Tennessee\n- Texas\n- Utah\n\nTwo cities even are known as the Buckle of the Bible Belt. These cities are Abilene, Texas, which is the location of three Christian universities, and Nashville, Tennessee, which has multiple Christian schools and over 700 churches.\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Arkansas","Georgia","Kentucky","Louisiana","Mississippi","North Carolina","Oklahoma","South
