Bible Belt Extends Throughout the American South","link":"https://www.thoughtco.com/the-bible-belt-1434529"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"bible-belt-states","name":"Bible Belt States"},{"article":"Birth rate is the number of live births per 1,000 women of the total population. The birth rate is used in conjunction with the mortality and migration rates to calculate population growth. \r\n\r\nBirth rate is often used interchangeably with fertility rate; however, fertility rate is the number of births per 1,000 women of childbearing age (ages 15 to 44) occurring in a particular year. \r\n\r\nThe birth rate is a concern for some governments. Some governments around the world are attempting to increase the birth rate with financial incentives or offering support services to new mothers. This is due to these countries having birth rates lower than their mortality rates, resulting in a declining population. Other governments, however, have the opposite problem of high birth rates that are causing overpopulation. This is seen in Chinaâs [one-child policy.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-child_policy)\r\n\r\nAdditionally, high birth rates are typically associated with low life expectancy, low living standards and education levels, and low social status for women. Some policies to low the birth rate in some countries have focused on improving womenâs rights and sexual and reproductive health. Improved information and access to birth control methods have achieved good results in Iran and Bangladesh. \r\n\r\nAccording to the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/), the U.S. birth rate was the lowest in 2018 than it has been in 32 years. The CDCâs [report](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/vsrr/vsrr-007-508.pdf) states that the total number of births in 2018 was down 2% from 2017. These numbers are lower than they were after the Great Depression. \r\n\r\nSeveral reasons are cited for the decline in the birth rate. More Americans are delaying marriage and having children as a result of pursuing higher education and focusing on building careers before building families. Additionally, there are fewer teen pregnancies and greater education and availability of contraception. \r\n\r\nAmerican women in their 30s have a higher birthrate for 2017 and 2018 than women in their 20s. Because of the 36.6 million American jobs lost between January 2009 to December 2017, some couples do not want children because they are unsure if they will have stable jobs in the future. \r\n\r\nWith a total fertility rate of 1.8 births per woman and only 3,788,235 babies born in 2018, the U.S. reproducing is below a viable replacement rate, which it has fallen short of since 1971. The U.S. population growth, therefore, relies on immigration.  \r\n\r\nThe U.S. birthrate is 11.6 per 1,000 population. The birth rate varies from state to state. [The National Vital Statistics System report from the CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvsr/nvsr68/nvsr68_13-508.pdf) lays out each stateâs birth rate, along with the fertility rate, total fertility rate, and fertility rate by age group of the mother. \r\n\r\nThe states with the lowest birth rates are:\r\n\r\n1.\tVermont (8.7)\r\n2.\tNew Hampshire (8.8)\r\n3.\tMaine (9.2)\r\n4.\tConnecticut (9.7)\r\n5.\tRhode Island (9.9)\r\n6.\tMassachusetts (10.0)\r\n7.\tOregon (10.1)\r\n8.\tWest Virginia (10.1)\r\n9.\tFlorida (10.4)\r\n10.\tPennsylvania (10.6)\r\n\r\nVermont has the lowest birth rate in the United States of 8.7 per 1,000 population. The six states with the lowest birth rates in the country are located in the northeast. These states will likely see their populations shrink between 2030 and 2040. \r\n\r\nThe states with the highest birth rates are:\r\n\r\n1.\tUtah (14.9)\r\n2.\tNorth Dakota (14.0)\r\n3.\tAlaska (13.7)\r\n4.\tSouth Dakota (13.5)\r\n5.\tTexas (13.2)\r\n6.\tNebraska (13.2)\r\n7.\tDistrict of Columbia (13.1)\r\n8.\tOklahoma (12.6)\r\n9.\tKansas (12.5)\r\n10.\tMississippi (12.4)\r\n\r\nUtah has the highest birth rate in the United States of 14.9 per 1,000 population. This is likely because of Utahâs large Mormon population, which is also the reason that Utah has the largest average household size in the country and the lowest median age in the country of 29.2. \r\n\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-rates-by-state","autism-rates-by-state","birth-rate-by-state","cancer-rates-by-state","circumcision-rates-by-state","corporate-tax-rates-by-state","crime-rate-by-state","depression-rates-by-state","employment-rate-by-state","flu-rates-by-state","infant-mortality-rate-by-state","labor-force-participation-rate-by-state","maternal-mortality-rate-by-state","murder-rate-by-state","obesity-rate-by-state","smoking-rates-by-state","state-tax-rates","suicide-rates-by-state","teen-pregnancy-rates-by-state","unemployment-rate-by-state","us-literacy-rates-by-state","vaccination-rates-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"birth-rate-by-state","name":"Birth Rate By State"},{"article":"Blue laws are laws designed to restrict certain activities on Sundays (or other specific days) for religious reasons in order to observe a day of worship or rest. Blue law also may ban shopping or ban sale of specific items on Sundays.\n\nWhile blue laws may seem unconstitutional because they are based on religion, the U.S. Supreme Court has ruled them constitutional by citing that blue laws secure a day of rest for certain workers, and guarantee the free exercise of religion. \n\nThere are currently 28 states with blue laws, and the laws vary by each state, and different counties occasionally have their own blue laws.\n\n## Arkansas\n\nOut of Arkansasâs 75 counties, 39 are âdryâ counties where the sale of alcohol is prohibited. Private facilities are given some exceptions, and must have hard-to-obtain licenses. \nThe sale of alcoholic beverages is entirely prohibited on Christmas Day. \nIn most counties, alcohol and liquor sales are not allowed on Sundays and statewide Christmas Day.\n\n## Delaware\n\nUp until 2003, Delaware banned the sale of liquor on Sundays. Today, alcoholic liquor can only be sold in specifically establishments between the hours of 9 am to 1 am.\n \n## Florida\nSome counties in Florida prohibit alcohol and sex toy sales on Sundays and during certain hours of the day.\n\n## Illinois\n\nHorse racing is prohibited on Sundays unless authorized by the local municipality. \nCar dealerships are closed on Sundays.\n\n## Indiana\n\nSunday alcohol sales are permitted between noon and 8pm.\n\n\n## Maine\n\nIt is illegal for almost all businesses to be open on Thanksgiving. \nHunting is illegal on Sundays.\n\n## Maryland\n\nProfessional sports cannot play games before 1pm on Sundays. \nExcept in Howard, Montgomery, and Prince George's counties, a new or used car dealer may not sell, barter, deliver, give away, show, or offer for sale a motor vehicle or certificate of title for a motor vehicle on Sunday.\n\n## Massachusetts\n\nCertain businesses have controlled hours of operation and the blue laws require that some businesses (retail establishments) pay their employees extra compensation on Sundays and on some holidays.\n\n## Michigan\n\nIt is prohibited to buy, sell, or participate in a trade of motor vehicles on Sunday. \n\n## Minnesota\n\nLiquor stores that choose to be open on Sundays are only allowed to operate between 11am and 6pm. \nCar dealerships are not allowed to be open or do business on Sundays anywhere in the state.\n\n## Mississippi\n\nThe sale of alcohol on Sundays is prohibited statewide.\n\n## New Jersey\n\nBergen County practices one of the only remaining Sunday closing laws. Shopping for clothing, electronics and furniture is not allowed on Sundays in Bergen County, which has four major malls. \nThe city of Paramus in Bergen County has stricter blue laws, which ban all type of work on Sundays except in grocery stores, pharmacies, hotels, restaurants and other hospitality workplaces.\n\n## New Mexico\n\nOn-premise alcohol sale is allowed from 7am to 2am and off-premise until midnight. \nNo alcohol sales on or off premise on Sundays or Christmas Day.\n\n## New York\n\nAlcohol can start being served on Sundays at 10am, thanks to introduction of the âBrunch Billâ in 2016. Certain New York counties have their own separate blue laws.\n\n## North Carolina\n\nAlcohol sales are prohibited between 2am and 7am Monday through Saturday, and between 2am and either 10am or 12pm on Sundays depending on the county. \nGun hunting is prohibited between 9:30am and 12:30pm on Sundays.\n\n## Oklahoma\nCar dealerships are closed on Sunday. \nSelling packaged liquor is prohibited on Sundays. \nAlcohol sales are prohibited on New Yearâs Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.\n\n## Pennsylvania\n\nHunting is prohibited on Sundays, except for foxes, crows, or coyotes. \nCar dealerships are closed on Sunday.\n\n## Tennessee\n\nAlcohol cannot be consumed on-premise between 3am and 10am on Sundays. If the local government had decided against extended hours for alcohol sales, the prohibited hours are 3am to noon.\n\n## Texas\n\nCar dealerships must close on either Saturday or Sunday, and have the option to determine which day.\nAny retailer with a license can sell beer and wine for âoff-premise consumption.â Beer can be sold from 7am to midnight Monday through Saturday, and from midnight to 1am and noon until midnight on Sunday.\nWine can be sold between 7am to midnight Monday through Saturday, and from midnight to 2am and noon until midnight on Sunday.\nLiquor must be sold at specialized stores. Liquor cannot be sold on Sunday; on New Yearâs Day, Thanksgiving or Christmas; and between 9pm and 10am.\n\n## Utah\n\nBars, clubs, and taverns are allowed to sell alcohol from 10am to 1am.\nRestaurants that serve alcohol are allowed between 11:30am to 1am, and the alcohol must be ordered with food. Additionally, alcohol sales have to remain under 30% of the restaurantâs total sales.\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-laws-by-state","blue-laws-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","clothing-laws-by-state","common-law-marriage-states","filial-responsibility-laws-by-state","final-paycheck-laws-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","helmet-law-states","homeschool-laws-by-state","incest-laws-by-state","late-fee-laws-by-state","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","marijuana-laws-by-state","mushroom-laws-by-state","pepper-spray-laws-by-state","seat-belt-laws-by-state","states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","tiny-house-laws-by-state","voter-id-laws-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"blue-laws-by-state","name":"Blue Laws By State"},{"article":"When the United States approaches a presidential election, the terms âred statesâ and âblue statesâ are often used by the media. What is a red state? What is a blue state?\n\nIf a state is a red state, the voters within that state primarily vote for the Republican Party. If a state is a blue state, its residents mostly vote for the Democratic Party. The term red state is also used to describe a state that is perceived to have conservative views, while a blue state is understood to have more liberal views.\n\nThis hasnât always been the case, however. During the 1980s, Democrats were associated with the color red, while Republicans were represented by the color blue. It was during the 2000 presidential election when journalist Tim Russert used the terms âred statesâ and âblue statesâ based on the colored maps that were used during his televised coverage. Since that time, media outlets have used red for Republican and blue for Democrat as the standard color scheme for their maps.\n\nThe measurement of how strongly a United States congressional district or state leans toward the Democratic or Republican Party compared to the nation as a whole is known as the Cook Partisan Voting Index (PVI). For example, if the national average is 51% Democratic, and the Democratic candidate of a state wins 62% of a two-party share, then that state voted 11 percentage points more Democratic than the country, for D+11.\n\nHouse balance gives a better indication of a partyâs electoral strength in a state than basic party identification and provides a definitive score that shows the strength of a party in an election. House balance takes into account the number of independents in a state. For example, California receives 55 electoral votes and has a house balance of 46D and 7R (53 out of 55).\n\n\nAccording to Gallup tracking, there were 15 stable blue states in 2017. Index","link":"https://cookpolitical.com/pvi-0"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"blue-states","name":"Blue States"},{"article":"The term âborder statesâ dates back to the American Civil War of 1861 to 1865. This term was used to describe slave states that did not secede from the Union or joint he Confederacy. The term âborder stateâ was used because free states bordered the states to the north. Four of the five border states also shared borders with Confederate states to the south.\n\nThe five border states were:\n\n- Delaware\n- Maryland\n- Kentucky\n- Missouri\n- West Virginia\n\nIn Delaware, slavery was rare leading up to the Civil War. Both houses of the General Assembly rejected secession from the Union.\n\nIn parts of Maryland, there was support for the Confederacy. However, Washington D.C. would have been surrounded if Maryland had joined the Confederacy. During the Civil War, Marylandâs state legislature wanted to stay neutral. During the war, a new constitution was drafted that made slavery illegal in the state.\n\nThe state of Kentucky passed two resolutions to stay neutral during the war. While the governor of Kentucky, Beriah Magoffin, believed that states should stick to the Constitution and not secede from the Union, he also refused to furnish troops to defeat the southern states. Neutrality was  broken and Kentucky began to back the Union.\n\nIn Missouri, the Missouri Constitutional Convention voted to stay in the Union but refused coercion of the southern states. Secession ordinances were later adopted, although the state was never entirely under Confederate control. In 1865, the state voted to abolish slavery.\n\nWest Virginia became a state during the war when it separated from the state of Virginia. After it was established, West Virginia was considered a border state.\n","data":{"states":["Delware","Maryland","Kentucky","Missouri","West Virginia"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["bible-belt-states","border-states","coastal-states",{"link":"4-corners-states","title":"Four Corners States"},"east-coast-states","eastern-states","flyover-states","gulf-states","great-lakes-states","lower-48-states",{"link":"midwest-states","title":"Midwestern United States"},{"link":"mid-atlantic-states","title":"Mid-Atlantic States"},"mountain-states","new-england-states","northern-states","rust-belt-states","southeast-states","southwest-states","west-coast-states"]}},"sources":[{"name":"The Border States","link":"https://www.nps.gov/resources/story.htm%3Fid%3D205"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.148Z","path":"border-states","name":"Border States"},{"article":"Are brass knuckles legal?\r\n\r\nBrass knuckles are pieces of metal shaped to fit around the knuckles and are weapons used in hand-to-hand combat. They are designed so that the userâs punch has a more concentrated force with a smaller and harder contact point.\r\n\r\nBrass knuckles are typically treated like other weapons such as knives and firearms in other countries. \r\n\r\nBrass knuckles are illegal in many countries including Hong Kong, Austria, Belgium, Bosnia, Canada, Croatia, Cyprus, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Malaysia, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Russia, Spain, Turkey, Singapore, Taiwan, and the United Kingdom.\r\n\r\nSome countries have specific regulations on brass knuckles. For example, in Serbia, brass knuckles are legal to purchase for people over 16 years old, but cannot be carried in public. \r\n\r\nIn the United States, there are no federal laws regulating brass knuckles; however, there are various states, county and city laws that prohibit their sale or possession. Brass knuckles can typically be purchased at markets or from companies that make belt buckles and other metal goods (where legal).\r\n\r\nBelow are each stateâs brass knuckle laws.\r\n\r\n## Alabama\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Alabama. Carrying brass knuckles in a concealed manner is Illegal in Alabama. You must obtain a permit to carry a concealed weapon. Failing to adhere to this law can result in a misdemeanor.\r\n\r\n## Alaska\r\n\r\n-\tAccording to Sec. 11.61.210. âA person commits the crime of misconduct involving weapons in the fourth degree if the personâ¦ manufactures, possesses, transports, sells, or transfers metal knuckles.â\r\n\r\n## Arizona\r\n\r\n-\tIn Arizona, individuals over 21 can legally carry a concealed firearm or deadly weapon without a permit. Brass knuckles are typically considered to be a deadly weapon. The use of brass knuckles can still result in a felony charge.\r\n\r\n## Arkansas\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Arkansas. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Charges can either be a misdemeanor or a felony, depending on the scenario in which the law was broken and how severe the consequences were.\r\n\r\n## California\r\n\r\n-\tCalifornia imposes a strict ban on all kinds of brass knuckles, whether they are metal or plastic. This includes selling, buying, using, carrying, repairing, lending and manufacturing. Breaking this law lands an individual in either California State Prison or Jail.\r\n\r\n## Colorado\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Colorado. This includes brass knuckles that are used as jewelry, accessories or anything else exhibiting them. Failing to adhere to this law can land an individual a $1,000 fine and one year of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## Connecticut\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Connecticut; however, it is illegal to carry them concealed. One will need to have either a license or a permit to do so. Failing to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor.\r\n\r\n## Delaware\r\n\r\n-\tIt is illegal to carry brass knuckles in Delaware without a conceal carry permit. First-time violations of this law lead to felony charges.\r\n\r\n## District of Columbia\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Washington DC. This includes brass knuckles that are used as jewelry, accessories or anything else exhibiting them. Brass knuckles, among some other weapons, may be possessed by on-duty military personnel, sheriffs, prison wardens, policemen, and some other select professions. \r\n\r\n\r\n## Florida\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Florida, but you must have a license or permit to carry a concealed weapon if you wish to carry them hidden or concealed. Failing to do so can result in a misdemeanor charge punishable by up to $1,000 in fines and three years in prison.\r\n\r\n## Georgia\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal to own and carry in Georgia. Using the brass knuckles to injure another person is a criminal act and one cannot carry brass knuckles in schools or hospitals. \r\n\r\n## Hawaii\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal to sell and possess, but cannot be carried or stored in oneâs vehicle. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor. \r\n\r\n## Idaho\r\n\r\n-\tThe law in Idaho does not specifically state whether brass knuckles are legal or not. However, brass knuckles can be considered to be a dangerous weapon; therefore, it is up to the courts to determine this and how the knuckles were used and if the owner had criminal intent.\r\n\r\n## Illinois\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles of any type and material are prohibited in Illinois. This includes anything shaped like a brass knuckle, including jewelry, bags, pendants or necklaces. Carrying or owning brass knuckles is illegal in Illinois, and using brass knuckles to injure is a felony charge.\r\n\r\n## Indiana\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal to own and carry in Indiana. Brass knuckles are not specifically labeled as a dangerous weapon under Indiana law; however, it is illegal to use them in an act of violence.\r\n\r\n## Iowa\r\n\r\n-\tThe law in Iowa does not specifically state whether brass knuckles are legal or not. However, brass knuckles can be considered a dangerous weapon; therefore, it is up to the courts to determine this and how the knuckles were used and if the owner had criminal intent. \r\n\r\n## Kansas\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are strictly prohibited in Kansas. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Charges can either be a misdemeanor or a felony, depending on the scenario in which the law was broken and how severe the consequences were.\r\n\r\n## Kentucky\r\n\r\n-\tKentucky requires a license to carry a concealed deadly weapon anywhere other than an individualâs own property, including brass knuckles. Carrying a concealed weapon without a license is considered a Class A misdemeanor and can lead to up to 12 months in jail and a fine of up to $500.\r\n\r\n## Louisiana\r\n\r\n-\tLouisiana allows the carrying of concealed weapons, such as brass knuckles, as long as the individual has a legal permit to carry a concealed weapon.\r\n\r\n## Maine\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in the state of Maine.\r\n\r\n## Maryland \r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Maryland; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed unless you have a license or permit to carry concealed weapons. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and lead to a fine up to $1000 and up to three years of imprisonment. \r\n\r\n## Massachusetts\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Massachusetts. This includes possession, sale, and manufacture of brass knuckles. Failure to adhere to this law will lead to a fine between $50 and $1000 or up to six months of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## Michigan\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles of any type and material are prohibited in Michigan. This includes anything shaped like a brass knuckle, including jewelry, bags, pendants or necklaces. Manufacture, sale or possession of brass knuckles are felony charges that lead to a fine of up to $2500 and imprisonment of up to five years.\r\n\r\n## Minnesota\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are strictly prohibited in Minnesota. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Charges can either be a misdemeanor or a felony, depending on the scenario in which the law was broken and how severe the consequences were.\r\n\r\n## Mississippi\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Mississippi; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed unless you have a license or permit to carry concealed weapons. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and lead to a fine up to $1000 and up to three years of imprisonment. \r\n\r\n## Missouri\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are strictly prohibited in Missouri. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Violation of this law can result in a Class D felony charge with up to four years in prison. \r\n\r\n## Montana\r\n\r\n-\tThe law in Montana does not specifically state whether brass knuckles are legal or not. However, brass knuckles can be considered a dangerous weapon; therefore, it is up to the courts to determine this and how the knuckles were used and if the owner had criminal intent.\r\n\r\n## Nebraska\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal to own in Nebraska; however, they are illegal to carry concealed unless the individual has a license or permit to do so. Certain places, such as churches, schools, and bars, prohibit concealed weapons even with a permit. Business owners have the right to prohibit weapons inside their business regardless of whether an individual has a permit or not. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor.\r\n\r\n## Nevada\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Nevada. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Failure to adhere to this law results in a misdemeanor leading to fines of up to $2,000 and/or up to one year in prison. \r\n## New Hampshire\r\n\r\n-\tIt is illegal to sell and carry brass knuckles in New Hampshire. Failure to adhere to this law results in a misdemeanor punishable by up to $2,000 in fines and up to one year in prison. \r\n\r\n## New Jersey\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal to possess and carry in New Jersey. However, one may be able to possess brass knuckles for lawful purposes such as for theater productions, personal collections, or other educational or entertainment purposes. Failure to adhere to this law, even if carrying in case of self-defense, will result in a felony with up to $10,000 in fines and up to 18 months in jail. If one is caught with brass knuckles with unlawful intent, punishment increases to a fine of $15,000 and three to five years in prison.\r\n\r\n## New Mexico\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in New Mexico; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed unless you have a license or permit to carry concealed weapons. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and lead to a fine up to $1000 and up to three years of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## New York\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in New York. This includes both metal and plastic knuckles. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and up to one year of imprisonment. \r\n\r\n## North Carolina \r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in North Carolina; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed unless you have a license or permit to carry concealed weapons. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and lead to a fine up to $1000 and up to three years of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## North Dakota\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in North Dakota; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed on oneâs person or in oneâs car without a permit. Even with a permit, concealed weapons are prohibited in certain places such as in a liquor store or public gatherings. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor charge. \r\n\r\n## Ohio\r\n\r\n-\tOhioâs law state that the use and possession of a deadly weapon are illegal but brass knuckles are not specifically mentioned. Brass knuckles, however, can be considered a deadly weapon, so one should use caution. Carrying a weapon concealed without a concealed carry permit is illegal and can result in fines and imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## Oklahoma\r\n\r\n-\tUnless in accordance with the Oklahoma Self Defense Act it is illegal to carry an offensive weapon, including brass knuckles. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor charge.\r\n\r\n## Oregon\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are not illegal in Oregon; however, it is illegal to carry them hidden or concealed unless you have a license or permit to carry concealed weapons. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor and lead to a fine up to $1000 and up to three years of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## Pennsylvania\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Pennsylvania. This includes selling, possessing, carrying, purchasing, manufacturing, repairing and transporting brass knuckles, whether they are made from metal or plastic. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor charge punishable by up to five years in prison. \r\n\r\n## Rhode Island\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal to possess and carry in Rhode Island. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor with fines up to $1,000 and up to one year of incarceration.\r\n\r\n## South Carolina\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal in South Carolina and one does not need a concealed carry permit. Brass knuckles are not allowed in schools or hospitals. It is illegal to possess brass knuckles if they are used with the intent to commit a crime. \r\n\r\n## South Dakota\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are legal in South Dakota. One may carry brass knuckles in a concealed manner unless they are being concealed with the intent to harm. Doing so will result in being charged with a felony.\r\n\r\n## Tennessee\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are strictly prohibited in Tennessee. This includes selling, brandishing, exhibiting, repairing, manufacturing, and possessing brass knuckles. Charges can either be a misdemeanor or a felony, depending on the scenario in which the law was broken and how severe the consequences were.\r\n\r\n## Texas\r\n\r\n-\tAs of September 1st, 2019, it is legal in Texas to possess and brass knuckles for self-defense purposes. Previously, carrying or possession was a misdemeanor punishable up to $4,000 in fines or up to one year in jail. \r\n\r\n## Utah\r\n\r\n-\tThe law in Utah does not specifically state whether brass knuckles are legal or not. However, brass knuckles can be considered a dangerous weapon; therefore, it is up to the courts to determine this and how the knuckles were used and if the owner had criminal intent.\r\n\r\n## Vermont \r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal to possess, use or sell in Vermont. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor with fines up to $1,000 and up to five years of imprisonment.\r\n\r\n## Virginia \r\n\r\n-\tIt is illegal to carry brass knuckles in Virginia without a concealed weapon permit. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor punishable by up to $2,500 in fines and up to one year in prison. Second-time offenders will face a felony charge.\r\n\r\n## Washington\r\n\r\n-\tBrass knuckles are illegal in Washington. Possession, distribution, or manufacturing of brass knuckles is seen as a gross misdemeanor punishable by fines up to $5,000 and up to one year in prison. \r\n\r\n## West Virginia\r\n\r\n-\tIt is illegal to carry brass knuckles in West Virginia without a concealed weapons permit. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor punishable by fines up to $1,000 and up to one year of prison.\r\n\r\n## Wisconsin\r\n\r\n-\tIn Wisconsin, brass knuckles are not illegal to own in oneâs home; however, brass knuckles cannot be carried concealed without a concealed carry permit. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a Class A misdemeanor.\r\n\r\n## Wyoming\r\n\r\n-\tIn Wyoming, brass knuckles are not illegal to possess, but it is illegal to carry a concealed weapon. Failure to adhere to this law will result in a misdemeanor punishable by fines up to $750 and up to six months in prison. \r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Brass In fact, itâs the second leading cause of death, coming only behind heart disease. Cancer is a disease that occurs when abnormal cells divide and begin to destroy body tissue. Cancer can affect nearly any part of the body. Some cancers can also shed cells into the bloodstream and spread throughout other parts of the body. \n \nAccording to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there were 1.658 million new cases of cancer in the United States in 2016. Nearly 600,000 people in the U.S. died as a result of cancer. When breaking this down, nearly 436 new cases were reported for every 100,000 people, while 156 out of every 100,000 people died of cancer. \n \nFemale breast cancer was the most common type of cancer when it came to new cases reported in 2016, affecting 124.2 out of every 100,000 people. Prostate cancer, lung cancer, and colon and rectum cancer were also the most prevalent types of cancers. The most deaths occurred in people that had cancer of the lung and bronchus, followed by female breast cancer, prostate cancer, and colon and rectum cancer. \n \nWhen looking at the numbers by state, the state of Kentucky had the highest rate of new cancer cases in 2016. levy assessed on the positive difference between the sale price of an asset and its original purchase price. Assets include shares of stock, a piece of land, jewelry, coin collections, or a business. \r\n\r\nCapital gains can be reduced by deducting capital losses that occur when a taxable asset is sold for less than the original purchase price, resulting in ânet capital gains.â\r\n\r\nThere are two types of capital gains tax: short-term and long-term. Short-term capital gains tax is levied on profits from the sale of an asset held for one year or less. The short-term capital gains tax rate equals the individualâs ordinary income tax rate (bracket). Long-term capital gains tax is levied on profits from the sale of an asset held for more than a year. Long-term capital gains tax rate is 0%, 15%, or 20% depending on the individualâs taxable income and filing status. Long-term capital gains tax rates are typically lower than short-term rates. \r\n\r\nIn addition to paying capital gains tax at the federal levels, a majority of U.S. states also have an additional tax rate between 2.90% and 13.30%. \r\n\r\nThe states with no additional state tax on capital gains are:\r\n\r\n-\tAlaska\r\n-\tFlorida\r\n-\tNew Hampshire\r\n-\tNevada\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tTennessee\r\n-\tTexas\r\n-\tWashington\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nThese are the same states that do not tax personal income on wages, although they might tax interest and dividends from investments, depending on the state. These states typically make up for their lack of overall tax income with higher sales and property taxes.  \r\n\r\nCalifornia has the highest capital gains tax rate of 13.30%. California has notoriously high taxes and with up to 39.6% in federal taxes alone, the state taxes can seem especially deep. For higher-income taxpayers, the capital gain rate at the federal level if 20%, plus a 3.8% net investment tax under Obamacare, plus 13.3%. \r\n\r\nHawaii has the second-highest capital gains tax rate of 11.00%, followed by New Jersey with 10.75%, Oregon with 9.90%, and Minnesota with 9.85%.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table of each stateâs capital gains tax rate. Gains Tax By State"},{"article":"What are car dealer fees? Car dealer fees are extra charges that a dealership adds to the final bill when you purchase a car. The most common additional fees are sales tax, vehicle registration, and a documentation fee. \r\n\r\nCar dealerships fees can often come as a surprise to car buyers because most car dealers will not bring them up during the negotiation stage when pricing a vehicle, but rather towards the end of the process.\r\n\r\nEvery dealership has a dealer documentation fee, which covers the office personnel doing the paperwork for the sale of a new or used car. These fees range from state-to-state and typically range from $50-$500. Depending on the state, fees might be determined by a percentage of the sale price. Many dealerships will not notify you of this fee until you are signing the final paperwork for your car; however, some dealerships will negotiate the fee with you and some will even remove it. \r\n\r\nCar buyers should be aware that 35 states do not have a limit on dealer documentation fees; therefore, car dealerships can price this fee as high as they want. Alaska has no limit on the dealership documentation fee, but the fee must be included in the price of the car. \r\n\r\nCurrently, New York has the lowest average dealership documentation fee of $75. \r\n\r\nBelow is a chart with the documentation fees of each state. \r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Dealer vehicle registration plate, commonly known as a license plate, is required for every vehicle for identification purposes. A vehicleâs title is a legal document that provides proof of ownership of a vehicle. \r\n\r\nEvery state requires motor vehicles to be registered and title with the stateâs transportation agency or department of motor vehicles (DMV). Motor vehicles may not be driven legally if either or both of these are expired.\r\n\r\nTitle fees are typically a one-time expense when the owner purchases the vehicle for the first time. License plate fees are often charged annually and can vary between states. Some states assess a flat fee while other states assess the registration fee based on vehicle weight, horsepower, or vehicle age. \r\n\r\nColorado, for example, assesses the registration fee based on the age and weight of the vehicle. Michigan and New Hampshire assess the registration fee based on the MSRP of the vehicle. Registration fees in Utah are based on the weight of the vehicle. Tax By State"},{"article":"A castle doctrine is a self-defense law that states that a personâs home (sometimes also a place of work or vehicle) is a place that grants one protections and immunities from prosecution in certain circumstance to use force or deadly force to defend oneself against an intruder. There is no duty to retreat from the situation in oneâs home (or workplace or vehicle if applicable) before using force, but there may be a duty to retreat in a public place. \n\nThe United States has two additional self-defense laws. The âStand Your Groundâ Law states that there is no duty to retreat from the situation before using deadly force, and is not limited to oneâs home, place of work, or vehicle. The âDuty to Retreatâ Law states that one cannot harm another in self-defense when it is possible to retreat from a threatening situation to a place of safety. \n\nCastle doctrines can vary slightly from state-to-state, with some states narrowing your right to use deadly force against an intruder. For example, in some states, you must provide evidence that an intruder was attempting to commit a felony. In other states, it is limited to only when a person is in his or her vehicle.\n\nNorth Carolina has a broad version of the castle doctrine. It states that a person who âunlawfully and forciblyâ enters oneâs home, workplace, or car is presumed to intend violence and to harm, and therefore it is easy to establish self-defense.\n\nIllinoisâs version of the castle doctrine has more restrictions. The castle doctrine for Illinois does not include oneâs workplace or vehicle. Additionally, one is only allowed to use deadly force if an intruder is committing a felony or enters the home in a âviolent, riotous or tumultuous manner.â\n\nThe following 23 states have a castle doctrine:\n\n- Arkansas\n- California\n- Colorado\n- Connecticut\n- Delaware\n- Hawaii\n- Illinois\n- Iowa\n- Maine\n- Maryland\n- Massachusetts\n- Minnesota\n- Nebraska\n- New Jersey\n- New Mexico\n- New York\n- North Dakota\n- Ohio\n- Oregon\n- Rhode Island\n- Virginia\n- Washington\n- Wisconsin\n\n\n\nThe following 26 states have passed a âStand Your Groundâ law:\n\n- Alabama\n- Alaska\n- Arizona\n- Florida\n- Georgia\n- Idaho\n- Indiana\n- Kansas\n- Kentucky\n- Louisiana\n- Michigan\n- Mississippi\n- Missouri\n- Montana\n- Nevada\n- New Hampshire\n- North Carolina\n- Oklahoma\n- Pennsylvania\n- South Carolina\n- South Dakota\n- Tennessee\n- Texas\n- Utah\n- West Virginia\n- Wyoming\n\n\n\nThe following have a âDuty to Retreatâ law:\n\n- Vermont\n- Washington D.C.\n","lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.152Z","path":"castle-doctrine-states","name":"Castle Doctrine States"},{"article":"CBD (cannabidiol) is a non-psychoactive compound found in cannabis. Unlike tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), CBD does not get a user âhigh;â however, its legality is still a gray area for some people because it is derived from the cannabis plant.\n\n## Is CBD Legal in the US?\nCBD must be legal on both the federal level and the state level in order for it to be legal in your state.\n\nThe 2018 Farm Bill legalized, on the federal level, the regulated production of hemp, or any part of the cannabis plant with a THC concentration below .3%. States, however, have the final say in whether or not cannabis-derived products are legal within their state lines.\n\n## Is CBD Legal in my State?\nThere are four different types of states when it comes to CBD and marijuana legality: Green, Amber, Amber-Red, and Red.\n\nThere are several states called Green States that have legalized both medicinal and recreational use of marijuana as long as you meet the minimum age requirement. The following are Green States:\n\nâ¢\tAlaska\nâ¢\tCalifornia\nâ¢\tColorado\nâ¢\tMaine\nâ¢\tMassachusetts\nâ¢\tMichigan\nâ¢\tNevada\nâ¢\tOregon\nâ¢\tVermont\nâ¢\tWashington\nâ¢\tWashington D.C.\n\nAmber States are those states that legalized marijuana and cannabis products (like CBD oil) for medical uses only, requiring you to obtain a medical marijuana card and a prescription from a medical marijuana doctor.\n\nAmber-Red States are those states that do not allow marijuana for any reason except for CBD products used for specific reasons unique to each state. Amber-Red states can be the trickiest. For example, in North Carolina, CBD oil is legal for severe epilepsy sufferers, and can only come from a hemp plant (not marijuana). In Alabama, under Leniâs Law, only those who have a medical condition that causes seizures or those who participate in a state-sponsored clinical trial studying the effects of CBD would have access to it. You should check with your stateâs specific conditions if you live in an Amber-Red state.\n\nFinally, Red States do not allow cannabis products in any form to be purchased or consumed for any reason. States"},{"article":"In the United States, there are a total of five time zones. This includes Hawaii-Aleutian Time Zone, which consists of the Hawaii and part of Alaska; the Alaska Time Zone, which includes only Alaska; the Pacific Time Zone, which includes states on the West Coast; Mountain Time Zone and Central Time Zone, which include the central states; and the Eastern Time Zone, which consists of the states along the East Coast. Today, weâre going to focus on the Central Time Zone.\n\nThere are a total of nine states that are located entirely within the Central Time Zone. Those states are:\n\n- Alabama\n- Arkansas\n- Illinois\n- Iowa\n- Louisiana\n- Minnesota\n- Mississippi\n- Missouri\n- Wisconsin\n\nOne thing to note about Alabama, however, is that Phenix City and Smiths Station observe Eastern Time unofficially since these are part of the Columbus, Georgia metro area.\n\nThere are a total of five states that observe Central Time in some cities and Eastern Time in others. Those states are:\n\n- Florida\n- Indiana\n- Kentucky\n- Michigan\n- Tennessee\n\nThere are an additional six states that observe Central Time. However, parts of each of these states also observe Mountain Time. Those states are:\n\n- Kansas\n- Nebraska\n- North Dakota\n- Oklahoma\n- South Dakota\n- Texas\n\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Arkansas","Illinois","Iowa","Louisiana","Minnesota","Mississippi","Missouri","Wisconsin"]},"sources":[{"name":"Central Time Zone in the United States","link":"https://www.timetemperature.com/tzus/central_time_zone.shtml"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.152Z","path":"central-time-zone-states","name":"Central Time Zone States"},{"article":"Whatâs the cheapest state to live in the United States?\n\nThe cost of living in the United States varies between states. The cost of living is the amount of money needed to sustain a certain standard of living. The cost of living includes housing, food, taxes, and healthcare. There is a strong correlation between a stateâs cost of living and per capita personal income.\n\nThe cost of living differs between states depending on how far the dollar goes in that state. This can be seen in housing costs especially. According to 24.7 Wall St., a dollar spent on rent in Arkansas is worth $1.58 in value, while a dollar spent on rent in Hawaii is worth $0.61.  \n\nMost of the states with the lowest cost of living are in the South, while those with the highest costs of living often have some of the nationâs largest urban clusters. Generally speaking, states that have a smaller portion of residents living in cities see the dollar go further.  \n\nThe cost of living index is based on the US average of 100. Any amount below 100 means that the cost is below the nationâs average, and any amount above 100 means that the cost is higher than the nationâs average. The lower the number, the further the dollar goes for that cost. \n\nThe cheapest state in the United States is Mississippi. Mississippiâs cost of living index is 86.1 and has the lowest overall housing cost index of all 50 states of 70.1. \n\n#### 1. Mississippi\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 4th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 1st  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 10th  \n\nThe cheapest state to live in in the United States is Mississippi. Overall, Mississippiâs average cost of living is about 19% lower than the national average cost of living. Mississippiâs living wage is only $48,537 and has the cheapest personal necessities anywhere in the country. Housing costs about $795 a month, and childcare in Mississippi is the cheapest in the country, costing about $2,869 a year. Food, health care, and many other necessities are among the least expensive in the nation as well.\n\n#### 2. Arkansas \n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 6th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 9th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 14th  \n\nArkansas has the lowest housing costs in America with the average residents on spending about $708 a month on rent or mortgages, which is half of what many people pay, and the median home cost is $128,800. The second-cheapest cost of living in America, however, comes with the second-lowest salaries in America. Arkansasâs living wage is $49,970. Transportation, utilities, food, and other expenses are also significantly lower in Arkansas.\n\n#### 3. Oklahoma\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 12th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 4th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 20th  \n\nOklahoma has the third-lowest cost of living in America. Like Mississippi and Arkansas, housing is one of the lowest in the country with the average home price at $124,800, an index of 54, and rent for a two-bedroom apartment average $740. Oklahoma also has some of the lowest gas prices in the U.S., and even utilities and grocery costs are below average with indexes of 94.9 and 96.5. Oklahoma City has an overall cost of living 15.4% below the national average. \n\n#### 4. Missouri\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 16th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 2nd  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 30th  \n\nThe fourth-least expensive state in America is Missouri. Joplin, Missouri has the lowest real estate prices in the country, where a four-bedroom home can cost just a little over $200,000. Groceries prices in Missouri are notably lower than in other parts of the country, with a dozen eggs costing only $1.32 in Joplin. Cities such as Springfield has an overall cost of living that is 14.1% lower than the national average, while Joplin is 17.7% below the national average. \n\n#### 5. New Mexico\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 27th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 13th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 4th  \n\nNew Mexico is the fifth-cheapest state in the U.S. Groceries are about the same as the national average; however, utilities and housing are significantly lower than the national average. The median home cost in New Mexico is $193,200 and the average rent for a two-bedroom home is $762 per month. The cost of living in the southern part of New Mexico is especially inexpensive, with transportation, utility, and health care being substantially less expensive than the rest of the state and country. \n\n\n#### 6. Tennessee\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 10th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 16th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 18th  \n\nTennessee is the sixth-cheapest state in America. The living wage in Tennessee is $50,152, the highest on the list so far, coupled with the highest housing costs so far of $810. Taxes in Tennessee are very low with no state income tax and food costs are very low too. Cities such as Morristown have an average cost of living that is 13% below the national average. Utilities in Tennessee are around or slightly above the national average monthly bill.\n\n#### 7. Michigan\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 2nd  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 10th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 25th  \n\nThe seventh-cheapest state in the U.S. is Michigan. Like Tennessee, Michigan has a relatively low food cost compared to other parts of the country; particularly with beef, where a pound costs only $3.78 per pound. Housing is also low in Michigan. Median rent for a two-bedroom apartment is $915 a month and the median home value is $161,063. The cost of living is even cheaper in Detroit, where the median home value is $48,188. \n\n#### 8. Kansas\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 5th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 8th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 35th  \n\nKansas is the eighth-cheapest state in America. The cost of living in Kansas is overall about 8.74% less than the rest of the country, and the average household income is about $41,644. A two-bedroom apartment in Kansas costs around $821 a month and the median home value is about $137,700. Groceries cost less in Kansas too, with a half-gallon of milk costing only $1.39 and a pound of ground beef costing $3.79. \n\n#### 9. Georgia\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 19th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 7th  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 17th  \n\nGeorgia is the ninth-cheapest state in the United States, despite the average utility bill being within the top ten most expensive in the country. Georgiaâs median household income is $56,183. The median home value is $180,679 and the median rent prices are cheaper than the rest of the country except for Atlanta, where rent for both one- and two-bedroom apartments are slightly above the national median. Groceries and gas prices are both below the national median as well. \n\n#### 10. Alabama\n\n\u003e **Grocery Cost Rank**: 20th  \n\u003e **Housing Cost Rank**: 3rd  \n\u003e **Utilities Cost Rank**: 36th  \n\nRounding out the ten cheapest states in America is Alabama. Alabama has relatively high taxes and above-average health care costs (cost index of 102.2, however, it makes up for it in housing. The median rent for a two-bedroom apartment in Alabama is $698 and the median home value is $129,300. A living wage in Alabama is $50,585, lower than some of the other states that ranked above it.  \n\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Cost Care Ratio By State"},{"article":"Disciplining children is undoubtedly one of the most controversial subjects among parents. It could become confusing in determining what is considered discipline and what is considered abuse. Therefore, parents could grow weary of what form of punishment to use. To understand more about the topic, here are the laws surrounding child discipline.\n\n## Discipline or Abuse?\nCurrently, all states allow some form of punishment that isn't too harsh for children. However, that's another issue that arises: What is considered too harsh or intense? Thanks to the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (CAPTA), these guidelines all depend on the state that people reside. \n\nSpankings are one form of punishment that is considered exceptional among states. This is because they are unable to cause any bruises that will impact the child in a significant way. These are the only guidelines that are followed throughout the country.\n\nThere are other states, however, that have special laws about discipline, which range from lenient to strict:\n\n- Lenient: Parents can spank their children if there will be no physical harm to the child(ren). \n- Strict: Parents can only gently spank their child(ren) and cannot strike, kick, burn, cut, or shake them. \n\n## Other Individuals\nIn addition to having laws about disciplining children, some laws cover other people disciplining children. These laws specifically include individuals like teachers and strangers. \n\nAs it pertains to teachers, 19 states allow teachers to initiate corporal punishment on students when necessary to correct their behavior. Punishments can include mostly spankings and paddling.\n\nStrangers disciplining other people's children, on the other hand, isn't explicitly mentioned in any state. Therefore, it would be up to the parent to decide whether they want another person to discipline their child for them. These other individuals include people like a parent of their child's friend and others.\n\n## Consequences\nFor states that don't allow any form of corporal punishment, there are significant consequences for the parents to deal with if they break the law. The more extreme the kind of punishment, the more likely the charges brought against a parent will be severe.\n\nMany states will charge parents with assault or even child abuse if they have caused physical marks on their bodies. There have been many instances where this was the case. One case, for example, is that of Vikings running back Adrian Peterson, who was arrested in 2014 for punishing his son with a switch and causing bruises on his back.\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-laws-by-state","blue-laws-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","clothing-laws-by-state","common-law-marriage-states","filial-responsibility-laws-by-state","final-paycheck-laws-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","helmet-law-states","homeschool-laws-by-state","incest-laws-by-state","late-fee-laws-by-state","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","marijuana-laws-by-state","mushroom-laws-by-state","pepper-spray-laws-by-state","seat-belt-laws-by-state","states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","tiny-house-laws-by-state","voter-id-laws-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-20T13:36:55.342Z","path":"child-discipline-laws-by-state","name":"Child Discipline Laws By State"},{"article":"","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["child-care-costs-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","child-support-percentage-by-state","529-plans-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.152Z","path":"child-support-percentage-by-state","name":"Child Support Percentage By State"},{"article":"Cigarette prices per state vary between $5.25 and $12.85 per pack. With 20 cigarettes per pack, this ranges between $.26 and $.64 per cigarette.\n\nOnly two states are outliers, with cigarette prices above $10 per pack. Illinois charges $11.50 per pack, and New York charges $12.85 per pack. While both of these states have large populations, there is no correlation between state population and how much they charge for a pack of cigarettes.\n\nThe average cost for a pack of cigarettes is across all states is $6.96 per pack or an average of $.35 per cigarette. 17 states have cigarette prices that fall above this average, and 23 states have prices that fall below this average. This means that states tend to have lower cigarette prices than higher.\n\nAccording to the [American Lung Association](https://www.lung.org/), the average smoker has 15 cigarettes a day. On average, this costs them $5.25 a day, or $1,916.25 per year. In New York, the average smoker would spend $9.60 per day, or $3,504 every year. In the states that charge only $5.25 per pack (Missouri and Virginia), the average smoker would spend $3.90 a day, or $1,423.50 per year.*\n\nGeographically, high cigarette prices tend to be concentrated in New York and the states north of it, which comprise the âNew Englandâ area, as well as the upper Midwest states of Illinois, Wisconsin, and Minnesota. Washington, Alaska, and Hawaii also have higher than average prices but are not concentrated in a geographic area.\n\nThe lowest prices are generally concentrated in the eastern states. The six lowest-priced states are Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina, Kentucky, Tennessee, and Missouri. Louisiana and Alabama are also among the lowest prices for cigarettes. \n\nThe north Rocky Mountain States, including Idaho, Wyoming, and North Dakota also have low prices and are geographically concentrated. In general, northern states are more likely to have higher cigarette prices than southern states.\n\nCigarettes are taxed on both the federal and state levels and are subject to both state and local sales tax as well. The federal tax rate on cigarettes is $1.0066 per 20-pack of cigarettes. The average cigarette tax among states is $1.73 per 20-pack of cigarettes. Cigarette taxes range from $0.17 per pack in Missouri to $4.35 per pack in New York. Every state also has some kind of tax on non-cigarette tobacco products as well.\n\nThe federal tax rate on cigarettes has remained at $1.01 since 2009 and many people support an increase in the tax rate. One of the main reasons for the support of increased cigarette taxes is that the increase in taxes leads to a decrease in smoking rates. This is especially prevalent among teenagers. Additionally, every state that has increased its cigarette tax has enjoyed substantial increases in revenue. Lastly, national and state polls have consistently found that people are in support of tax increases for tobacco and prefer tax increases on tobacco products rather than cutting programs such as education.
