States"},{"article":"Human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, is a virus that weakens a personâs immune system by attacking cells that fight off infection, specifically a personâs CD4 cells. HIV is spread through body fluids such as blood. If HIV goes untreated and advances, it can lead to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome or AIDS.\r\n\r\nUnlike most other viruses, when a person contracts HIV, they have it for life because the human body cannot fight off the virus entirely. HIV, however, can be controlled and its progression can be slowed significantly. There are three stages of HIV:\r\n\r\n1. Acute HIV infection\r\n2. Clinical latency (HIV inactivity or dormancy)\r\n3. AIDS\r\n\r\n## HIV Around the World\r\nAccording to the [World Health Organization](https://www.who.int/hiv/data/en/), there are about 37.9 million people in the world living with HIV in 2018. The prevalence of HIV in adults ages 15 to 29 is estimated at about 0.8% of the worldâs population. \r\n\r\nHIV is believed to have come from a type of chimpanzee in Central Africa, where the chimpanzee version of the virus, simian immunodeficiency virus or SIV, was transmitted to humans when they hunted the animal and came into contact with the blood. Once the virus was transmitted to humans, it mutated into HIV. It is believed that HIV was first transmitted in the 1800s and spread slowly across Africa and later into the rest of the world, reaching the United States around the mid to late 1970s. Unfortunately, because it is the origin of HIV, Africa has the highest prevalence of the virus at an estimated 3.9%. \r\n\r\n## HIV Treatment\r\nAlthough HIV cannot be cured, it can be controlled and treated through viral load suppression, also known as antiretroviral therapy (ART). ART reduces the viral load (amount of the virus) in the bodyâs blood and fluids. ART can not only slow the progression of HIV but also reduces the chances of transmitting the virus to other people. \r\n\r\nART is recommended for all people diagnosed with HIV and should be started as soon as possible after diagnosis. \r\n\r\nOf the 37.9 million people living with HIV around the world, 23.3 million are receiving ART, which means about 62% of those diagnosed with HIV are controlling their virus. While accessibility to testing and treatment has significantly improved around the world, poverty, gender equality, and HIV stigma and discrimination are major barriers to HIV prevention and treatment in many countries. \r\n\r\n[UNAIDS](https://www.unaids.org/en), the Joint United Nations Program on HIV/AIDS, is the worldâs leading advocate for the comprehensive and coordinated global action against the HIV/AIDS pandemic. In 2014, UNAIDS established the [90-90-90 goals](https://www.unaids.org/sites/default/files/media_asset/90-90-90_en.pdf), which called for countries around the world to get 90% of people living with HIV diagnosed; 90% of those diagnosed accessing treatment, and 90% of people on treatment to have suppressed viral loads by 2020. \r\n\r\n## HIV in the United States\r\nBased on the most recent information from the [Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)](https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/statistics/overview/ataglance.html), about 1.14 million Americans had HIV at the end of 2016. About 1 in 7 of those with the virus are unaware that they have it. \r\n\r\nIn 2018, 37,832 people received an HIV diagnosis, [according to the CDC]( https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/statistics/overview/ataglance.html). Among those, 42% were black or African American, 27% were Hispanic or Latino, and 25% were white. Also among the new diagnoses, 69% were among gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (sometimes referred to as MSM); 24% were among heterosexuals, and 7% were among people who inject drugs. \r\n\r\nIn the United States, there are five categories of laws pertaining to HIV and other STDs. As of 2018, 26 states have HIV-specific laws that criminalize behaviors that can potentially expose another person to HIV. \r\n\r\n#### States with the Highest Rates of HIV\r\nThese numbers are based on the CDCâs [HIV Surveillance Report](https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/pdf/library/reports/surveillance/cdc-hiv-surveillance-report-2018-vol-30.pdf).\r\n\r\nCalifornia has the highest number of people living with HIV of 128,153, a rate of 389.7 people with HIV per 100,000 residents. Of those living with HIV in California, the largest group is White with 48,155 people and the second-largest is Hispanic/Latino with 48,029. \r\n\r\nNew York has the second-highest number of people living with HIV of 126,495, a rate of 760.2 per 100,000. This rate is more than double that of Californiaâs. The largest group living with HIV in New York is Black/African American with 47,164 people living with the virus. \r\n\r\nFlorida has 110,034 people living with HIV, the third-highest number in the United States. Floridaâs HIV rate is 612.3 per 100,000. The group with the highest number of people living with HIV is Black/African American with 49,943. \r\n\r\nTexas has the fourth-highest number of people living with HIV in the United States of 88,099, translating to a rate of 382.9 per 100,000 people. The largest group living with the virus is Black/African American with 31,915 people, followed by Hispanic/Latino with 29,758. \r\n\r\nGeorgia has 52,528 people living with HIV, a rate of 608.8 per 100,000. This is the fifth-highest in the country. A majority of those infected with the virus are Black/African American, totaling 35,974. \r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["hospital-rankings-by-state","medicaid-enrollment-by-state","medicaid-income-limits-by-state","states-that-expanded-medicaid","abortion-laws-by-state","abortion-rates-by-state","hiv-statistics-by-state","maternal-mortality-rate-by-state","infant-mortality-rate-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.160Z","path":"hiv-statistics-by-state","name":"Hiv Statistics By State"},{"article":"In the United States, there are over half a million people experiencing homelessness. These individuals live in a temporary shelter or transitional housing or sleep in a place not meant for habitation (like an abandoned building). \r\n \r\nOverall, 66.7 percent of the total homeless population of the United States is single individuals, with the remaining 33.3 percent being families. \r\nIn recent years, homelessness increased nationally by almost one percent. This number is comprised of unaccompanied children and young adults, single adults experiencing chronic homelessness, and people experiencing unsheltered homelessness. \r\n\r\nSome populations have seen a decrease in homelessness. Dramatic reductions are amongst families and the veteran community.\r\n\r\nThe state of California currently has the highest homeless population, with almost 25 percent of the total population experiencing some form of homelessness. This figure is attributed to issues with providing affordable and adequate housing opportunities, current drug laws, and the inaccessibility of important mental health resources. \r\n\r\nAnother alarming statistic comes from New York City. In recent years, homelessness in this city reached the highest levels since the Great Depression in the 1930s, reaching its highest point under Mayor Bill de Blasio. This year, however, saw the second year in the decline of the homeless or unsheltered population, attributed to the creation of safe havens, or specialized shelters, that have a streamlined process of getting people into permanent housing. \r\n\r\nThe state with the lowest percentage of homeless population is experiencing an increase as well. Due to an oil and gas boom, North Dakota now has the fastest-growing economy. With this comes a rush of people coming to the state for work, but surging housing prices has made it difficult to find a home. \r\n\r\nFor a state-by-state look at homeless statistics, take a look at the table below. Data from this table was retrieved from the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness.\r\n","sources":[{"name":"Homelessness Statistics by State","link":"https://www.usich.gov/tools-for-action/map/#fn[]=1400\u0026fn[]=2900\u0026fn[]=6000\u0026fn[]=9900\u0026fn[]=13500"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.160Z","path":"homeless-population-by-state","name":"Homeless Population By State"},{"article":"Homeschooling is the education of children at home or another place that is not a school. Homeschooling is typically conducted by a parent, tutor or online teacher. \n\nHomeschooling and education by family members at home was a common practice for many years and in many cultures in the past. It declined in the 19th and 20th centuries as mandatory attendance laws began for schools. In the 1960s and 1970s, homeschooling became popular again as some people became dissatisfied with industrialized education.\n\nHomeschooling is legal in all 50 states, and every state has the freedom to create its own regulations for home education. \n\nBelow is a list of all 50 states and their homeschooling laws. Included in this data are how to enroll your child in homeschooling, instructor qualifications, required days of instruction, required subjects to be taught, homeschool records, and testing.\n\n## Alabama\n- In Alabama, the Homeschool Law requires you to send an enrollment form to your local education authority containing the names of all of the children you will be homeschooling and their address by the fifth day of the public school year, or before you withdraw your child to begin homeschooling.\n- If your child already attends an Alabama public school, you must first send in an enrollment form to notify the school that you will be homeschooling, and then send an official withdrawal letter.\n- The instructor does not need to meet specific qualifications.\n- You must teach the same number of days as a public school: 180 days per year.\n- There are no specific educational subjects that you are required to teach.\n- You must keep a record of your childâs attendance throughout the year.\n- There is no requirement for homeschool students to participate in testing.\n\n## Alaska\n- In Alaska, the Homeschool Law does not require you to notify the school district that you are homeschooling.\n- If your child already attends an Alaska public school, you will need to send a withdrawal form to the school district. \n- The instructor does not need to meet specific qualifications.\n- There is no required number of hours per day or days per year for homeschooling.\n- There are no specific educational subjects that you must teach.\n- You are not required to keep records of your homeschooling.\n- Independent homeschoolers are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Arizona\n- In Arizona, you must file an affidavit of intent with your county school superintendent within 30 days from the time you begin to homeschool. The affidavit must be notarized. Most counties will also need a copy of the childâs birth certificate.\n- If your child is already enrolled in a public school, you will need to send an affidavit of intent and then fill out and send a withdrawal letter to the school.\n- If you move counties, you must send an affidavit of intent for your new county and notify your previous county that you are no longer homeschooling there.\n- The instructor does not need to meet specific qualifications.\n- There is no required number of hours per day or days per year for homeschooling.\n- Arizona requires that you teach five educational subjects: reading, grammar, mathematics, social studies, and science.\n\n## Arkansas\n- In Arkansas, you must file a Notice of Intent with the superintendent of your local school district before August 15th of every school year that you homeschool.\n- If your child is already enrolled in a public school, you will need to send a Notice of Intent and then send an official letter of withdrawal to the school.\n- The instructor does not need to meet specific qualifications to homeschool; however, you will not be allowed to homeschool if a sex offender lives in your home.\n- There is no required number of hours per day or days per year for homeschooling.\n- There are no specific educational subjects that you are required to teach.\n- You are not required to keep records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## California\n- California has four legal homeschooling options: home-based private school, a private school independent study program, hiring a private tutor or teacher, a public school independent study program.\n- You will first need to decide which type of homeschool option you wish to enroll your child in. Each has a separate procedure to notify the Superintendent of Public Instruction that you will be homeschooling your child. You will then need to submit a withdrawal letter with a specific date that you will be withdrawing your child either by mail or in person.\n- There are specific qualifications for each homeschool education option in California depending on which option you choose.\n- The hours required per day and days required per year depend on the homeschool option you choose.\n- All four homeschool options require seven educational subjects to be taught: English, mathematics, social studies, science, visual and performing arts, health and physical education.\n- Required records and testing regulations depend on which homeschool option you choose for your child. \n\n## Colorado\n- Coloradoâs Homeschool Law requires that you send a Letter of Intent 14 days before beginning homeschooling every year to notify the school district that you will be homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you must send a Letter of Intent 14 days before homeschooling. Some schools have an official withdrawal form.\n- You must be a parent, legal guardian or an adult relative designated by the parent to homeschool a child\n- Colorado Homeschool Law requires that you teach a minimum of 172 days out of the year and an average of 4 hours per day.\n- Colorado requires you to teach your child seven educational subjects: communication skills (reading, writing and speaking), mathematics, history, civics, literature, science, and the United States Constitution\n- You must keep records for each child that you homeschool of attendance, test and evaluation results, and immunization records.\n- Homeschool students in Colorado are required to participate in testing during grades 3,5,7,9, and 11. Your child can either take a national standardized test or be evaluated by a qualified person. The results must be sent to your school district and 13% or higher must be achieved (or be making satisfactory academic progress) to continue homeschooling.\n\n## Connecticut\n- The Connecticut Homeschool Law does not require you to notify the school district that you are homeschooling your child. You should fill out a Notice of Intent form within 10 days of beginning to homeschool every year.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you need to send in a withdrawal letter before removing him/her.\n- There are no required qualifications for the instructor.\n- There are no required hours per day or days per year for homeschooling; however, you are asked in your Notice of Intent how many days in the year you will be teaching. An average public school year in Connecticut is 180 days.\n- There are seven required education subjects: reading, writing, spelling, English grammar, geography, arithmetic, and US history and citizenship.\n- There are no required records to be kept for homeschooled students; however, you should keep a portfolio of your childâs education.\n- Homeschooled students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n\n## Delaware\n- The Delaware Homeschool Law requires you to officially open a non-public school through the Department of Education. This is where you will report the enrollment of your student(s) and their attendance information.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you will need to first open a non-public school with the Department of Education and then, once accepted, you will receive an acknowledgment page, which you will bring to the school to withdraw your child.\n- There are no required qualifications for homeschool instructors. \n- There are no required hours per day or days per year that a homeschool student needs to attend.\n- You must keep a record of your childâs attendance throughout the year.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n\n## District of Columbia\n- In Washington DC, you must fill out a Notice of Intent every year you are homeschooling by August 15th (15 days before homeschooling at any time of the year if it is your first year).\n- If you need to withdraw your child, submit a Notification of Intent and then contact the school for any forms needed to officially withdraw.\n- Homeschool instructors must have at least a high school diploma or equivalent.\n- There are no required hours per day or days per year that a homeschool child must receive instruction, but you must provide enough for him/her to academically progress.\n- There are eight required educational subjects: language arts, mathematics, science, social studies, art, music, health, and physical education\n- You are required to keep a portfolio of your childâs work that contains at least a yearâs worth of the following materials: writing samples, worksheets, workbooks, creative materials, assessment reports.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in yearly testing. Homeschool students can take the standardized tests in the local school.\n\n## Florida\n- In Florida, you must file a notice of intent form with your school district superintendent of the county within 30 days of starting homeschooling. This only needs to be filed one time, and for any child who is 6 years old or older before February 1st.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, submit your Notice of Intent first and then notify your childâs school that you will be withdrawing your child.\n- There are no requirements for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no specific hours per day or days per year that your child needs to be homeschooled.\n- There is no list of required education subjects for homeschooled students.\n- Florida Homeschool Law requires you to maintain a portfolio of records and materials for your child for the superintendent.\n- Homeschool students must be evaluated annually, which can be done in a variety of ways. The results of this evaluation must be documented and an evaluation letter must be sent to your countyâs superintendent. \n\n## Georgia\n- Georgia homeschool law requires you to file a Declaration of Intent with the Department of Education within 30 days of beginning to homeschool and must be filed every year following before September 1st.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, submit your Declaration of Intent and then notify the school of withdrawal.\n- Homeschool instructors must have at least a high school diploma or GED and you may only teach your own children.\n- Homeschool students must be taught a minimum of 180 days that consist of 4.5 hours of schooling. \n- There are five required education subjects for homeschooled students: reading, language arts, mathematics, social studies, and science.\n- You must make an annual progress assessment report and keep a copy of your Declaration of Intent and your childâs test scores for your homeschool records.\n- Homeschooled students in Georgia must take a national standardized test in grades 3, 6 and 9.\n\n## Hawaii\n- Hawaii Homeschool Law requires you to file a Notice of Intent with your public school principle before homeschooling. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, first send your Notice of Intent form and then contact the school to see how you need to withdraw your child.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no required hours per day or days per week for teaching homeschooled students, but you need to keep track of the hours/week that your child is taught.\n- There are eight required subjects for elementary level students: language arts, mathematics, social studies, science, art, music, health, and physical education. There are seven for secondary level students: social studies, English, mathematics, science, health, physical education, guidance.\n- Hawaii requires that you keep a record of the curriculum plan for each homeschool student, as well as a copy of the Notice of Intent, your childâs test scores and samples of the childâs work.\n- Hawaii homeschool students must follow the statewide testing program, requiring each student to test in grades 3, 5, 8, and 10.\n\n## Idaho\n- Idaho does not require you to notify your school district if you decide to homeschool. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, you should contact your school to notify them and ask if they have an official withdrawal form.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that a homeschool student must be taught.\n- There are seven required subjects for homeschool students: language arts and communication, mathematics, science, social studies, fine arts, health, and physical education.\n- Idaho does not require that you keep specific records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Illinois\n- Illinois Homeschool Law does not require you to notify your school district if you decide to homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you will need to send in a withdrawal letter, keep your child home on the day indicated in your letter, and send in a student records quest letter within 10 days of sending your withdrawal letter.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that a homeschool student must be taught.\n- There are six required educational subjects for homeschool students: language arts, mathematics, biological and physical sciences, social sciences, fine arts, physical development, and health.\n- Illinois does not require that you keep specific records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Indiana\n- Indiana Homeschool Law does not require you to notify your school district if you decide to homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child from school, fill out and send a withdrawal letter and keep your child home from school on the date indicated. If withdrawing from a high school the law requires that you meet with the school principal to discuss legal requirements and sign a form.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students must be taught for a minimum of 180 days per year.\n- Homeschool students must be taught âequivalent instructionâ to what is taught in public schools, but the parent is left to determine what âequivalent instructionâ is.\n- You are required to keep a record of attendance for each homeschooled child.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Iowa\n- Iowa Homeschool Law does not require you to notify your school district if you decide to homeschool your child.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you need to contact your school to inform them that you are withdrawing your child for homeschooling.\n- There are no specific required qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There is no minimum number of hours per day or days per year that your child must be taught.\n- There are five required educational subjects for homeschooled students: mathematics, reading, language arts, science, and social sciences.\n- Iowa does not require that you keep specific records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students in Iowa are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Kansas\n- Kansas Homeschool Law states that you must register your homeschool with the stateâs board of education.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you can do so by phone, in person or by letter to officially withdraw them.\n- You must be a âcompetent instructorâ to teach homeschool students, but there is no authority to determine who is âcompetentâ to teach, and there are no specific requirements for instructors in non-accredited schools.\n- Homeschool students must be instructed 186 days/year for 6 hours per day for first grade through 11th grade.\n- There are no required educational subjects for homeschool students.\n- Kansas does not require that you keep specific records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students in Kansas are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Kentucky\n- Kentucky Homeschool Law states that you must send a Letter of Intent to the district superintendent 10 days before school begins and send the letter each year that you intend to homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child from school, fill out and send a letter of withdrawal to officially withdraw him/her.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors in Kentucky.\n- Homeschool students must receive a minimum of 185 days of instruction per year.\n- There are eight required subjects for homeschool students, reading, writing, spelling, grammar, history, mathematics, science, and civics.\n- Kentucky requires that a record of attendance, courses, and grades are kept for each homeschool student, and suggests a portfolio of each childâs work.\n- Homeschool students in Kentucky are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Louisiana\n- Louisiana Homeschool Law states that you must submit a Home Study Application to the Department of Education within 15 days of beginning to homeschool. Every year, you must re-apply by October 1st or within 12 months of your first application.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, do so before starting homeschooling by filling out and send a withdrawal letter to the school.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students must receive a minimum of 180 days of instruction per year.\n- You must teach your homeschool student a âsustained curriculum of quality at least equal to that offered in public schools at the same grade levelâ (LA Rev Stat Â§ 17:236.1).\n- There are no required records to be kept for each homeschooled child; however, you have to option to submit a portfolio for each homeschool child with your re-application every year to show achievement and progress.\n- Louisiana requires each homeschooled student to participate in annual testing, such as a competency exam, a standardized test, or a statement from a certified teacher.\n\n## Maine\n- Maine Homeschool Law requires you to send a Notice of Intent to your school and commissioner with 10 days of the start of homeschooling. Every following year, you must submit another Notice of Intent by September 1st and submit an assessment of your childâs progress.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you must officially do so by sending a withdrawal letter to your school.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students must receive 175 days of instruction per year.\n- Maine requires you to teach 11 required subjects: English, language arts, math, science, social studies, physical education, health education, library skills, fine arts, Maine studies, and computer proficiency.\n- Maine requires that you keep copies of your original Notice of Intent and every year-end assessment for your child.\n- Maine requires each homeschool student to participate in yearly testing or assessment, which can be a standardized test, one developed for school officials, or a review done by a certified teacher.\n\n## Maryland\n- Maryland Homeschool Law requires you to submit a Homeschool Notification Form to your superintendent 15 days before beginning to homeschool. You must notify your school of your intent to continue homeschooling every year.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your school by letter, e-mail or in-person to officially withdraw your child.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors in Maryland.\n- Homeschool students must be taught a minimum of as many hours as needed for the students to meet the standard achievement level of their grade.\n- There are eight required subjects for homeschool students to be taught: English, mathematics, science, social studies, art, music, health, physical education.\n- Maryland requires that you keep a portfolio of each childâs relevant work.\n- At the end of each semester, you must meet with a representative of the school district to review each childâs portfolio. Homeschool students are also allowed (but not required) to participate in standardized testing with the local school.\n\n## Massachusetts\n- Massachusetts requires that you get approval from your local school district and may reject your request. You might need to provide your education plan, your qualifications to instruct, your education materials and information on your childâs academic process. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, you should send a withdrawal letter before starting homeschooling.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year required for homeschool instruction.\n- There are no required educational subjects for homeschool students, however, local school officials can ask to review your educational materials to determine what you should teach.\n- There are no required records to be kept for homeschool students; however, your school district might ask to see information about your childâs academic process.\n- Massachusetts does not require homeschool students to participate in testing, but your school district can require an assessment or evaluation such as a portfolio review or an assessment by a professional educator.\n\n## Michigan\n- Michigan Homeschool Law does not require you to notify your school district of your choice to homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you will need to send the school a withdrawal letter and officially withdraw your child.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year required for homeschooling.\n- There are eight required educational subjects for homeschool students: reading, spelling, mathematics, science, history, civics, literature, writing, and English grammar.\n- There are no required records to be kept for homeschool students.\n- Michigan does not require homeschool students to participate in testing.\n\n## Minnesota\n- Minnesota Homeschool Law requires you to report to your local superintendent once a year for every year that you homeschool. After your first year, you must send a Letter of Intent by October 1st every year to continue to homeschool.\n- You must officially withdraw your child from school.\n- Homeschool instructors have to meet one of the following requirements: be a parent of the child; have a valid Minnesota teaching license for the grade level to be taught; be supervised by a licensed teacher; complete a teacher competency exam; teach in an accredited school, or have a baccalaureate degree.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year required for homeschooling.\n- There are 13 educational subjects required for homeschool students: reading, writing, literature, fine arts, mathematics, science, history, geography, economics, government, citizenship, health, and physical education.\n- You must keep records of your childâs class schedules, copies of instruction materials, and descriptions of assessment methods.\n- Minnesota requires that each child is tested/assessed every year. You must report which test your child will take to the superintendent.\n\n## Mississippi\n- Mississippi Homeschool Law states that you must submit a certificate of enrollment for each child you homeschool by September 15th every year.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you can do so at any point in the school year and must send a withdrawal letter to the school and contact the countyâs attendance officer.\n- There are no qualifications for homeschool instructors except that you must be a parent, guardian or custodian of the child.\n- Homeschool students must be taught for a minimum of 180 days per year.\n- There are no required educational subjects for homeschool students.\n- Mississippi does not require you to keep any records of your childâs homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students in Mississippi are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Missouri\n- Missouri Homeschool Law does not require you to notify the school district that you are homeschooling your child.\n- If your child needs to withdraw fro school, send in a withdrawal letter to your local superintendent.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students must receive 1,000 hours of instruction per year, and at least 600 must be taught teaching the required subjects. 400 of those hours must be at the regular homeschool location.\n- There are five required educational subjects: reading, language arts, mathematics, social studies, and science.\n- Missouri requires that you keep a written record of the subjects you teach, a portfolio of each childâs work, and copies of academic evaluations for each child.\n- Missouri homeschool students are not required to participate in testing, but their academic progress does need to be evaluated.\n\n## Montana\n- Montana Homeschool Law requires you to notify your county superintendent each year that you homeschool. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your childâs school to see if they have a method for withdrawal.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students must be taught for a minimum of 360 hours for kindergarten, 720 hours for grade 1-3, and 1,080 hours for grades 4-12. \n- Homeschool students are required to learn the basic educational subjects taught in Montana public schools.\n- Montana requires that you keep records of your childâs attendance and immunizations.\n- Montana homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Nebraska\n- Nebraska Homeschool Law requires you to file for exempt status as a non-accredited school annually by July 15th before homeschooling. \n- You need to officially withdraw your child from school by having an exit interview with the superintendent, sign a notarized release form with the Commissioner of Education and file for exempt status.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students are required to be taught a minimum of 1032 hours per year for elementary students and 1080 hours for high school students.\n- There are five required educational subjects: language arts, mathematics, science, social studies, and health. \n- Nebraska does not require any records to be kept for homeschool students.\n- Nebraska homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Nevada\n- Nevada Homeschool Law requires you to file a Notice of Intent with the district superintendent to begin homeschooling. This only needs to be filed once unless your situation changes.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your school district and ask if they have a form for you to fill out.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors. You must be the legal parent or guardian of the child being homeschooled.\n- There is no required minimum of hours per day or days per year.\n- There are four required educational subjects: English, social studies, mathematics, and science.\n- Nevada does not require any records to be kept for homeschool students.\n- Nevada homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## New Hampshire\n- New Hampshire Homeschool Law requires you to notify your district superintendent of your homeschooling within 5 business days of starting. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your childâs school to notify them and ask if they have an official form for you to fill out.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors. You must be the legal parent or guardian of the child being homeschooled.\n- There is no required minimum of hours per day or days per year.\n- There are 11 required educational subjects: science, mathematics, language, government, history, health, reading writing, spelling, US and NH constitution and art and music appreciation.\n- Nevada requires you to keep a portfolio of writing samples, worksheets, workbooks and a reading log for each child. \n- Nevada requires each homeschool student to receive an evaluation every year such as a portfolio reviewed by a certified teacher, and National Student Achievement Test, a Student Assessment test or an approved alternative evaluation method.\n\n## New Jersey\n- New Jersey Homeschool Law does not require notification to your school district that you are homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, notify your childâs school and the district superintendent, and send a withdrawal letter.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no required educational subjects but you should offer equivalent instruction.\n- New Jersey does not require that you keep any specific records for your child.\n- New Jersey homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## New Mexico\n- New Mexico Homeschool Law requires you to notify the state through the New Mexico Public Education Departmentâs (electronically or by mail) within 30 days of beginning to homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your childâs school to notify them and ask if they have an official form for you to fill out.\n- You must be the legal parent or guardian of each child you homeschool and have a minimum high school diploma or GED.\n- Homeschool students must receive at least 180 days of instructions per year, or 990 hours/year for K-6 or 1,080 hours for 7-12 grade.\n- There are five required educational subjects: reading, language arts, mathematics, social studies, and science.\n- New Mexico requires that you keep records of your childâs immunization record, proof of your qualification, a calendar showing that you meet the minimum day/hour requirements. \nNew Mexico homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## New York\n- New York Homeschool Law requires that you send a Letter of Intent to your school district 14 days after beginning to homeschool. After the first year, this letter must be sent by July 1st. You then will receive, fill out and return an Individual Home Instruction Plan (IHIP) for each child.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your childâs school to notify them and ask if they have an official form for you to fill out.\n- You must be the legal parent or guardian of the child or children you are homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students must be taught for 180 days per year or 900 hours for grade 1-6 and 990 hours for grades 7-12.\n- There are four required education subjects for all grades (plus additional required subjects for elementary, middle school, and high school levels): patriotism and citizenship, health education, highway safety and traffic regulation, and fire and arson prevention safety.\n- New York requires that you keep a record of attendance as well as a copy of your letter of intent, IHIP, quarterly reports for each child, and a copy of your childâs yearly test scores or evaluations.\n- New York homeschool students are required to participate in testing every year. Each child must take an achievement test administered at your local public school or non-public school, or at home, by a professional. Children in grades 1-3 can receive an academic evaluation as an alternative.\n\n## North Carolina\n- North Carolina Homeschool Law requires that you send a Notice of Intent to the Department of Non-Public Education, sent after July 1st for the first year of homeschooling. This only needs to be sent in once, and you will need to include a copy of your high school diploma.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send a note with your Notice of Intent and copy of your diploma that says âPriority Handling Request: Child is currently in a year-round school.â Make sure your child attends school until the registration process is complete.\n- Homeschool instructors must have a minimum of a high school diploma or GED.\n- Homeschool students must attend at least 9 months of instruction.\n- There are no specific required educational subjects.\n- North Carolina requires you to keep a record of your childâs attendance, immunization records, and annual test scores.\n- North Carolina homeschool students are required to participate in a nationally standardized test of your choice every year. The test you choose must cover English, reading, spelling, and mathematics.\n\n## North Dakota\n- North Dakota Homeschool Law requires you to send a Statement of Intent to your local districtâs superintendent 14 days before homeschooling begins.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you should contact your childâs school to officially withdraw them before starting homeschooling. Ask if they have any specific forms for you to fill out.\n- Homeschool instructors must have a high school diploma or GED.\n- Homeschool students must be taught a minimum of 4 hours per day for 175 days per year.\n- Elementary and middle school level students must be taught six educational subjects: English, mathematics, social studies, science, physical education, and health.\n- High school level students must be taught 10 educational subjects: English, mathematics, science, social studies, health, physical education, fine arts, foreign language, career and technical education, and an advanced placement course.\n- You are required to keep yearly records of any courses your child takes, your childâs progress assessment, and your childâs test results.\n- North Dakota homeschool students are required to participate in testing in grades 4, 6, 8, and 10. You can use the test that your local school district uses or request a different national standardized test.\n\n## Ohio\n- Ohio Homeschool Law states you must send a Home Education Notification form to your superintendent every year of homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, contact your school and ask if they have any forms you need to fill out. This needs to be done before homeschooling your child.\n- Homeschool instructors must have a high school diploma, GED, or standardized test scores that show you have a high school equivalent education.\n- Homeschool students must receive 900 hours of education per year.\n- There are thirteen required educational subjects: language, reading, spelling, writing, geography, history, government, mathematics, science, health, physical education, fine arts, and first aid, safety, and fire prevention.\n- Ohio does not require that you keep any specific records for your child.\n- Ohio homeschool students are required to participate in yearly testing by taking a national standardized test or a written assessment by an authorized person.\n\n## Oklahoma\n- Oklahoma Homeschool Law does not require you to notify your school district that you are homeschooling. \n- It is not required that you give any notice or explanation before withdrawing your child, but you should notify the school before keeping your child home.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that homeschool students must attend, but 180 days per year is strongly recommended.\n- There are no required educational subjects, but you are encouraged to teach the same subject taught in public schools.\n- Oklahoma does not require that you keep any specific records for your child.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## Oregon\n- Oregon Homeschool Law requires you to notify your Education Service District (ESD) of your decision to homeschool within 10 days of starting.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send a withdrawal letter to your childâs school to officially withdraw them. \n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that homeschool students must attend. \n- There are no required educational subjects.\n- Oregon does not require that you keep any specific records for your homeschooling. \n- Homeschool students are required to participate in testing during grades 3, 5, 8, and 10.  The test must be given by an approved tester and done before August 15th.\n\n## Pennsylvania\n- Pennsylvania Homeschool Law requires you to send a notarized affidavit to your superintendent by August 1st every year before you begin homeschooling every year.\n- If you need to withdraw your child from school, you should fill out and send a withdrawal letter to official withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- Homeschool instructors are required to have a high school diploma or GED.\n- Homeschool students are required to attend a minimum of 180 days per year or 900 hours per year for grade K-6 or 990 hours per year for grades 7-12.\n- Grades K-6 have the following required educational subjects: English, arithmetic, science, geography, history, civics, safety, health and physiology, physical education music and art.\n- Grades 7-12 have the following required educational subjects: English, science, geography, social studies, mathematics, art, music, physical education, health, and safety education.\n- Pennsylvania requires that you keep a portfolio and a written academic evaluation for each child.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in testing during grades 3, 5, and 8. They must take a national standardized test.\n\n## Rhode Island\n- Rhode Island Homeschool Law requires you to send a Notice of Intent to Homeschool to your school and you must receive approval from a committee before homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child from school, you should fill out and send a withdrawal letter to official withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students are required to attend a minimum of 180 days per year of instruction.\n- There are eight required educational subjects: reading, writing, geography, arithmetic, history of the US and Rhode Island, civics, health, and physical education. \n- Rhode Island requires you to keep a record of your childâs attendance throughout the year.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in testing.\n\n## South Carolina\n- South Carolina Homeschool Law requires you to receive approval from your school districtâs Board of Trustees. You can find a homeschool application on your school districtâs website. \n- If your child needs to withdraw from school, you will need to register with the school district, and then fill out any paperwork that your school district may have to officially withdraw your child.\n- Homeschool instructors are required to have a high school diploma, GED, or baccalaureate degree.\n- Homeschool students are required to attend at least 4.5 hours per day and 180 days per year of instruction.\n- There are 5 required subjects for grades K-6: reading, writing, mathematics, science, and social studies. Grades 7-12 add composition and literature.\n- South Carolina requires you to keep records of the subjects you teach, a portfolio of your childâs work samples, and a record of evaluations.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in yearly testing and should take the state-approved testing for all public school students.\n\n## South Dakota\n- South Dakota Homeschool Law requires you to send an initial Notification for Public School Exemption Certificate to your school district and send an annual one every year.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, you will need to send your school district an Initial Notification for Public School Exemption Certificate and as your childâs school for any specific forms.\n- There are no specific qualifications for homeschool instructors.\n- Homeschool students are required to receive a minimum of 437 hours per year for kindergarten, 875 hours per year for grades 1-5, and 962 hours per year for grades 6-12.\n- There are two required educational subjects: languages arts and mathematics.\n- South Dakota requires you to keep a copy of your childâs birth certificate on record.\n- Homeschool students are required to take a national standardized achievement test in grades 4, 8, and 11. \n\n## Tennessee\n- Tennessee Homeschool Law requires you to send a Notice of Intent to Homeschool to your Director of Schools every year.\n- If your child needs to withdraw from school, send in your Notice of Intent and then contact your school to see if there are specific forms for you to complete to officially withdraw.\n- Homeschool instructors must have a high school diploma or GED.\n- Homeschool students must attend a minimum of 4 hours per day for 180/days per year of instruction.\n- There are no required educational subjects.\n- Tennessee requires you to keep a record of your childâs attendance each year to submit to the Director of Schools.\n- Homeschool students are required to take a standardized test in grades 5, 7, and 9. These test scores must be submitted to the Director of Schools.\n\n## Texas\n- Texas Homeschool Law does not require that you send a notice to your school that you are homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send a withdrawal letter and contact them to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- There are no specific qualifications for instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that your child must attend homeschooling.\n- There are five required educational subjects: Math, spelling, grammar, reading, and good citizenship.\n- Texas does not require you to keep records of your homeschooling, but it is encouraged.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n\n## Utah\n- Utah Homeschool Law requires you to submit a notarized affidavit to your school district. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the affidavit and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- There are no specific qualifications for instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that your child must attend homeschooling.\n- There are no specific required education subjects.\n- Utah does not require you to keep records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n\n## Vermont\n- Vermont Homeschool Law requires you to send a written enrollment notice every year to the Commissioner of Education that you are homeschooling.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the notice and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- There are no specific qualifications for instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that your child must attend homeschooling.\n- There are eleven required educational subjects: basic communication skills, reading, writing, use of numbers, US citizenship, history and government; physical education, health, literature, natural science, and fine arts.\n- Vermont does not require you to keep records of your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in testing every year through an educational evaluation, a written report and portfolio, or a standardized achievement test.\n\n## Virginia\n- Virginia Homeschool Law requires you to send a Notice of Intent to your superintendent but August 15th every year. You must include the subjects that your child that year and a copy of your qualification.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the notice and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- Homeschool instructors must meet one of the four following requirements: have a high school diploma or higher, have a Virginia teaching certificate, enroll your child in a distance learning program, or show evidence that you can provide sufficient education for your child.\n- Homeschool students are required to attend 180 days per year of instruction.\n- There are no specific required educational subjects.\n- Virginia does not require that you keep a record of your childâs homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in yearly testing via a standardized test, educational evaluation or assessment, or a report card from a distance learning program. Results must be sent to your superintendent by August 1st.\n\n## Washington\n- Washington Homeschool Law requires you to send a Declaration of Intent to your superintendent before September 15th every year that you homeschool.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the declaration and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- Homeschool instructors must meet one of the four following qualifications: 30 college semester credit hours, completion of a parent qualifying course in-home instruction, allow a certified person to oversee your homeschooling or approval from the superintendent of your school district.\n- Homeschool students must attend 180 days per year of instruction.\n- There are eleven required educational subjects: reading, writing, spelling, language, math, science, social studies, history, health, occupational education, and art and music appreciation. \n- Washington requires that you keep records of annual tests or assessments, immunizations and other records relating to your childâs homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are required to participate in yearly testing either by taking a standardized achievement test or by being evaluated by a certified person.\n\n## West Virginia\n- West Virginia Homeschool Law requires you to send a Notice of Intent to your superintendent.\n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the notice and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- Home school instructors must have a high school diploma or GED.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year that your child must attend homeschooling.\n- There are five required educational subjects: reading, language, mathematics, science, and social studies.\n- West Virginia requires you to keep a record of your childâs yearly educational assessment for up to three years. \n- Homeschool students are required to participate in yearly educational assessments and can choose one of the following: a national standardized test, a public school testing program, a portfolio evaluation, or an alternative academic assessment. Results must be sent to your county superintendent at the end of grades 3, 5, 8 and 11.\n\n## Wisconsin\n- Wisconsin Homeschool Law requires you to submit an affidavit with the Department of Public Instruction every year before October 15th. \n- If you need to withdraw your child, send the affidavit and contact your childâs school to officially withdraw your child before homeschooling.\n- There are no specific requirements for instructors.\n- Homeschool students must attend 875 hours per year of instruction.\n- There are six required educational subjects: reading, language arts, mathematics, social studies, science, and health.\n- Wisconsin does not require that you keep any specific records for your homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n\n## Wyoming\n- Wyoming Homeschool Law requires that you submit a list of your curriculum to your schoolâs board of trustees at the beginning of every school year.\n- If your child needs to withdraw, first submit your curriculum and then send a withdrawal letter to your school to officially withdraw.\n- There are no specific qualifications for instructors.\n- There are no minimum hours per day or days per year of instruction.\n- There are seven required educational subjects: reading, writing, mathematics, civics, history, literature, and science. \n- Wyoming does not require you to keep specific records for your childâs homeschooling.\n- Homeschool students are not required to participate in yearly testing.\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-laws-by-state","blue-laws-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","clothing-laws-by-state","common-law-marriage-states","filial-responsibility-laws-by-state","final-paycheck-laws-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","helmet-law-states","homeschool-laws-by-state","incest-laws-by-state","late-fee-laws-by-state","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","marijuana-laws-by-state","mushroom-laws-by-state","pepper-spray-laws-by-state","seat-belt-laws-by-state","states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","tiny-house-laws-by-state","voter-id-laws-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Homeschool Laws in Your State","link":"https://hslda.org/content/laws/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.160Z","path":"homeschool-laws-by-state","name":"Homeschool Laws By State"},{"article":"A homestead exemption is a legal provision that helps shield a home from some creditors following the death of a homeowner spouse or the declaration of bankruptcy. A homestead exemption can block the forced sale of a primary residence and provide tax relief for surviving spouses. Homestead exemptions are only for one primary residence and no other exemption can be claimed on any other property anywhere. \r\n\r\nHomestead exemption is a great option for those facing financial hardship, such as people filing for bankruptcy or widow or widower facing higher bills than he or she can no longer afford to pay due to the passing of a spouse. \r\n\r\nHomestead exemptions can protect a home up to a certain value of the homeownerâs equity in it. If the homesteadâs equity exceeds the limit of the exemption in that state, creditors may force the debtors to sell. In this case, the debtors would receive the monetary amount of the bankruptcy exemption. \r\n\r\nTax reductions under homestead exemptions are usually a fixed discount on taxes. For example, a home valued at $150,000 using a $50,000 homestead exemption will be taxed on $100,000 of assessed value.\r\n\r\nHomestead exemptions vary by state, including how it is applied and how much protection it offers against creditors. The exemption is an automatic benefit in some states and a claim must be filed in others. New Jersey and Pennsylvania have no homestead exemptions.\r\n\r\nThe current federal bankruptcy exemption amount as of 2019 is $25,510. While most states require homeowners to use the stateâs limit, some will allow the homeowner to use either the federal or the state.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table with each stateâs homestead exemption amounts.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Homestead Exemption There are 48 contiguous states plus Alaska located in the far northwestern part of North America and Hawaii located in the mid-Pacific. The United States also has five major territories and various islands. \n\nThe United States of America â also known as the USA or the US â is a nation located on the continent of North America. Mexico borders it to the south and Canada to the north.\n\nUnsurprisingly, the thirteen colonies were the first thirteen states to be ratified. The first states to be ratified were Delaware, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania in 1787. Georgia, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maryland, South Carolina, New Hampshire, Virginia and New York were ratified in 1788, followed by North Carolina in 1789 and Rhode Island in 1790. Alaska and Hawaii, the only states that are not part of the mainland United States, were the last states to be admitted in 1959. \n\nAlaska is the largest state in the United States, spanning over 663,300 square miles. On the opposite end, Rhode Island is the smallest state with an area of just 1,212 square miles. California is the most populous state with over 39 million residents and Wyoming is least population with only 577,000 residents. \n\n\nThere are four statistical regions of the United States as defined by the US Census Bureau. Each area contains multiple states. The first region is the Northeast. The states in this region include:\n\n- Connecticut\n- Maine\n- Massachusetts\n- New Hampshire\n- New Jersey\n- New York\n- Pennsylvania\n- Rhode Island\n- Vermont\n\nRegion 2 is the Midwest. The states in this region include:\n\n- Illinois\n- Indiana\n- Iowa\n- Kansas\n- Michigan\n- Minnesota\n- Missouri\n- Nebraska\n- North Dakota\n- Ohio\n- South Dakota\n- Wisconsin\n\nRegion 3 is the South. The southern states are:\n\n- Alabama\n- Arkansas\n- Delaware\n- Florida\n- Georgia\n- Kentucky\n- Louisiana\n- Maryland\n- Mississippi\n- North Carolina\n- Oklahoma\n- South Carolina\n- Tennessee\n- Texas\n- Virginia\n- Washington D.C.\n- West Virginia\n\nRegion 4 â the final region â is the West. The western states include:\n\n- Alaska\n- Arizona\n- California\n- Colorado\n- Hawaii\n- Idaho\n- Montana\n- Nevada\n- New Mexico\n- Oregon\n- Utah\n- Washington\n- Wyoming\n","frontmatter":{"title":"How Many States are in the United Many States"},{"article":"How many states did Trump win? \r\n\r\nDonald Trump was elected President of the United States in November 2016. Trump won the electoral vote against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton 304-227. Donald Trump won the vote of 30 states while Hillary Clinton won 20. \r\n\r\nWhile some historically Democratic states like California and New York stayed democratic in 2016, Trump won some crucial states that had previously voted for President Obama in 2012 such as Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin. \r\n\r\nPVI is the [Cook Partisan Voting Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cook_Partisan_Voting_Index)\r\n is the measurement of how strongly a Unite States congressional district or state leans toward the Democratic or Republican Party compared to the nation as a whole. For example, if the national average is 49% Republican, and the Republican candidate of a state wins 58% of the two-party share, then that state voted 9 percentage points more Republican than the country, or R+9.\r\n\r\nThe states with the highest PVI that voted more Republican than the national average are Wyoming (R+25), Utah (R+20), and Oklahoma (R+20). The PVI of all 50 states in the 2016 election was R+3.48. Wyoming is the most conservative state in the US, having voted a Republican Party candidate for every presidential election since the 1950s (except for the 1964 election).\r\n\r\nWisconsin, Pennsylvania, and New Hampshire were all even between Republican and Democrat in the 2016 election. Trump ended up winning Wisconsin and Pennsylvania. \r\n\r\nThe map and table show which states voted for Trump, which states voted for Hillary, and which were split even. In general, the northeast and west coast voted Democratic, and the Great Plains states and south voted Republican.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"totalRow":{"columns":{"pvi":{"type":"avg"},"governorParty":false,"senateParty":false}},"columns":["state",{"header":"PVI","field":"pvi","format":"pvir"},{"header":"Governor many states did Trump win? A state-by-state look back at the 2016 presidential election","link":"https://www.aol.com/article/news/2017/07/05/how-many-states-did-trump-win-state-by-state-look-back-2016-presidential-election/23017643/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.160Z","path":"how-many-states-did-trump-win","name":"How Many States Did Trump Win"},{"article":"What is human trafficking? Human trafficking is a serious crime and violation of human rights, involving the use of force, coercion or fraud to exploit a person into slave labor or sexual exploitation.\r\n\r\nHuman trafficking can happen to people of all ages and genders, and of any race or religious background.  Victims frequently do not seek help due to language barriers, fear of their traffickers or fear of law enforcement. Because human trafficking is considered to be a hidden crime, several key indicators can help people recognize potential endangerment and notify law enforcement.\r\nA common misconception about human trafficking is that it does not happen in the United States. This is false, as the United States is ranked as one of the worst countries in the world for human trafficking. It is estimated that 199,000 incidents occur within the United States every year.\r\n\r\nThe [National Human Trafficking Hotline](https://humantraffickinghotline.org/states)\r\nhas one of the most extensive data sets on human trafficking in the United States collected through phone calls, texts, online chats, emails, and online tips received by the hotline. While this information is some of the most comprehensive available, the data does not define the totality of human trafficking. The number of cases presented is only the cases that are reported. \r\n\r\nThe [Human Trafficking Hotline](https://humantraffickinghotline.org/) serves victims and survivors of human trafficking across the United States. The Hotline is available 24/7, 365 days a year, and in more than 200 languages. The confidential Hotline helps any person of any age, religion, race, language, gender identity, sexual orientation, or disability. To contact the Hotline to report a tip, seek services, or ask for help, dial 1-888-373-7888. Hearing and speech-impaired individuals should dial 711. You can also send an SMS text to 233-733 or start a live chat on their website. \r\n\r\n#### States with the Highest Human Trafficking Rates\r\nWashington D.C. has the highest human trafficking rate in the United States of 11.66 victims per 100,000 people. In 2019, there were 34 human trafficking cases reported in D.C., 18 of which were sex trafficking, 7 of which were labor trafficking, 7 were unspecified and 3 were sex and labor trafficking. \r\n\r\nNevada has the second-highest human trafficking rate of 9.97 victims per 100,000 people. Nevada has 124 reported human trafficking cases in 2019, 100 of which were sex trafficking cases. Because adult prostitution is legal in 11 counties in Nevada, traffickers use legal brothels to traffic children by creating false identification. \r\nDelaware has the third-highest human trafficking rate of 4.27 victims per 100,000 people. Delaware has 14 cases reported in 2019, 10 of which were sex trafficking. Females were the majority of victims in the cases. Delaware is a popular state for traffickers due to its location on I-95.\r\n\r\nWith a human trafficking rate of 4.2 victims per 100,000 people, Nebraska has the fourth-highest human trafficking rate in the United States. Nebraska had 25 reported cases in 2019, the majority of which were sex trafficking cases. Females were the primary target of sex trafficking, mostly adults but some minors were involved as well. Some of the main centers of trafficking in Nebraska are Omaha, Lincoln, and Grand Island. \r\n\r\nCalifornia has the fifth-highest rate of human trafficking of 4.15 victims per 100,000 residents. California has the highest number of human trafficking cases reported of 749 cases in 2019. Given Californiaâs location by an international border and presence of major airports, traffickers see the state as a low-risk, high-reward, and profitable human trafficking location. Of the 749 cases reported, 535 were sex trafficking, 85 were labor trafficking, 81 were unspecified, and 48 were sex and labor trafficking. \r\n\r\nMichigan has the sixth-highest human trafficking rate of 3.81 victims per 100,000 people. Michigan has the seventh-highest number of sex trafficking cases reported in 2019 of 172. Of the 172 cases, 131 of them were sex trafficking, 16 were unspecified, 15 were labor trafficking, and 10 were sex and labor. The top industries for labor trafficking in Michigan were restaurants and foodservice and traveling sales crew and the top industries for sex trafficking were residence-based commercial sex and hotel- and motel-based. \r\n\r\nGeorgia has the seventh-highest human trafficking rate of 3.49 victims per 100,000 residents. Georgia has the fifth-highest number of human trafficking cases of 222 in 2019. Atlanta, in particular, is a major human trafficking transportation hub and is one of the top U.S. cities with the highest levels of child sex trafficking. Of the 222 cases in 2019, 159 were sex trafficking, 41 were labor trafficking, 13 were sex and labor, and nine were unspecified. About 57 cases were confirmed to involved minors. \r\n\r\nHawaii has the eighth-highest human trafficking rate in the United States of 3.4 victims per 100,000 people. In 2019, Hawaii had 21 reported human trafficking cases. [A study](https://www.dropbox.com/s/e9muqfigatvfdp1/2020_SexTraffickingHawaii_FINAL.pdf?dl=0) published interviewed sex trafficking victims in Hawaii. The study revealed that more than 75% of trafficked victims reported being homeless, 64% of victims were Native Hawaiian, and 82% of victims were first trafficked as children.\r\n\r\nNew Mexico has the ninth-highest human trafficking rate in the U.S. of 3.34 cases per 100,000 people. There were 31 reported human trafficking cases in 2019 in New Mexico. The majority of human trafficking cases are sex trafficking, with most of the victims being female. New Mexico is a prime location for human trafficking because the interstate exchange of I-25 and I-40 called the Big I. New Mexico is also attractive to traffickers because of its high rates of poverty and domestic violence.\r\n\r\nWith a human trafficking rate of 3.26 victims per 100,000 people, Kansas has the tenth-highest rate in the country. There were 43 reported cases in 2019. The majority of cases were sex trafficking and the majority of victims were female. Cities and counties along the I-70 corridor in Kansas experience a high-than-average amount of trafficking. \r\n\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Rate (per sexual relationship between two closely related family members. The relationship between the two people is so close that they are unable to legally get married. \n\nIn the majority of states in the United States, incest is illegal. The punishments associated with engaging in an incestuous relationship vary by state. In many cases, incest is not revealed to outside parties, so therefore, the parties involved are not prosecuted. \n\nIn the states of New Jersey and Rhode Island, incest between adults is legal. However, neither state permits marriage. In New Jersey, each person involved in the relationship must be at least 18 years old. In Rhode Island, the age of consent is 16 years old. \n\nIn the state of Ohio, incest is legally allowed provided that one party is not a parental figure to the other party. \n\nIn all other states, incest is illegal. The punishments for engaging in an incestuous relationship by state are as follows: \n\n- Alabama: 1 to 10 years in prison and a fine up to $15,000\n- Alaska: 2 to 12 years in prison and a fine up to $50,000\n- Arizona: 1 to 3.75 years in prison\n- Arkansas: 3 to 10 years in prison and a fine of $10,000\n- California: Probation or up to 3 years in prison and a fine of $10,000\n- Colorado: 2 to 12 years in prison and a fine of $2,000 to $750,000\n- Connecticut: 1 to 5 years in prison and a fine of $5,000\n- Delaware: Up to 1 year in prison and a fine of $2,300\n- District of Columbia: Up to 12 years in prison and a fine of $37,500\n- Florida: Up to 15 years in prison and a fine of $5,000\n- Georgia: 10 to 30 years in prison\n- Hawaii: Up to 5 years in prison\n- Idaho: Up to a life sentence in prison\n- Illinois: 2 to 10 years in prison and a $25,000 fine\n- Indiana: 1 to 6 years in prison\n- Iowa: Up to 5 years in prison and a fine of $7,500\n- Kansas: 5 months to 136 months in prison\n- Kentucky: 5 years to life in prison\n- Louisiana: 5 years to 30 years\n- Maine: Up to 5 years in prison and/or a $5,000 fine\n- Maryland: 1 to 10 years in prison\n- Massachusetts: Up to 20 years in prison\n- Michigan: Up to 2 years in prison and/or a fine up to $500\n- Minnesota: Up to 10 years in prison\n- Mississippi: Up to 10 years in prison or a fine up to $500\n- Missouri: Up to 7 years in prison\n- Montana: Up to a life sentence in prison\n- Nebraska: 1 to 25 years in prison\n- Nevada: 2 years to life in prison and a fine of $10,000\n- New Hampshire: 10 to 20 years in prison\n- New Jersey: At least 15 years without parole for 2nd degree assault; up to 18 months for criminal sexual contact\n- New Mexico: Up to 3 years in prison and a fine of $5,000\n- New York: 10 to 25 years in prison\n- North Carolina: 10 months to 182 months in prison\n- North Dakota: Up to 5 years in prison and a fine of $10,000\n- Ohio: 2 to 6 years in prison\n- Oklahoma: Up to 10 years in prison\n- Oregon: Up to 20 years in prison and a fine of $375,000\n- Pennsylvania: Up to 10 years in prison\n- Rhode Island: No criminal prosecution for consensual incest between parties aged 16 or Laws By State"},{"article":"Income includes the revenue from wages, salaries, interest on a savings account, dividends from shares of stock, rent, and profits from selling something for more than you paid for it. Income inequality refers to the extent to which income is distributed unevenly among a population. \r\n\r\nThe [Gini coefficient](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gini-index.asp), also called the Gini Index or Gini ratio, is a statistical measure of distribution intended to represent the income or wealth distribution of a nation. It ranges from 0 (0%) to 1 (100%), with 0 representing perfect equality and 1 representing perfect inequality. A higher Gini coefficient means greater inequality. The Gini coefficient would be zero is everyone in a nation had the same income. \r\n\r\nThe Gini coefficient is defined based on the [Lorenz curve](https://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/lorenz-curve.asp). The Lorenz curve plots the percentiles of the population on the horizontal axis of the graph according to income or wealth, whichever is being measured (income, in this case). The cumulative income of the population is plotted on the vertical axis.\r\n\r\nThe United States has a Gini coefficient of 0.485, the highest it has been in 50 years, according to the United States Census Bureau. Each state also has a Gini coefficient. \r\n\r\n[Zippia](https://www.zippia.com/advice/states-highest-lowest-income-inequality/) analyzed datasets from 2010 and 2016 from the American Community Survey and then analyzed the Gini coefficient for each state in both periods. Based on this, the five states with the highest income inequality in the United States are:\r\n\r\n1.\tNew York (.5102)\r\n2.\tConnecticut (.4947)\r\n3.\tLouisiana (.4903)\r\n4.\tCalifornia (.4880)\r\n5.\tFlorida (.4852)\r\n\r\nAll five of these states have a Gini coefficient that is higher than the U.S. Gini coefficient. \r\n\r\nNew York has the greatest income inequality in the United States. In 2015, the average income of the top 1% was $2.2 million and the average income of the bottom 99% was $49,617. This is a ratio of 44.4 to 1. Nationally, the numbers were $1.32 million for the top 1% and $50,107 for the bottom 99%, a ratio of 26.3 to 1. \r\n\r\nThe five states with the least income inequality are:\r\n\r\n1.\tAlaska (.4174)\r\n2.\tUtah (.4261)\r\n3.\tWyoming (.4279)\r\n4.\tNew Hampshire (.4344)\r\n5.\tHawaii (.4369)\r\n\r\nDespite these states being the least unequal in the U.S., their Gini coefficients are still higher than many countries around the world. Alaska is about as unequal as Russia. \r\n\r\nMontana, California, Rhode Island, and Maine are experiencing the fastest changes in income inequality in the U.S. From 2010 to 2016, Montanaâs Gini coefficient increased by .022, Californiaâs increased by .019, and both Rhode Islandâs and Maineâs increased by .018.\r\n\r\nIncome inequality has both economic and political impacts such as slower GDP growth, reduced income mobility, greater household debt, political polarization, and higher poverty rates. Crime has been shown to be correlated with inequality. The separation of society into the âelitesâ and the âmassesâ played a central role in the collapse of other advanced civilizations such as the Roman Empire. \r\n\r\nThe income inequailty of each state can be found on [Zippia](https://www.zippia.com/advice/states-highest-lowest-income-inequality/).\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":[{"link":"gdp-by-state","title":"GDP by State"},"gdp-growth-by-state",{"link":"richest-states-in-usa","title":"Richest States"},"poorest-states","per-capita-income-by-state","income-inequality-by-state","income-tax-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.160Z","path":"income-inequality-by-state","name":"Income Inequality By State"},{"article":"In the United States, each state has its own policy for collecting income taxes. Incomes taxes are just one of the ways that state governments make revenues for operations â think things like building schools and repairing roads. Of the 50 states, a total of 43 have some form of state income taxes. In 41 states, wages and salaries are taxed. In New Hampshire and Tennessee, only interest income and tax dividends are taxed. In the remaining seven states, there is no state income tax. However, the state makes revenue through other forms of taxation, such as higher property tax rates or higher sales tax rates. \n\nThese arenât the only differences among the states when it comes to income taxes, either. For example, some states have their own deductions and exemptions, while others use rates based on the federal tax code, while some states donât allow any deductions or exemptions. Some states have different brackets for married and single tax filers. \n\nFor the purpose of this article, weâre going to take a look at the latest marginal individual income tax rates as of 2019. Remember, though, this data is subject to change over time but is accurate as of August 2019. \n\nThe state with the highest income tax bracket is California, which has a maximum tax rate of 13.3%. The lowest tax bracket in California is 1%, which is one of the lowest in the nation. The next highest income tax rate is found in Oregon, where the highest bracket has a rate of 9.9%. The lowest income tax bracket in Oregon is 5%. Minnesota has a similar range of state income tax rates, with the lowest being 5.35% and the highest reaching 9.85%. \n\nOther states with income tax rates that exceed 8% include Iowa, New Jersey, Vermont, Washington D.C., New York, and Hawaii. \n\nStates with maximum state income tax rates of at least 6% but less than 7% include Connecticut, Arkansas, Montana, Nebraska, Delaware, West Virginia, Georgia, Missouri, Kentucky, and Louisiana. \n\nStates with maximum income tax rates of at least 5% but less than 6% are Rhode Island, Maryland, Virginia, Kansas, Ohio, Oklahoma, Alabama, and Mississippi. \n\nOther than the states that do not levy an individual income tax, North Dakota has the lowest income tax rate in the nation. The tax rates in this state fall between 1.1% and 2.9%. Arizona has the second-lowest rates at 2.59% to 4.54%. Finally, New Mexico also has a low income tax rate of 1.7% to 4.9%.\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Income Tax Lowest
