Killers By State"},{"article":"Most of us have conversations in person and on the phone without having to record it. There are other situations, however, where you may consider or possibly move forward with recording the conversation. Maybe youâre trying to gather evidence against someone that has done you wrong. Alternatively, perhaps you have a more innocent excuse â youâre talking with a bill collector, and you want to make sure that you keep everything documented. Apps on smartphones make recording a conversation as easy as tapping a button.\n\nHowever, you should be aware that there are legal issues with recording a conversation, whether itâs in person in your home or over the phone. In some states, two-party consent is required before you hit ârecord.â This means that ALL parties involved in the conversation must be aware that they are being recorded.\n\nIn other states, there are more relaxed laws. Many states have single-party consent laws. This means that just one party involved in the conversation needs to be aware that it is being recorded. If youâre the one recording the conversation, for example, you do not have to reveal this to the other party.\n\nWashington, D.C. also has single-party consent laws.\n\nItâs also important to note that some states do have exceptions to their laws. For example, in Hawaii, all parties must be notified if the recorder is located in a private area.\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Alaska","Arizona","Arkansas","Colorado","Georgia","Hawaii","Idaho","Indiana","Iowa","Kansas","Kentucky","Louisiana","Maine","Minnesota","Mississippi","Missouri","Nebraska","New Jersey","New Mexico","New York","North Carolina","North Dakota","Ohio","Oklahoma","Rhode Island","South Carolina","South Dakota","Tennessee","Texas","Utah","Virginia","West Virginia","Wisconsin","Wyoming"]},"sources":[{"name":"Recording Phone Calls and Conversations","link":"http://www.dmlp.org/legal-guide/recording-phone-calls-and-conversations"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"single-party-consent-states","name":"Single Party Consent States"},{"article":"The United States as we know it is the 'land of the free.' With so many freedoms, itâs hard to believe that there was a time in history when a group of people did not have any freedom. These people could not own land, they could not vote, and they worked for no pay and were frequently mistreated. These people â slaves â did not enjoy the freedom and the opportunities of the United States until after the American Civil War.\n\nIn Americaâs early history, all of the British colonies initially allowed slavery. When the original Thirteen Colonies of the United States were established, each permitted slavery. It wasnât until the mid-18th century when political and social movements were created to speak out against slavery. During the American Revolution, thousands of black Americans fought. Many fought against the British in hopes that they would be freed. Others fought with the British army after being offered freedom in exchange for serving in the military.\n\nIt was during the late 17th century that black Americans began petitioning legislatures to abolish slavery. Five northern states agreed to gradually abolish slavery, with Pennsylvania being the first state to approve, followed by New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut, and Rhode Island. By the early 1800s, the northern states had all abolished slavery completely, or they were in the process of gradually eradicating it.\n\nBy the early 1800s, there was an equal number of slave and free states. These states were divided by what became known as the Mason-Dixon line. In 1808, international slave importing was banned but domestic trade will still legal.\n\nAs the United States continued to grow, so did the number of slave states. In 1836, there were 13 slave states and 13 free states. States that allowed slavery included:\n\n- Arkansas\n- Missouri\n- Mississippi\n- Louisiana\n- Alabama\n- Kentucky\n- Tennessee\n- Virginia\n- Maryland\n- Delaware\n- North Carolina\n- South Carolina\n- Alabama\n- Florida at the time was still a territory, and slavery was allowed.\n\nAbout ten years later, the number of slave states rose to 15, outnumbering the 14 free states. The newly added slave states were:\n\n- Florida\n- Texas\n\nIn the late 1850s, the free states finally began to outnumber the 15 slave states. This continued through the early 1860s, when the number of free states rose to 19, while there were still just 15 slave states.\n\nAt the beginning of the Civil War, there were 34 total states in the U.S. Of these states, 15 still allowed slavery. Slavery was the key driver behind the Civil War, with states seceding from the Union and forming the Confederacy. Many states including Maryland, Tennessee, and Missouri abolished slavery before the end of the Civil War. However, some states still allowed slavery until the Thirteenth Amendment to the Constitution was put into place, entirely abolishing slavery in the nation in 1865.\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Arkansas","Delaware","Florida","Georgia","Kentucky","Louisiana","Maryland","Mississippi","Missouri","North Carolina","South Carolina","Tennessee","Texas","Virginia"]},"sources":[{"name":"Map of Free and Slave States in 1860","link":"https://herb.ashp.cuny.edu/items/show/2008"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"slave-states","name":"Slave States"},{"article":"Tobacco is the common name of several plants of the Nicotiana genus and is the general term for any product made using cured tobacco leaves, such as cigarettes. Because tobacco contains nicotine, it can become addictive and users often find it difficult to quit using tobacco products.\r\n\r\nAccording to the World Health Organization, tobacco kills more than 8 million people per year, including both smokers and those who are exposed to second-hand smoke. In the United States, tobacco use is the leading cause of preventable death. \r\n\r\nTobacco use increases the risk of several health problems. These include blood clots, coronary heart disease, heart attacks, certain types of cancer, and lung disease. Tobacco use also leads to tooth and gum decay and wrinkled skin. \r\n\r\nAccording to the [Center for Disease Control](https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/disparities/low-ses/index.htm) (CDC), there are disparities in tobacco use between socioeconomic classes. âIn the U.S., people living below the poverty level and people having lower levels of educational attainment have higher rates of cigarette smoking than the general population.â Additionally, those in lower-income areas have less access to primary health care and health insurance, and fewer resources to help them quick smoking, increasing their chances of being diagnosed with later stages of cancer and diseases from smoking. The tobacco industry also systematically target low-income populations and specific demographics with price discounts, direct-mail marketing, and in-store promotions. \r\n\r\nThe ten states with the highest rates of tobacco use are:\r\n\r\n1.\tWest Virginia (26.00%)\r\n2.\tKentucky (24.60%)\r\n3.\tLouisiana (23.10%)\r\n4.\tTennessee (22.60%)\r\n5.\tArkansas (22.30%)\r\n6.\tMississippi (22.20%)\r\n7.\tIndiana (21.80%)\r\n8.\tOhio (21.10%)\r\n9.\tAlaska (21.00%)\r\n10.\tAlabama (20.90%)\r\n\r\nWest Virginia has the highest rate of tobacco use at 26%. People living in rural areas are more likely to smoke than others and are more likely to consume more than 15 cigarettes per day, according to an analysis by the [American Lung Association](https://www.lung.org/assets/documents/research/cutting-tobaccos-rural-roots.pdf). West Virginia, and many of the top ten states, all have vast rural areas. \r\n\r\nThe ten states with the lowest rates of tobacco use are:\r\n\r\n1.\tUtah (8.90%)\r\n2.\tPuerto Rico (11.30%)\r\n3.\tCalifornia (11.30%)\r\n4.\tConnecticut (12.70%)\r\n5.\tHawaii (12.80%)\r\n6.\tWashington (13.50%)\r\n7.\tMassachusetts (13.70%)\r\n8.\tNew Jersey (13.70%)\r\n9.\tMaryland (13.80%)\r\n10.\tNew York (14.10%)\r\n\r\nUtah has the lowest rate of tobacco use in the United States at 8.9%. Utah is the only state to have a tobacco usage rate in the single digits. Throughout the United States, however, tobacco use has been decreasing over the years thanks to smoke-free policies; increased support and programs to help people quit smoking; and campaigns spreading the awareness of health risks associated with tobacco use.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table of each stateâs rate of tobacco use.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Number of State"},{"article":"Citizens and permanent residents of the United States are issued a Social Security number by the Social Security Administration. Your Social Security number â or SSN, for short â is a nine-digit unique identifier that is used for a number of purposes. The most common way that this number is used is for tracking citizens and residents for Social Security purposes. However, your Social Security number can also be used for taxation, applying for credit, and other purposes. \n\nAs mentioned, the SSN consists of nine numbers. These numbers are broken into three parts. The first three numbers are the area number. Until 2011, this number corresponded with the state or territory in which the number was assigned. However, after 2011, numbers were assigned at random. \n\nThe next set of numbers consists of two digits. This set is known as group numbers and does not relate to geographical location. \n\nFinally, the last set of numbers consists of four digits. This is a number that goes in order from 0001 to 9999. \n\nAny Social Security number issued prior to 2011 can be evaluated to determine where the number was issued. To learn where a Social Security number was issued, look at the area number â the first three digits. Then, match these numbers with the following. Note that some states may appear on this list more than once. \n\n- New Hampshire: 001 to 003\n- Maine: 004 to 007\n- Vermont: 008 to 009\n- Massachusetts: 010 to 034\n- Rhode Island: 035 to 039\n- Connecticut: 040 to 049\n- New York: 050 to 134\n- New Jersey: 135 to 158\n- Pennsylvania: 159 to 211\n- Maryland: 212 to 220\n- Delaware: 221 to 222\n- Virginia: 223 to 231\n- West Virginia: 232 to Security Number By State"},{"article":"The Southeast United States is the region of the United States located in the southeastern portion of the United States. More specifically, it includes all states that fall south of the Mason-Dixon line and the Ohio River, stretching as far as Arkansas. Like other informal regions of the United States, the states that are considered part of the Southeast are defined differently. \n \nThe American Association of Geographers has defined the Southeast region to include the following states: \n \n- Alabama\n- Florida\n- Georgia\n- Kentucky\n- Maryland\n- Mississippi\n- North Carolina\n- South Carolina\n- Tennessee\n- Virginia\n- West Virginia\n \nThe U.S. Geological Survey the Southeast slightly differently. Under this definition, the following states make up this region: \n \n- Alabama\n- Arkansas\n- Florida\n- Georgia\n- Louisiana\n- Mississippi\n- North Carolina\n- South Carolina\n- Tennessee\n \nThe territories of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands are also included as part of the Southeast under this definition. Other definitions also include Delaware, Maryland, and the District of Columbia. \n \nThe Southeastern United States has a total area of over 580,000 square miles with a population of over 97 million. The population density is just over 150 people per square mile. \n \nThe most populous state in the region is Florida, which has an estimated population of nearly 21 million people. Other populous states include Georgia, which has a population of over 10.4 million, North Carolina, which has a population of over 10.27 million, and Virginia, with a population of over 8.47 million. \n \nThe least populous state in the Southeast is West Virginia, which has a population of 1.8 million, followed by Mississippi with a population of 2.98 million. Arkansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, and Alabama are also among the least populous southeastern states with populations that each fall below 5 million per the latest estimates. \n \nThe largest city in the Southeast is Jacksonville, Florida, which has a population of over 868,000. Other populous cities include Charlotte, North Carolina; Washington, D.C.; Nashville, Tennessee; Memphis, Tennessee; and Baltimore, Maryland. \n\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Florida","Georgia","Kentucky","Maryland","Mississippi","North Carolina","South Carolina","Tennessee","Virginia","West Virginia"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["bible-belt-states","border-states","coastal-states",{"link":"4-corners-states","title":"Four Corners States"},"east-coast-states","eastern-states","flyover-states","gulf-states","great-lakes-states","lower-48-states",{"link":"midwest-states","title":"Midwestern United States"},{"link":"mid-atlantic-states","title":"Mid-Atlantic States"},"mountain-states","new-england-states","northern-states","rust-belt-states","southeast-states","southwest-states","west-coast-states"]}},"sources":[{"name":"What is SEDAAG?","link":"https://sedaag.org/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"southeast-states","name":"Southeast States"},{"article":"The Southwestern states â or, simply, the Southwest â is a region that is located in the western region of the United States. Since this in an informal region, exact boundaries vary. Depending on what definition you use, as few as two states or as many as eight states make up this region. \n\nThe states of Arizona and New Mexico are said to be the core of the region. No matter what boundaries are used, these two states are always considered southwest states. The six additional states that may or may not be included in the definition of the southwest states are: \n\nCalifornia\nColorado\nNevada\nOklahoma\nTexas\nUtah\n\nPer the last U.S. census taken in 2010, Nevada was the fastest-growing state in the nation. Other southwestern states including Texas, Colorado, and Arizona were among the top ten fastest-growing states per the census.\n\nSome of the largest cities in the world are located in the southwest region. Las Vegas, Nevada, and Albuquerque, New Mexico, are two of the fastest-growing cities in the nation. \n\nPhoenix, Arizona, the largest metropolitan area, has a population of about 4 million. Las Vegas (population of over 2 million) and Tucson (population of over 1 million) are also large metro areas located in this region. The city of Phoenix is also the largest city in the southwest and is the only city with a population of more than 1 million. \n\nOne of the characteristics of the southwestern states are that they are ethnically diverse. African Americans, Asians, American Indians, and Hispanic Americans are among the groups that live in the southwest. Southwestern cities including San Antonio, Texas; Albuquerque, New Mexico; Mesa, Arizona; and El Paso, Texas, have large populations of Mexican Americans and Spanish Americans. \n\nAnother standout feature of the southwestern states are the national parks and monuments. One of the most notable is the Grand Canyon, which is located in Arizona. Other significant landmarks include Californiaâs Death Valley National Park, Coloradoâs Great Sand Dunes National Park, and Texasâ Big Bend National Park.\n\n","data":{"states":["California","Colorado","Nevada","Oklahoma","Texas","Utah"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["bible-belt-states","border-states","coastal-states",{"link":"4-corners-states","title":"Four Corners States"},"east-coast-states","eastern-states","flyover-states","gulf-states","great-lakes-states","lower-48-states",{"link":"midwest-states","title":"Midwestern United States"},{"link":"mid-atlantic-states","title":"Mid-Atlantic States"},"mountain-states","new-england-states","northern-states","rust-belt-states","southeast-states","southwest-states","west-coast-states"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Southwest Region, United States","link":"https://www.britannica.com/place/Southwest-region"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"southwest-states","name":"Southwest States"},{"article":"Speed limits are restrictions on the minimum and maximum speeds vehicles may travel on a given stretch of road. Speed limits are designated by signs and are used in many countries. In the United States, speed limits are used to protect drivers and regulate unruly or dangerous behavior on the roads.\r\n\r\nThere is no guarantee that posting speed limits has any effect on driver behaviors, as most drivers will ultimately travel at the speed that they feel the most comfortable going. However, law enforcement does monitor the speed of motorists and failure to adhere to posted speed limits can result in fines and, depending on how fast a driver is going, arrest. \r\n\r\nSpeed limits vary between states and are often different for rural interstates, urban interstates, and other types of roads. Montana has different speed limits for day and night on certain types of roads. Some states, such as California and Arkansas, have different speed limits for trucks and cars.\r\n\r\nThere are three main categories of roads: arterial, collector and local. Arterial roads have higher speeds and fewer access points, such as on- and off-ramps. Collector roads have high speeds and are balanced to have more access points. Local roads have lower speeds and more access points, such as intersections and cross streets. The difference between these three types of streets is the reason why there are different speed limits. Roads with fewer travelers and fewer vehicles attempting to cross one another can sustain higher speeds, while roads with more volume of travelers and have more bikers or pedestrians need to have lower speeds.\r\n\r\nSouth Dakota has the highest speed limits in the United States. Rural and urban interstates both have a speed limit of 80 miles per hour and other roads are posted at 70 miles per hour. Hawaii has the overall lowest speed limits in the United States. Rural and urban interstates in Hawaii have a speed limit of 60 miles per hour and other roads are posted at 45 miles per hour.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table with each stateâs speed limits for rural interstates, urban interstates, and other roads.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"note":"* All speeds are in miles per hour.","columns":["state",{"header":"Rural State"},{"article":"What are the most densely populated states in the United States of America? Here is a list of the top ten states with the largest population density:\n\n1. District of Columbia (Population density: 11,665 people per square mile)\n2. New Jersey (Population density: 1,213 people per square mile)\n3. Rhode Island (Population density: 1,022 people per square mile)\n4. Puerto Rico (Population density: 900 people per square mile)\n5. Massachusetts (Population density: 890 people per square mile)\n6. Connecticut (Population density: 737 people per square mile)\n7. Maryland (Population density: 625 people per square mile)\n8. Delaware (Population density: 500 people per square mile)\n9. New York (Population density: 414 people per square mile)\n10. Florida (Population density: 404 people per square mile)\n\nAnd what about the least densely populated states in the US? These are the top ten states with the smallest population density:\n\n1. Alaska (Population density: 1 people per square mile)\n2. Wyoming (Population density: 6 people per square mile)\n3. Montana (Population density: 7 people per square mile)\n4. North Dakota (Population density: 11 people per square mile)\n5. South Dakota (Population density: 12 people per square mile)\n6. New Mexico (Population density: 17 people per square mile)\n7. Idaho (Population density: 22 people per square mile)\n8. Nebraska (Population density: 25 people per square mile)\n9. Nevada (Population density: 28 people per square mile)\n10. Kansas (Population density: 36 people per square mile)\n\nFor those who enjoy wide open spaces, the United States offers plenty of options. The large states of Alaska, Wyoming, and Montana have the lowest population densities in the country, with Montana having 7p/miÂ² in a population of 1,062,330, Wyoming 6p/miÂ² with a population of just 573,720 (also the lowest population in the country), and Alaska topping them all with only 1p/miÂ² relative to its population of 738,068 and total area of 570,641miÂ².\n\nIn comparison to the other states, the District of Columbia covers a tiny area of just 61miÂ², yet it has a population of 703,608 which makes it by far the densest state of all at 11,535p/miÂ². New Jersey follows with a population density of 1,228p/miÂ², and Rhode Island is close behind at 1,027p/miÂ² â both are also among the smallest states.\n\nStatistics show a range of population densities in the most highly populated states. California has a total population of 39,776,830, and a population density of 255p/miÂ², Texas has a population of 28,704,330 and its population density is a relatively low 110p/miÂ² (although this is due to it also being one of the largest states at 261,232miÂ²), while Florida's population of 21,312,211 has a population density of 397p/miÂ². These numbers likely reflect the fact that some states have particularly populous cities, which is likely to skew the statistics somewhat â for example, New York has a total population of 19,862,512 and a population density of 421p/miÂ², but New York City is also the most highly populated city in the United States.\n","frontmatter":{"title":"United States by Density","date":"2018-11-8","description":"The United States contains a variety of population densities."},"data":{"customMeta":{"columns":["state","density","population","area"],"sortField":"Density","sortAsc":false,"showAllstates":true,"chloroMap":{"field":"Density","scale":"log"}}},"sources":[{"name":"US Census State Population Estimates","link":"https://www.census.gov/data/tables/2016/demo/popest/state-total.html","description":"Most recent state estimates from the Census Bureau's Population Estimates Program"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:26.812Z","path":"state-densities","name":"State Densities"},{"article":"The [mottos](https://statesymbolsusa.org/categories/state-motto) of all fifty states in the US are representative of what each state values the most. The purpose of each state motto is to give a voice to the individual states and show what the state believes at its core. The motto of each state is different from the slogan of the states. State slogans are intended to welcome visitors and assist with tourism rates in the given states, whereas mottos are meant to paint a picture of the state and its principles. its own [nickname](https://alphabetizer.flap.tv/lists/list-of-states-in-alphabetical-order.php). There is a story behind the nicknames, too. Below are each of the fifty states in America, followed by their various [nicknames](https://statesymbolsusa.org/categories/nickname), as well as a brief synopsis of how their full nicknames came to be. \n\n## Alabama\n- Abbreviation: AL\n- Full nickname: The Yellowhammer State\n\nThere is a bird known as the yellowhammer after which Alabama is named because the bird was representative of the uniforms of confederate soldiers in Alabama during the 1860s. \n\nAdditional nicknames for includeâ¦\n- Camellia State\n- The Heart of Dixie\n\n## Alaska\n- Abbreviation: AK\n- Full nickname: The Last Frontier\n\nAlaska is called the Last Frontier State because it was the second to last state to join the nation.\n\nAdditional nicknames for Alaska includeâ¦\n- Land of the Midnight Sun\n- The North Star State\n\n## Arizona\n- Abbreviation: AZ\n- Full nickname: The Grand Canyon State\n\nArizona is home to the Grand Canyon, and since it's an incredibly renowned national park, so the popularity of the park is where Arizona gets its nickname. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Arizona includeâ¦\n- The Apache State\n- The Copper State\n\n## Arkansas\n- Abbreviation: AR\n- Full nickname: The Natural State\n\nArkansas has so much natural beauty and scenery, hence the nickname of The Natural State. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Arkansas includeâ¦\n- The Land of Opportunity\n- The Wonder State\n\n## California\n- Abbreviation: CA\n- Full nickname: The Golden State\n\nIn 1848, Californians struck gold during the Gold Rush, and coupled with the Golden Gate Bridge, the historical event is where California gets its nickname. \n\nAdditional nicknames for California includeâ¦\n- The Grape State\n- The Land of Milk and Honey \n\n## Colorado\n- Abbreviation: CO\n- Full nickname: The Centennial State\n\nThe centennial part of Colorado's name refers to the fact that Colorado officially became part of the US one hundred years after Congress signed the Declaration of Independence.\n\nAdditional nicknames for includeâ¦\n- The Columbine State\n- The Rocky Mountain State\n\n## Connecticut\n- Abbreviation: CT\n- Full nickname: The Constitution State\n\nSome of the very first laws put into place in the US were written in Connecticut, so the state was nicknamed after the Constitution itself.  \n\nAdditional nicknames for Connecticut includeâ¦\n- The Arsenal of the Nation\n- The Nutmeg State\n\n## Delaware\n- Abbreviation: DE\n- Full nickname: The First State\n\nOut of all the original thirteen colonies, Delware signed the Consitution first, so it was dubbed the First State. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Delaware includeâ¦\n- The Diamond State\n- The Spud State\n\n## Florida\n- Abbreviation: FL\n- Full nickname: The Sunshine State\n\nThe Sunshine State is Florida's nickname because of the state's geography and abundance of sunny weather. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Florida includeâ¦\n- The Everglade State\n- The Orange State\n\n## Georgia\n- Abbreviation: GA\n- Full nickname: The Peach State\n\nGeorgia peaches are the best of the best, earning Georgia the nickname of The Peach State.\n\nAn additional nickname for Georgia is...\n- The Empire State of the South\n\n## Hawaii\n- Abbreviation: HI\n- Full nickname: The Aloha State\n\nAloha is Hawaiian for hello, so the state was nicknamed as the Aloha State. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Hawaii includeâ¦\n- The Pineapple State\n- The Rainbow State\n\n## Idaho\n- Abbreviation: ID\n- Full nickname: The Gem State\n\nIdaho is known as the Gem State because its official state name is actually a Shoshone Native American word for gem of the mountains. \n\n## Illinois\n- Abbreviation: IL\n- Full nickname: The Prairie State\n\nIllinois is nicknamed after Abraham Lincoln who lived in Illinois when he was chosen as the president of the US in 1861.  \n\nAdditional nicknames for Illinois includeâ¦\n- The Land of Lincoln\n- The Rainy State\n\n## Indiana\n- Abbreviation: IN\n- Full nickname: The Hoosier State \n\nThe official nickname of Indiana is pulled from a poem called \"The Hoosier's Nest,\" by poet John Finley. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Indiana includeâ¦\n- The Hoosier State\n- The Hospitality State\n\n## Iowa\n- Abbreviation: IA\n- Full nickname: The Hawkeye State\n\nNative American tribe leader Chief Black Hawk was forced to move to land that is now Iowa, so the state is nicknamed after him out of respect and appreciation. \n\n## Kansas\n- Abbreviation: KS\n- Full nickname: The Sunflower State\n\nKansas is home to sunflowers galore, earning it the title of the Sunflower State. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Kansas includeâ¦\n- The Jayhawk State\n- The Wheat State\n\n## Kentucky\n- Abbreviation: KY\n- Full nickname: The Bluegrass State\n\nGrasslands in Kentucky sprout grass with blue budding flowers at the tips, hence the term bluegrass. \n\n## Louisiana\n- Abbreviation: LA\n- Full nickname: The Pelican State\n\nThere are more pelicans in Louisiana than in most other places, so Louisiana i known as the Pelican State.\n\nAdditional nicknames for Louisiana includeâ¦\n- The Bayou State\n- The Child of the Mississippi\n\n## Maine\n- Abbreviation: ME\n- Full nickname: The Pine Tree State\n\nWhite pine trees are some of Maine's most unique and treasured natural beauties.  \n\nAn additional nickname for Maine is...\n- Vacationland \n\n## Maryland\n- Abbreviation: MD\n- Full nickname: The Old Line State\n\nDuring the Revolutionary War in the United States, the troops from Maryland that fought in the war were known as the Maryland Line military. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Maryland includeâ¦\n- The Cockade State\n- The Free State\n\n## Massachusetts\n- Abbreviation: MA\n- Full nickname: The Bay State\n\nCape Cod Bay is part of Massachusetts, and the state was also home to the Massachusetts Bay Company which acted as the government, if you will, until the year 1684. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Massachusetts includeâ¦\n- The Colony State\n- The Spirit of America\n\n## Michigan\n- Abbreviation: MI\n- Full nickname: The Wolverine State\n\nWolverines are not hard to find in Michigan, so the state earned a nickname inspired by the wild animals. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Michigan includeâ¦\n- The Mitten State\n- The Winter Water Wonderland\n\n## Minnesota\n- Abbreviation: MN\n- Full nickname: The North Star State\n\nThe state motto of Minnesota is translated in English to mean the Star of the North, so it makes sense to nickname the state something similar. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Minnesota includeâ¦\n- The Gopher State\n- The State of Hockey\n\n## Mississippi\n- Abbreviation: MS\n- Full nickname: The Magnolia State \n\nThere are magnolias all over the state of Mississippi, and it happens to be the state's official flower as well as its nickname. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Mississippi includeâ¦\n- The Hospitality State\n- The Mudcat State\n\n## Missouri\n- Abbreviation: MO\n- Full nickname: The Show-Me State\n\nMissouri's official nickname reflects a line from the speech given by the congressman of Missouri in 1899.\n\nAdditional nicknames for Missouri includeâ¦\n- The Bullion State\n- The Cave State\n\n## Montana\n- Abbreviation: MT\n- Full nickname: The Treasure State\n\nMontana has a plethora of gold mines and various other reserves with an abundance of minerals. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Montana includeâ¦\n- Big Sky Country\n- The Last Best Place\n\n## Nebraska\n- Abbreviation: NE\n- Full nickname: The Cornhusker State \n\nA cornhusker is someone who grows corn competitively, which is quite seriously a sport in the state of Nebraska.\n\nAn additional nickname for Nebraska is...\n- The Beef State\n\n## Nevada\n- Abbreviation: NV\n- Full nickname: The Silver State\n\nNevada is the heart of the silver mining industry. \n\nAdditional nicknames for Nevada includeâ¦\n- The Battle-Born State\n- The Sagebrush State\n\n## New Hampshire\n- Abbreviation: NH\n- Full nickname: The Granite State \n\nIf you are ever in search of granite, New Hampshire is the state to visit. \n\nAdditional nicknames for New Hampshire includeâ¦\n- The Mother of Rivers\n- The White Mountain State\n\n## New Jersey\n- Abbreviation: NJ\n- Full nickname: The Garden State\n\nIn 1876, Abraham Browning presented a speech during which he mentioned New Jersey as being the Garden State, and the nickname stuck ever since becoming official in 1954. \n\n## New Mexico\n- Abbreviation: NM\n- Full nickname: The Land of Enchantment\n\nNew Mexico's nickname was inspired by the text in one of  Lilian Whiting's books. \n\nAn additional nickname for New Mexico is...\n- The Land of Enchantment\n\n## New York\n- Abbreviation: NY\n- Full nickname: The Empire State\n\nNew York was noted as being the Seat of the Empire by George Washington in 1785, eventually earning the state its current official nickname. State"},{"state":"Wyoming","nickname":"The Equality State","description":"","additional_nicknames":"The Cowboy State, The Park State"}]},"sources":[{"name":"State Nicknames","link":"https://statesymbolsusa.org/categories/nickname"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"state-nicknames","name":"State Nicknames"},{"article":"In the federal government, there is an immense amount of power divided among three main branches: the legislative, executive, and judicial branches. The state governments, on the other hand, arenât as powerful as the federal government. However, their power is significant within each state.\n\nState governments operate similarly to the federal government, but the only difference is they have more power over the state. They also have a similar structure to the federal government, with each state possessing a legislative, executive, and judicial branch. Any action or ability that isnât given to the federal government is handed down to the state governments, which then divides into the three central powers/branches.\n\n## Legislative\nThe legislative branch is comprised of two parts: the House of Representatives and the Senate. These two parties are part of the bicameral legislature in each state - except Nebraska, which has one - and they both work together to achieve common goals, including: \n\n- Making laws\n- Approving state budgets\n- Bringing forth tax legislation\n- Drafting articles of impeachment\n\nIn the federal government, the legislative branch is responsible for the same duties. The only difference is that Congress is made of both members from the House of Representatives and the Senate. They all end up coming together to make the countryâs laws. \n\n## Executive\nThe executive branch is the entity that performs one duty: enforce approved laws. Itâs generally run by a governor, who also works alongside his/her executive officers and agencies to get the job done. \n\nThe citizens of the state usually elect these members of the branch. Although this is a general way to pick who is enforcing the laws in each state, the executive legislation within each state is not the same.\n\nThe federal government, on the other hand, performs the same duties. They play a slightly more significant role, though, because this branch is enforcing laws throughout the country. The positions are also somewhat different as this entity contains members like:\n\n- The President\n- The Vice President\n- The Cabinet\n- Some other federal agencies\n\n## Judicial\nThe judicial branch has the help of the state supreme court and other municipal courts to interpret and evaluate the laws in place today. In the state, these court systems are used to bring forth matters related to regulations affecting the state. \n\nSometimes, when people arenât happy with the results they get from the state courts, they will appeal the judgment to the Court of Appeals, then the U.S. Supreme Court. The U.S. Supreme Court is the court that the federal government uses to make any corrections to mistakes that the lower courts have made.\n\nUnlike the state government, the federal government has the help of the Supreme Court and other higher appointed courts to make their decisions about laws. The judges for these courts are chosen based on who the President decides, and they are appointed for life. Judges for state governments, on the other hand, are selected by the state legislature.\n","lastModified":"2020-04-20T13:36:55.346Z","path":"state-powers","name":"State Powers"},{"article":"The World's Fair of 1893 was held in Chicago. In preparation for the event, there was something called the National Garland of Flowers that was created for the sake of representing every US state at the World's Fair. The garland was comprised of flowers for each of the fifty states, and at the time, the flowers were not necessarily considered state symbols. Instead, the National Garland of Flowers inspired the concept of state symbols. From there, state symbols such as trees, birds, songs, and, of course, flowers were born. \n\nBelieve it or not, even though state symbols seem mighty official, there is no actual process for selecting the state symbols in America. Take the official state dog of the state of Delaware as a perfect example. \n\nOn August 3 of 2016, the official [state dog of Delaware](https://statesymbolsusa.org/symbol-official-item/delaware/dogs-cats-mammals/golden-retriever) was announced, making the golden retriever the state dog of Delaware. The way the state dog was selected was very simple and quite humorous. A group of fourth graders sent in letters to Delaware legislators, pleading with them to make the golden retriever the state's official dog. \n\nThey had been learning about state symbols in school at the time, and one of their class assignments was to mail letters to the government regarding the state symbols. The lawmakers received the letters and put their plea to a vote, which ultimately resulted in the golden retriever becoming the official state dog of Delaware.\n\nAnother example of the casual ways by which state symbols are chosen has to do with the [official state dinosaur](https://statesymbolsusa.org/symbol-official-item/arkansas/dinosaurs-fossils/arkansaurus-fridayi) of the state of Arkansas. In 2013, a boy by the name of Mason Cypress Oury of Fayetteville County decided to embark on a campaign. He wanted the state dinosaur of Arkansas to officially be named as the Arkansaurus fridayi. Using social media, Oury was able to spread the word and the governor of Arkansas, Governor Hutchinson, signed a document that officially made the Arkansaurus fridayi the state dinosaur in 2017.\n\nWithout further ado, here are the [state symbols](https://www.infoplease.com/us/states/state-symbols) of the United States of America. Taxes are used to fund a number of public expenditures, such as roads, public transportation, education, and others. When expenditures exceed tax revenue, the government goes into debt.\r\n\r\nTaxes have two effects:\r\n\r\n-\tAn income effect because they reduce purchasing power to taxpayers (income tax)\r\n-\tA substitution effect when taxes cause a substitution between taxed goods and untaxed goods (sales tax)\r\n\r\nFederal income tax is the tax levied by the United States Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on the earnings of individuals and legal entities. However, most states collect state income and sales taxes in addition to the federal income tax. State taxes are given little attention compared to federal income taxes.\r\n\r\nStates take one of three approaches when it comes to state income taxes:\r\n\r\n-\tThe state does not collect income tax\r\n-\tThe state imposes a flat tax, taxing all income (or only dividends and interest) at the same rate\r\n-\tThe state imposes a progressive tax which taxes higher income at higher rates\r\n\r\nFirst, there are seven states that do not collect a state income tax. While these states do not have an additional income tax, other taxes, such as property or sales taxes, could be higher in these states. The seven states are:\r\n\r\n-\tAlaska\r\n-\tFlorida\r\n-\tNevada\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tTexas\r\n-\tWashington\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nSecond, there are eleven states with flat income tax rates. In New Hampshire and Tennessee, the tax rate applies to dividends and interest income and regular income is typically not subject to state tax. These states are:\r\n\r\n-\tColorado (4.63%)\r\n-\tIllinois (4.95%)\r\n-\tIndiana (3.23%)\r\n-\tKentucky (5%)\r\n-\tMassachusetts (5.05%)\r\n-\tMichigan (4.25%)\r\n-\tNew Hampshire (5%)\r\n-\tNorth Carolina (5.25%)\r\n-\tPennsylvania (3.07%)\r\n-\tTennessee (2%)\r\n-\tUtah (4.95%)\r\n\r\nThe remaining states and the District of Columbia have state income tax brackets. The higher an individualâs income, the higher the tax bracket he/she will be placed into. California has the highest potential state income tax bracket of 13%.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table with each stateâs lowest and highest state income tax bracket. largest state by area in the United States of America? Here is a list of the top ten biggest states by size:\n\n1. Alaska (Total area: 665,384 square miles)\n2. Texas (Total area: 268,596 square miles)\n3. California (Total area: 163,696 square miles)\n4. Montana (Total area: 147,040 square miles)\n5. New Mexico (Total area: 121,590 square miles)\n6. Arizona (Total area: 113,990 square miles)\n7. Nevada (Total area: 110,572 square miles)\n8. Colorado (Total area: 104,094 square miles)\n9. Oregon (Total area: 98,379 square miles)\n10. Wyoming (Total area: 97,813 square miles)\n\nThe United States has a diverse climate, and this reflected in the landscape of the country. Not surprisingly, Alaska and Texas are the largest states by area, although Alaska, at 665,384 miÂ², is substantially larger than Texas at 268,596 miÂ². Alaska is made up of 85.76% land, while water covers an area of 94,743 miÂ² (the highest in the US). However, the much dryer southern state of Texas consists of 97.26 miÂ² of land and has only 7,365 miÂ² of water. Other states with arid climates are similar: New Mexico and Arizona are almost entirely comprised of land (99.76% and 99.65%, respectively) with very little water.\n\nMany states have large areas of water. These include the states of Michigan (40,175 miÂ²) and Wisconsin (11,339 miÂ²) in the Great Lakes region of the northern US, and the humid Gulf States of Florida (12,133 miÂ²) and Louisiana (9,174 miÂ²). There are of course many other states that may not have vast areas of water within the state, but which are Ocean-facing (such as Georgia), as well as states that have small areas of water in terms of percentage, but the numbers simply reflect the size of the state itself (for example, tiny Rhode Island with its 511 miÂ² of water).\n\nThe smallest states by area are of course the District of Columbia at just 68 miÂ² and Rhode Island at 1,545 miÂ². Interestingly, there are only a handful of tiny states; Delaware, Connecticut, New Jersey, New Hampshire, and Vermont are the only other states with a total area of under 10,000 miÂ² and the numbers increase significantly from that point onwards, emphasizing just how large the United States as a country is.\n","frontmatter":{"title":"United States by Area","date":"2018-11-8","description":"Areas of the United States"},"data":{"customMeta":{"columns":["state","totalArea","area","waterArea","density","population"],"sortField":"TotalArea","sortAsc":false,"showAllstates":true}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:26.812Z","path":"states-by-area","name":"States By Area"},{"article":"The United States of America was established in July 1776 when the first 13 states â then known as individual colonies â agreed to the United States Declaration of Independence. The first state to join the union was Delaware, which ratified the 1787 Constitution (which created the federal union of states that exists today) on December 7, 1787. Pennsylvania closely followed it on December 7, 1787, and New Jersey on December 18, 1787. A further ten states along the eastern seaboard made up the original 13 states of the United States of America â Rhode Island was the last of these to join in May 1790.  \n\nOver the next 20 years, a further 11 states joined the union, including Ohio (1803), Louisiana (1812), and Maine (1820). There was then a gap of 15 years before the next state joined â this was Arkansas in June 1836. Two of today's most populous states, Texas and California, joined in 1845 and 1850, respectively. By the end of the 19th century, the majority of the states that make up the current union had joined. Utah was the last 19th-century state to join in January 1896.\n\nThroughout the 20th century, only a further five states would join the union. These were Oklahoma in November 1907, New Mexico in January 1912, and Arizona in February 1912, while Alaska and Hawaii â the only two non-continental states â joined as recently as 1959, taking the total number of states in the union to 50. Today, Americans are citizens of both the state in which they live as well as the Federal Republic of the United States. Interestingly, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Kentucky continue to use the term 'commonwealth' rather than state in their full official names.\n","frontmatter":{"title":"United States by Statehood","date":"2018-11-8","description":"Information on the statehood dates of various states."},"data":{"customMeta":{"columns":["state","statehoodYear"],"sortField":"StatehoodYear","sortAsc":true,"showAllstates":true,"chloroMap":{"field":"StatehoodYear"}}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:26.812Z","path":"states-by-statehood","name":"States By Statehood"},{"article":"Military retirement pay based on age or length of service is considered a taxable income for Federal income taxes and state income taxes in some states. Both military disability retirement pay and veteranâs benefits, including service-connected disability pension payments, are typically excluded from taxable income. \r\n\r\nUnderstanding military retirement income taxes helps one better plan their retirement years, as these taxes can have a large impact on oneâs financial plans and goals. \r\n\r\nGenerally, in order to be eligible for military retirement benefits, one needs to serve for 20 years. Military retirement pay is not considered earned income and no Social Security is withheld. \r\n\r\nLaws vary greatly between states. Some states do not tax military retirement pay, and some states have specific tax exemption, such as exempting taxation up to a certain amount or being exempt depending on age or year of retirement. In Arizona, for example, up to $2,500 in military retirement pay can be exempted from taxable income. In Kentucky, military pensions are fully exempt if the person retired before 1997.\r\n\r\nThe states can be divided into four categories: no state income tax; exempts military pension income from state taxes; offers special tax treatments for military pensions, and treats military retirement pay as ordinary taxable income. \r\n\r\nThe following states have state income tax but exempt military retirement pay:\r\n\r\n-\tAlabama\r\n-\tArkansas\r\n-\tConnecticut\r\n-\tHawaii\r\n-\tIllinois\r\n-\tIowa After nearly a lifetime of work, many Americans get to finally cash in on their retirement plan, like a pension plan. \n \nA pension plan is a type of retirement plan that is made up of contributions from the employer. In some cases, the employee may also be able to contribute to the plan, and the employer can make these funds up to a set limit or certain percentage. \n \nA pension plan assures a person that he or she will be able to have an income following retirement. Unfortunately, though, in many states, pension funds can be taxed just like ordinary income. \n \nLaws vary from state to state regarding how pensions are taxed. In some cases, at least a portion is taxed based on the amount of money in the plan and the age of the retiree. However, in other states, pensions arenât taxed at all. Letâs take a look at the states that donât tax pensions. \n \n- Alabama: This state doesnât tax pension income from defined benefit retirement plans. \n- Alaska: Because Alaska doesnât have an income tax, you wonât pay taxes on your pension or other income. \n- Florida: Like Alaska, Florida doesnât have an income tax, so your pension will not be taxed. \n- Hawaii: Public and private pensions arenât taxed in Hawaii with one exception. Any portion that you contributed will be taxed. \n- Illinois: Private pensions from qualified employee benefit plans are exempt from taxation in Illinois. \n- Mississippi: Pensions used after the age of 59.5 are not taxed in Mississippi. \n- Nevada: No income tax in Nevada means that your pension will not be taxed after retirement. \n- New Hampshire: New Hampshire is another state with no income taxes, so there is no tax on pension income. There is, however, taxes on interest and dividends. \n- Pennsylvania: The only time pensions are taxed in this state is when you retire early. \n- South Dakota: There are no income taxes in the state of South Dakota. \n- Tennessee: Taxes are only paid on interest and dividends in this state, not on pensions. \n- Texas: No personal income tax means that Texans can hold onto their pension funds. \n- Washington: Washington is another state without an income tax. \n- Wyoming: Like many other states on this list, Wyoming does not have an income tax. \n\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Alaska","Florida","Hawaii","Illinois","Mississippi","Nevada","New Hampshire","Pennsylvania","South Dakota","Tennessee","Texas","Washington","Wyoming"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["alcohol-tax-by-state","corporate-tax-rates-by-state","income-tax-by-state","sales-tax-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-pensions","states-with-lowest-taxes","taxes-on-lottery-winnings-by-state","capital-gains-tax-by-state","gas-taxes-by-state","property-taxes-by-state","state-tax-rates","states-that-tax-social-security","states-with-no-income-tax","tax-burden-by-state","car-sales-tax-by-state","highest-taxed-states","retirement-taxes-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-military-retirement","states-with-internet-sales-tax",{"link":"states-without-property-tax","title":"States With No Property Tax"},"taxes-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"14 States That Wonât Tax Your Pension","link":"https://www.kiplinger.com/slideshow/taxes/T054-S001-14-states-that-won-t-tax-your-pension/index.html"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"states-that-dont-tax-pensions","name":"States That Dont Tax Pensions"},{"article":"The Affordable Care Act that was enacted in 2010 under former United States President Barack Obama was designed to give more Americans access to affordable healthcare. Under this expansion, households with incomes up to 133% of the federal poverty level would be eligible to receive Medicaid benefits, which provides free healthcare services. \n\nUnfortunately, this isnât universal across all of the states. As of early 2019, a total of 36 states plus Washington, D.C., have received federal funds to expand Medicaid. Additional states are expected to follow suit by the end of 2019. Some states are even working to make changes to the Medicaid program, including buy-in programs and putting lifetime caps in place. \n\nRepublican lawmakers pushed for Medicaid work requirements. This means that a person on Medicaid must be working, in school, volunteering, or participating in job training. A total of eight states have received approval from the federal government for work requirements, while other states have put in waivers or may submit them in the future. Work requirements must be approved by the government and vary by state. \n\nAs of June 2019, the states that have adopted Medicaid expansion are: \n\n- Alaska\n- Arizona\n- Arkansas\n- California\n- Colorado\n- Connecticut \n- Delaware\n- Hawaii\n- Idaho\n- Illinois\n- Indiana\n- Iowa\n- Kentucky\n- Louisiana\n- Maine\n- Maryland\n- Massachusetts \n- Michigan\n- Minnesota\n- Montana\n- Nebraska\n- Nevada\n- New Hampshire\n- New Jersey\n- New Mexico\n- New York\n- North Dakota\n- Ohio\n- Oregon\n- Pennsylvania\n- Rhode Island\n- Vermont\n- Virginia\n- Washington\n- Washington, D.C. \n- West Virginia\n\n","data":{"states":["Alaska","Arizona","Arkansas","California","Colorado","Connecticut","Delaware","Hawaii","Idaho","Illinois","Indiana","Iowa","Kentucky","Louisiana","Maine","Maryland","Massachusetts","Michigan","Minnesota","Montana","Nebraska","Nevada","New Hampshire","New Jersey","New Mexico","New York","North Dakota","Ohio","Oregon","Pennsylvania","Rhode Island","Vermont","Virginia","Washington","Washington DC","West Virginia"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["federal-aid-by-state","medicaid-enrollment-by-state","medicaid-income-limits-by-state","states-that-expanded-medicaid","welfare-recipients-by-state","unemployment-benefits-by-state","unemployment-rate-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Status of State Medicaid Expansion Decisions: Interactive Map","link":"https://www.kff.org/medicaid/issue-brief/status-of-state-medicaid-expansion-decisions-interactive-map/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"states-that-expanded-medicaid","name":"States That Expanded Medicaid"},{"article":"Any adult living in the United States knows about paying taxes. We pay taxes to the federal government on our income, and we also pay income taxes in our state too, depending on where we live. We pay taxes on our homes, and we may also have to pay taxes on our vehicles. We pay taxes on the items we purchase, and in some states, a gas tax is also applied. \n \nSocial Security benefits are also taxable. Across the nation, up to 85% of your benefits can be taxed by the federal government. In some states, a state tax is also applied. \n \nOf the 50 states, 13 states tax Social Security benefits. Those states are: \n \n- Colorado\n- Connecticut\n- Kansas\n- Minnesota\n- Missouri\n- Montana\n- Nebraska\n- New Mexico\n- North Dakota\n- Rhode Island\n- Utah\n- Vermont\n- West Virginia\n \nIf you live in one of these states or planned to move to one of these states for retirement, this extra tax on Social Security benefits may throw up a red flag. However, many of the states on this list have been ranked as some of the most tax-friendly states for retirees when considering other types of state taxes, including sales tax, property tax, estate tax, and inheritance tax. \n\n","data":{"states":["Colorado","Connecticut","Kansas","Minnesota","Missouri","Montana","Nebraska","New Mexico","North Dakota","Rhode Island","Utah","Vermont","West Virginia"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["alcohol-tax-by-state","corporate-tax-rates-by-state","income-tax-by-state","sales-tax-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-pensions","states-with-lowest-taxes","taxes-on-lottery-winnings-by-state","capital-gains-tax-by-state","gas-taxes-by-state","property-taxes-by-state","state-tax-rates","states-that-tax-social-security","states-with-no-income-tax","tax-burden-by-state","car-sales-tax-by-state","highest-taxed-states","retirement-taxes-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-military-retirement","states-with-internet-sales-tax",{"link":"states-without-property-tax","title":"States With No Property Tax"},"taxes-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Which states tax Social Security benefits?","link":"https://www.aarp.org/retirement/social-security/questions-answers/which-states-do-not-tax-social-security-benefits.html"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"states-that-tax-social-security","name":"States That Tax Social Security"},{"article":"Rainwater harvesting is the accumulation and storage of rainwater, rather than allowing it to run off, in order to reuse it for on-site purposes. Simply installing a system in oneâs home makes it easy to utilize Earthâs hydrological cycle and allowing people to collect rainwater on their own properties reduces the demand from water facilities and improves conservation efforts.\n\nThe Federal Government does not have any laws or restrictions regarding rainwater harvesting. Most states allow citizens to collect rainwater, and even encourage them to do so. Rhode Island, Texas, and Virginia encourage residents to collect rainwater by offering a tax credit or exemption for equipment purchased for rainwater harvesting.\n\nSome states currently have restrictions on the amount of rainwater that can be collected and the method by which it is collected; however, it is not entirely illegal to collect rainwater in any of the 50 states.\n\nA reason for some of these restrictions is the belief that the harvesting would disrupt rainâs natural flow back into streams and bodies of water on the Earth. The amount of rainwater collected by individual homes, according to a study by the Scientific World Journal, would have little to no effect on the hydrological cycle, especially because homeowners would use this water for their yards or gardens, so it would return back to the Earth.\n\nIn Western states, restrictions exist because old water laws stated that all precipitation belonged to existing water-rights owners. These laws were known as prior appropriation, or âfirst-come, first serveâ laws for settlers in the Old West.\n\nRainwater harvesting poses a health problem, as some water may be unsafe and not suitable for potable purposes (i.e. drinking). This is something legislators must take into consideration.\n\nBelow is a list of rainwater harvesting laws for each state.\n\n## Alabama\n\nRainwater harvesting is considered a private property right. There are no current regulations for rainwater harvesting.\n\n## Alaska\n\nRainwater harvesting is unrestricted as it is the primary source of water for many residents. Groundwater harvesting is regulated and can be purchased as a water right.\n\n## Arizona\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal. House Bill 2830 allows cities and towns to establish a fund for rainwater harvesting systems.\n\n## Arkansas\n\nRainwater harvesting is allowed with some minor restrictions. The Arkansas Code Annotated Rainwater Â§ 17-38-201 states that harvested rainwater can be used for non-potable purposes if the harvesting system is designed by a professional engineer licensed in Arkansas, is designed with appropriate cross-connection safeguards, and complies with Arkansas Plumbing Code.\n\n## California\n\nThe Rainwater Capture Act of 2012 states that residential, commercial and governmental landowners may install, maintain, and operate rainwater capture systems for specified purposes.\n\n## Colorado\n\nAccording to House Bill 16-1005, residents are allowed to collect rainwater in two rain barrels with a combined capacity of 110 gallons. The collected water can only be used on the property where it was collected and for outdoor purposes.\n\n## Connecticut\n\nThere are no restrictions on rainwater harvesting, and the stateâs citizens are encouraged to collect rainwater.\n\n## Delaware\n\nThere are no restrictions on rainwater harvesting. Delaware sponsors incentive programs encouraging rainwater harvesting.\n\n## Florida\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions in Florida, and it is highly encouraged by the state. Several local municipalities encourage rainwater harvesting with tax incentives and rebate programs.\n\n## Georgia\n\nRainwater harvesting must be used for outdoor purposes only, and is closely regulated by the Department of Natural Resources in the Environmental Protection Division.\n\n## Hawaii\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions, and rainwater harvesting is highly encouraged.\n\n## Idaho\n\nResidents can capture rainwater and diffused surface waters on their own property as long as it does not cause injury to the existing water rights of others and is not rainwater that has entered natural waterways.\n\n## Illinois\n\nRainwater harvesting is highly regulated in Illinois. Plumbing-Rainwater Systems Bill SB0038 states that collected rainwater collected can only be used for non-potable purposes and rainwater-harvesting systems must be constructed in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code.\n\n## Indiana\n\nThere are no restrictions or regulations on rainwater harvesting and it is highly encouraged by the state.\n\n## Iowa\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions or regulations.\n\n## Kansas\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal, and no permit is needed if the water is used for domestic purposes such as household use, watering livestock on pasture, or for lawns and gardens.\n\n## Kentucky\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions or regulations.\n\n## Louisiana\n\nRainwater collection is legal, but state statutes require covers for large collection tanks (cisterns).\n\n## Maine\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions or regulations.\n\n## Maryland\n\nThere are no rainwater harvesting restrictions or regulations. Some counties offer incentives for rainwater collection.\n\n## Massachusetts\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Michigan\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Minnesota\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Mississippi\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n\n## Missouri\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Montana\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Nebraska\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and promoted by several universities in the state.\n\n## Nevada\n\nNB74 allows for rainwater collection under the grant of a water right, which must be used for intended purposes or risk being revoked. Assembly Bill 198 states that the Legislative Committee on Public lands will review alternative sources of water, including rainwater harvesting.\n\n## New Hampshire\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## New Jersey\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal. Assembly Bill 2442 requires the Department of Environmental Protection to establish a Capture, Control, and Conserve Reward Rebate Program for property owners who use eligible techniques on their properties.\n\n## New Mexico\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## New York\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal, encouraged and taught in New York.\n\n## North Carolina\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal with two laws regulating it. House Bill 609 states that the Department of Environment and Natural Resources will provide statewide assistance and ensure best management practices for water reuse and rainwater harvesting. Senate Bill 163 recognizes the benefit of harvesting rainwater the for stateâs future water supply.\n\n## North Dakota\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Ohio\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal for both non-potable and potable uses, as long as the water system is providing drinking water to fewer than 25 people (Ohio Rev. Code Â§3701.344).\n\n## Oklahoma\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal. The Water for 2060 Act initiates grants for water conservation projects, such as campaigns for harvesting rainwater.\n\n## Oregon\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal, but rainwater can only be collected from systems on rooftop surfaces.\n\n## Pennsylvania\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## Rhode Island\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and citizens are provided incentives for harvesting. House Bill 7070 gives a tax credit for 10% of the cost of installing a cistern to individuals or businesses who do.\n\n## South Carolina\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal and encouraged.\n\n## South Dakota\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n\n## Tennessee\n\nThe enactment of Senate Bill 2417/ House Bill 1850 allows for the use of green infrastructure practices, making rainwater harvesting legal.\n\n## Texas\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal with some regulations. House Bill 3391 states that the collection system needs to be incorporated into the design of the building and a written notice needs to be given to the municipality.\n\n## Utah\n\nRainwater harvested is allowed on land owned or leased by the person responsible for the collection. Additional regulations exist, according to Senate Bill 32, depending on if a person is registered with the Division of Water Resources or not. A person who is registered may store no more than 2,500 gallons of rainwater, and a person who is unregistered may use no more than two containers at 100 gallons or less per container.\n\n## Vermont\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n\n## Virginia\n\nSenate Bill 1416 grants an income tax credit to citizens who install rainwater-harvesting systems. Virginia Code Â§32.1-248.2 states that The Department of the state, in conjunction with the Department of Environmental Quality, shall promote the use of rainwater to help reduce fresh water consumption, promote conservation and reduce demand on water supply systems.\n\n## Washington\n\nRainwater collection is legal. A water permit is not required for rooftop harvesting systems.\n\n## West Virginia\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n\n## Wisconsin\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n\n## Wyoming\n\nRainwater harvesting is legal.\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Legal Virginia","legality":"Legal"},{"state":"Wisconsin","legality":"Legal"},{"state":"Wyoming","legality":"Legal"}]},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.172Z","path":"states-where-it-is-illegal-to-collect-rainwater","name":"States Where It Is Illegal To Collect Rainwater"},{"article":"What states have Internet sales tax?\r\n\r\nInternet sales tax is a tax on Internet-based services. For many years, states argued that they were losing money by not being able to collect sales tax on Internet sales. On June 21, 2018, the US Supreme Court changed the rules for collection of sales tax by Internet-based retailers stating that individual states can require online sellers to collect state sales tax.\r\n\r\nAny individual who sells products online should be aware of the different laws in different states. The provisions set by the states are called âRemote Seller Nexusâ and vary between states. There are four different types of Nexus according to the [Sales Tax Institute](https://www.salestaxinstitute.com/resources/remote-seller-nexus-chart):\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus requires that if a seller contracts with an individual or company in-state who refers potential customers to the retailer for a commission, the retailer is considered to have a place of business in that state.\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus states an affiliated person of the retailer with a physical presence, or employees or agents in-state, has sufficient nexus in state to require the retailer to collect and remit sales and use taxable retail sales of tangible personal property or services.\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus requires the marketplace facilitator to register and collect tax as a retailer if the online marketplace operates in a state and provides e-commerce infrastructure including customer service, payment processing services and marketing. \r\n-\tEconomic Nexus requires an out-of-state retailer to collect sales tax once the retailer meets a certain level of sales transactions or gross receipts activity within the state. The retailer does not need to have a physical presence in that state.\r\n\r\nAdditionally, there are Notice and Reporting Requirements, which require retailers to notify buyers that they must pay and report state use tax on purchases. \r\n\r\nThe following states do not have an Internet sales tax:\r\n\r\n-\tAlaska\r\n-\tDelaware\r\n-\tNew Hampshire\r\n-\tMontana\r\n-\tOregon\r\n\r\nBelow are each stateâs enacted Internet sales tax provisions. Proposed legislation is not included.\r\n\r\n# Internet Sales Tax Provisions by State\r\n## Alabama\r\n\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus\r\n-\tReporting Requirements\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $250,000 or more)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Alaska\r\n\r\n-\tNo current state sales tax.\r\n\r\n\r\n## Arizona\r\n\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (current threshold of $200,000; $150,000 in 2020; and $100,000 in 2021 forward)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Arkansas\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus (repealed effective 6/30/2019)\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus (repealed effective 6/30/2019)\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## California\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus (repealed effective 4/1/2019)\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus (repealed effective 4/1/2019)\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $500,000)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Colorado\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus (repealed effective 6/1/2019)\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus (repealed effective 4/1/2019)\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Connecticut\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus \r\n-\tReporting Requirements\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $250,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Delaware\r\n\r\n-\tNo current state sales tax.\r\n\r\n## District of Columbia\r\n\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Florida \r\n\r\n-\tNo provisions. The law in Florida predates the Wayfair case. Section 212.06 of Floridaâs sales tax law requires âany personâ¦ who maintains or has within [Florida], directly or by a subsidiary, an office, distributing house, salesroom, or house, warehouse, or other place of businessâ to pay sales tax.\r\n\r\n## Georgia\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus\r\n-\tReporting Requirements (repealed effective 4/28/2019)\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n\r\n## Hawaii\r\n\r\n-\tReporting Requirements\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Idaho\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus \r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Illinois\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus (repealed effective 6/28/2019)\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus (repealed effective 6/28/2019)\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Indiana\r\n\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Iowa\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus\r\n-\tReporting Requirements\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n-\tMarketplace Nexus\r\n\r\n## Kansas\r\n\r\n-\tClick-Through Nexus\r\n-\tAffiliate Nexus\r\n-\tEconomic Nexus (threshold of $100,000 or at least 200 separate transactions)\r\n\r\n\r\n## Kentucky\r\n\r\n-\tReporting Internet Sales Tax"},{"article":"Letâs face it: everyday life can be expensive. Weâre not talking about taking extravagant trips, purchasing your childrenâs Christmas gifts, or even facing an emergency like a broken down car. Weâre talking about everyday life.\n\nThe cost of living takes into account several necessary expenses that most of us need to live from day to day. The cost of living includes housing, food, childcare, and educational costs, transportation costs, and medical costs.\n\nDepending on where you live in the world, your cost of living varies. Even within the United States, the cost of living varies from state to state. Living in New York City, for example, is far more expensive than living in a rural town in Nebraska. The price of a 3,000-square-feet home with an inground swimming pool in a small town may be the same price as a studio apartment in a big city. This example shows the differences in the cost of living.\n\nDetermining the states with the lowest cost of living can be difficult. This is because many different factors could be used. For example, one list may include childcare costs, while another leaves this off completely. However, there are a few reputable publications and organizations that have compiled data to find the states with the lowest cost of living.\n\n## Ten States with the Lowest Cost of Living\n\n#### 1. Mississippi\n\nMississippi has the lowest cost out of living of all 50 states. Mississippiâs cost of living index is 86.1. Mississippi has the lowest housing costs in the country, with the average home price at $128,000 ad the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment at $746 per month. With the lowest cost of living in the country comes the lowest median household income of $43,567 per year. \n\n#### 2. Arkansas\n\nThe state with the second-lowest cost of living is Arkansas. Arkansas has a cost of living index of 86.9, with housing, transportation, and healthcare costs all being significantly lower than the national average. To live comfortably in Arkansas, one would need to make only $44,571 for a family, which is just below the median household income of $45,726. \n\n#### 3. Oklahoma\n\nOklahoma has the third-lowest cost of living in the United States. Oklahomaâs housing costs are also very low, with the average two-bedroom apartment costing $879 per month and the median home value equaling $130,001. Oklahoma also has low transportation costs, with regular gasoline costing $2.262 per gallon as of January 2020, the second-lowest in the country. The living wage in Oklahoma is $46,159 and the median household income is $51,424. \n\n#### 4. Missouri\n\nMissouri has the fourth-lowest overall cost of living. Missouriâs housing index is only 70.6, with the second-lowest average rent in the country for a two-bedroom apartment of $827 per month. Missouri has the lowest gas prices of any state, with regular gasoline costing $2.209 per gallon as of January 2020. The livable wage in Missouri for a family of four is $53,078, which would just be covered by the stateâs median household income of $53,560. \n\n#### 5. New Mexico \n\nNew Mexico has the fifth-lowest cost of living in the United States with a cost of living index of 87.5. New Mexicoâs low cost of living is greatly influenced by its low housing costs, with a median home value of $193,200 and the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment costs $847 per month. A monthly utility bill is also below-average in New Mexico. New Mexicoâs median household income is $48,059.\n\n#### 6. Tennessee\n\nTennessee has the sixth-lowest cost of living in the United States. Tennessee has a livable wage of $46,785. Tennesseeâs housing index is 72.5, the fifth-lowest in the country. One can expect to pay about $854 per month on average for a two-bedroom apartment with some upward variation in cities such as Chattanooga and Knoxville. Monthly utility bills and healthcare costs come out to right around the national average. The median annual income in Tennessee is $50,972.\n\n#### 7. Michigan\n\nThe state with the seventh-lowest cost of living is Michigan, with an index of 89.6. The median home price in Michigan is $151,400 and the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment is $885 per month. While housing is very affordable and 70% of residents own a home, Michigan has the ninth-highest property tax rate of 1.71%. Utilities and healthcare costs are slightly below the U.S. average and grocery costs are about the same as the U.S. average. The livable wage in Michigan is $48,882 and the median household income is $54,938. \n\n#### 8. Kansas \n\nKansas has the eighth-lowest cost of living in the U.S. Kansas is tied with Tennessee for housing costs with an index of 72.5. The median home cost in Kansas is about $137,700 and the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment is $821 per month. Kansas has relatively low transportation costs, with regular gasoline costing $2.278 per gallon as of January 2020, the third-lowest price in the U.S. The livable wage in Kansas is $48,054 and the median household income is $57,422.\n\n#### 9. Georgia\n\nGeorgia ranks ninth for the lowest cost of living in the U.S. Georgiaâs housing index is 72.2, with the median home price at $186,500 and the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment at $958. Rent increases significantly in cities such as Atlanta, Savannah, Augustus, and Columbus. While transportation and grocery costs are slightly below average, Georgia residents pay a slightly above average utility bill of about $126.38 on average. The livable wage in Georgia is $47,946 and the median household income is $55,679.\n\n#### 10. Alabama\n\nAlabama finishes the top ten states with the lowest cost of living. Alabamaâs housing index is only 69.9. The median home price in Alabama is $129,300 and the average rent for a two-bedroom apartment is $772 per month. Alabama is one of the best states for retirement because it offers beaches, golf, and warm weather but is significantly cheaper than Florida. The livable wage in Alabama is $45,824 and the median household income is $48,486. Of Living"},{"article":"Weâve all heard the adage, âNothing is certain except death and taxes.â We all know that we have to pay taxes if we live in the United States, but did you know that some states have lower tax rates than others? Some states also may eliminate certain taxes, but often, theyâre merely paying more in other types of taxes.\n\nAdult citizens in the United States pay a variety of different taxes. We pay taxes to the federal government. We also pay local and state taxes. It isnât just your annual state tax return, either. We pay property taxes, sales taxes, and other taxes that help fund things like schools, roads, and critical infrastructure.\n\nBecause there are so many different types of taxes, there isnât just one list of states with the lowest tax rates. For example, property tax in one state may be much lower but personal income tax may be much higher. But we can break down the states with the lowest taxes based on tax type.\n\n In 2018, it was found that Louisiana had the lowest property tax rate at 0.18%. Hawaii came in second with a property tax rate of 0.26%. Alabama has the third-lowest property taxes at 0.33%.\n\nThe top 10 states with the lowest property tax rates in 2018 were:\n\n- Louisiana\n- Hawaii\n- Alabama\n- Delaware\n- District of Columbia\n- West Virginia\n- South Carolina\n- Arkansas\n- Mississippi\n- New Mexico\n\nWhen it comes to states with the lowest personal income tax rates, there are several that top the list because they have no personal income tax. Those states are:\n\n- Alaska\n- Florida\n- Nevada\n- South Dakota\n- Texas\n- Washington\n- Wyoming\n- Tennessee and New Hampshire also do not charge taxes on income from wages. However, interest and dividend income are taxed.\n\nWhen it comes to sales tax, five states do not have charge sales tax. Those states are:\n\n- Alaska\n- Delaware\n- Montana\n- New Hampshire\n- Oregon\n\nItâs important to note that local municipalities in Montana and Alaska can impose a sales tax.\n\nThe organization Tax Foundation released a report in 2018 that evaluated local taxes to determine which states were the most tax-friendly. There are many people for the legalization of medical marijuana, pointing to its health benefits, its natural properties, and how it can replace dangerous prescription medications. On the other side, there are opponents to legalizing medical marijuana, with most people stating that itâs an addictive drug that can lead to other, harder drugs.\n\nNo matter what your personal feelings are on the subject, some states are moving forward with the legalization of medical marijuana. In these states, medical-grade marijuana can be prescribed by a doctor to patients experiencing anything from seizures to nerve pain, glaucoma, or even cancer.\n\nWhatâs interesting about medical marijuana is how it can be administered. While most people immediately think of smoking marijuana, this isnât the only way it can be administered. There are capsules, patches, sprays, oils, and lozenges available to help a patient with their symptoms.\n\nAs of January 2019, a total of 33 states plus Washington, D.C., have legalized medical marijuana.
