health care, and other programs.\n\nHow is this money raised? It is typically raised through taxes. Most states tax the wages of its residents with a state income tax. However, some states do not have a state income tax, although residents do have to pay federal taxes.\n\nWhile living in a state with no taxes sounds great, itâs important to note that these states still have to raise revenue. This means that taxes in other areas â such as sales tax or property tax â are much higher for residents.\n\nIn the United States, there are currently seven states that do not have a state income tax. These states are:\n\n1. Alaska\n2. Florida\n3. Nevada\n4. South Dakota\n5. Texas\n6. Washington\n7. Wyoming\n\nSome states, such as Washington, have never had a personal income tax. Other states, such as Alaska, have repealed laws in recent years that require citizens to pay state income taxes.\n\nIn some states, other types of taxes are used to replace the individual income tax. In Florida, for example, residents have to pay sales taxes, higher property taxes, and corporate income taxes.\n\nThese arenât the only states that donât tax wages. Both Tennessee and New Hampshire do not have a personal income tax. However, these states do tax some dividends and interest. In Tennessee, the income tax rate on investment income is being reduced until the year 2022, when it will be eliminated. In the state of New Hampshire, there are not only no income taxes or sales taxes, but there are excise taxes. violence in the United States has been a controversial topic, particularly in recent years. Some citizens and politicians push for gun control, while others believe that the countryâs laws surrounding guns should remain the same. One law that is particularly controversial is the âstand your groundâ law. \n\nStand your ground laws allow a person to use force if necessary if there is a threat of harm. Many self-defense laws state that a person that believes they are being threatened with personal injury has a duty to retreat. If there is a continued threat after leaving, the threatened person is permitted to use force to defend themselves. In stand your ground states, there is no duty to retreat. \n\nFor example, a robber comes into the home of a person who is sleeping. The person awakens and investigates the noises and is met by the robber, who is holding a gun. In states with stand your ground laws, the threatened person could respond with force â including using their own gun, if one is owned â if necessary. A person that defends themselves in such a situation would not have to worry about criminal prosecution. \n\nOpponents of stand your ground laws often believe that such laws can be dangerous. For example, a person could shoot first when there isnât a real threat. One such instance was the case against George Zimmerman, who faced criminal charges following the shooting death of Trayvon Martin. Zimmerman was later acquitted of the charges. \n\nThere are several states that have adopted stand your ground laws. Those states are: \n\n- Alabama\n- Alaska\n- Arizona\n- Florida\n- Georgia\n- Idaho\n- Indiana\n- Iowa\n- Kansas\n- Kentucky\n- Louisiana\n- Michigan\n- Mississippi\n- Missouri\n- Montana\n- Nevada\n- New Hampshire\n- North Carolina\n- Oklahoma\n- Pennsylvania\n- South Carolina\n- South Dakota\n- Tennessee\n- Texas\n- Utah\n- West Virginia\n- Wyoming\n\nSome states use stand your ground in practice, such as through jury instructions or case law. These states are: \n\nCalifornia\nColorado\nIllinois\nNew Mexico\nOregon\nVirginia\nWashington\n\nSome states have also adopted stand your ground laws, but these laws only apply when a person is in their vehicle. These states are: \n\nNorth Dakota\nOhio\nWisconsin\n\nFinally, there are states with castle doctrine, which allows a person to defend themselves using force while in the home or their vehicles, but have a duty to retreat in public places. These states are: \n\nArkansas\nConnecticut\nDelaware\nMaine\nMaryland\nMassachusetts\nMinnesota\nNebraska\nNew York\nNew Jersey\nRhode Island\n\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Alaska","Arizona","Florida","Georgia","Idaho","Indiana","Iowa","Kansas","Kentucky","Louisiana","Michigan","Mississippi","Missouri","Montana","Nevada","New Hampshire","North Carolina","Oklahoma","Pennsylvania","South Carolina","South Dakota","Tennessee","Texas","Utah","West Virginia","Wyoming"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-laws-by-state","blue-laws-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","clothing-laws-by-state","common-law-marriage-states","filial-responsibility-laws-by-state","final-paycheck-laws-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","helmet-law-states","homeschool-laws-by-state","incest-laws-by-state","late-fee-laws-by-state","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","marijuana-laws-by-state","mushroom-laws-by-state","pepper-spray-laws-by-state","seat-belt-laws-by-state","states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","tiny-house-laws-by-state","voter-id-laws-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Self Defense and âStand Your Ground","link":"http://www.ncsl.org/research/civil-and-criminal-justice/self-defense-and-stand-your-ground.aspx"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","name":"States With Stand Your Ground Laws"},{"article":"Climate preferences are highly personal. Some people prefer cold weather, some prefer hot, and some like it right in the middle. Some people prefer to have all four seasons â fall, winter, spring and summer â and all of the weather that comes with each. Other people would love for it to be summer all year round.\r\n\r\nIf someone is looking to move to a new state, for a vacation spot, or for a location to retire, itâs helpful to know which states in the US have the best weather year-round.\r\n\r\nThis type of information can be especially helpful for individuals who suffer from Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD). SAD is a type of depression that is affected by the seasons, typically starting in the fall and lasting through the winter, and then going away during the spring and summer. Those looking to relocate who are affected by SAD will most likely want to find a home where the weather is favorable and warm all year.\r\n\r\nWhat states have the best weather? When evaluating each state for temperature, rain, and sun, some states stand out. Although climate and weather preferences are personal and subjective, some criteria are considered to make up the best weather, according to [Current Results](https://www.currentresults.com/Weather/top-10-us-states-with-best-weather.php):\r\n\r\n-\tComfortable temperatures from 63Â°F to 86Â°F for more than half of the year.\r\n-\tDry weather with no more than 60 inches of rain per year.\r\n-\tMostly clear skies with an average of sunshine for at least 60% of the year.\r\n\r\nBased on these criteria, California has the best weather of all 50 states. Coastal cities in south and central California, such as San Diego, Los Angeles, Long Beach, and Santa Barbara, experience only 20 inches of rain per year and temperatures typically between the low 60s and 85 degrees. Los Angeles reports sunshine for 73% of the year. \r\n\r\nThe ten states in the US with the best weather are:\r\n\r\n1.\tCalifornia\r\n2.\tHawaii\r\n3.\tTexas\r\n4.\tArizona\r\n5.\tFlorida\r\n6.\tGeorgia\r\n7.\tSouth Carolina\r\n8.\tDelaware\r\n9.\tNorth Carolina\r\n10.\tLouisiana\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["best-states-for-education","best-states-for-gun-owners","best-states-for-teachers","best-states-to-live-in","best-states-to-raise-a-family","best-states-to-retire","states-with-the-best-weather","worst-drivers-by-state","worst-states-to-live-in","worst-states-to-retire"]}},"sources":[{"name":"The 20 Best Places to Live in the U.S. for the Weather in 2019","link":"https://realestate.usnews.com/real-estate/slideshows/the-best-places-to-live-in-the-us-for-the-weather"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"states-with-the-best-weather","name":"States With The Best Weather"},{"article":"âSpring Forward, Fall Back.â If youâve ever heard this saying, then you probably live in an area that observes daylight savings time. During daylight savings time in the United States, residents set their clocks ahead by one hour. This results in mornings with less sunlight and more sunlight during the evenings. \n \nDaylight savings time begins on the second Sunday in March. When it ends on the first Sunday in November, clocks are set back an hour. Clocks are always set forward or backward at 2:00 AM local time. \n \nMost states in the United States observe daylight savings time, although many people have argued against its usefulness and advocate for a year-round daylight savings time without having to set clocks forward or back. As of mid-2019, however, no changes have been made, and the majority of the U.S. states continue to observe daylight savings time. Uniform daylight savings time was established under the Uniform Time Act of 1966. \n \nThere are, however, a handful of exceptions. In Arizona, daylight savings time was observed in 1967. However, an exemption statute was enacted the following year, and ever since 1968, this state has not observed daylight savings time. However, the Navajo Indian Reservation, which is located in the states of Arizona, Utah, and New Mexico, does observe daylight savings time. \n \nThe state of Hawaii opted out of daylight savings time under the Uniform Time Act, so this state has never observed daylight savings time. Due to Hawaiiâs location, there are fewer variations between winter and summer daylight hours, so it makes sense to not have daylight savings time in this state. \n \nHawaii and Arizona are the only two states in the U.S. that do not observe daylight savings time. However, there are several overseas territories that do not observe daylight savings time. Those territories include American Samoa, Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.\n\n","data":{"states":["Arizona","Hawaii"]},"sources":[{"name":"The Reason Some States Don't Observe Daylight Saving Time","link":"https://time.com/5005600/states-without-daylight-savings-time/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"states-without-daylight-savings","name":"States Without Daylight Savings"},{"article":"Residents of the United States are familiar with paying taxes. Individuals pay federal income taxes and additional state income taxes that vary depending on their state of residence. In addition to income taxes, property taxes may also be applicable. \n\nProperty tax is a real estate ad-valorem tax, considered a regressive tax, levied by the jurisdiction in which the property is located and paid for by the property owner. Taxes are determined by multiplying the property tax rate by the current market value and are recalculated annually. Property taxes are used to fund education, infrastructure, law enforcement, parks and recreation, public transportation, and water and sewer improvements. \n\nUnfortunately, every state has property taxes; however, some property taxes are very low and others do not apply to vehicles. States that have lower property taxes may have higher costs elsewhere, such as a high sales tax, in order to make up for the costs. \n\n## States with the Highest Property Tax Rates\n\nSome of the highest property taxes can generally be found in the northeast, with the highest rate being 2.44% in New Jersey. The average homeowner in New Jersey paid $8,500 per home in property taxes. One reason for the property tax rate being consistently high in New Jersey is that county and municipal governments cannot impose local income or sales tax in New Jersey as they can in other states. Property taxes pay for most of everything in New Jersey.\n\nThe second-highest property tax rate is in Illinois. The property tax rate is 2.31% in Illinois. In 1996, Illinois property tax bills were around the national average and then saw an 80% increase in the following 20 years. Home value appreciation has been lagging despite property taxes increasing quickly.\n\nNew Hampshire has the third-highest property tax rate in the U.S. of 2.20%. Residents of New Hampshire pay a higher percentage of income in property taxes (5.6%) than any other state. The high property tax rate has made it hard for younger people to purchase homes because the property tax bill is often larger than their mortgages. New Hampshire, however, does not impose an income tax on earned salaries or wages and does not have a sales tax. \n\nThe fourth-highest property tax rate is in Connecticut, which has a rate of 2.07%.  The state per capita tax burden is at $2,847, twice the national average of $1,518. Property taxes now total over $11 billion annually in Connecticut. Local officials are worried that relying on property tax to fund the local government is unsustainable. \n\nWisconsin has the fifth-highest property tax rate in the United States of 1.94%, which finally dips just below 2%. Per capita property taxes in Wisconsin are about $1,615.71, above the national average. The median home value in Wisconsin in $178,900 and the median household income is $59,305.\n\n## States with the Lowest Property Tax Rates\n\nAs previously stated, there are no states that have no real estate property tax. There are 26 states, however, that have property taxes below 1.00%.\n\nWhich state has the lowest property tax rate? Hawaii has the lowest property tax rate of 0.27%. Although this rate is very low, Hawaii has a very high median house cost; therefore, homeowners will still expect to pay around $1,529 in property taxes.\n\nAlabama has not only the second-lowest property tax rate of 0.42% but also has one of the lowest median home prices ($130,500) well below the median home value in the United States ($225,300). This makes the median annual tax only $558. \n\nLouisiana has the third-lowest property tax rate in the U.S. of 0.52%. Louisianaâs property tax rate is less than half that of the national average of 1.08%. One reason that property taxes are so low is the stateâs homestead exemption, which reduces the taxable value of owner-occupied properties by $7,500 in assessed value. \n\nColorado has the fourth-lowest property tax rate of 0.55%. With the average home value being the fifth-highest in the nation, homeowners can expect to pay the 21st lowest average property tax bill in the country instead of the fourth-lowest. \n\nDelaware has the fifth-lowest property tax rate in the U.S. of 0.56%. Delawareâs high income tax rate is offset by its low property tax rate and lack of retail sales tax. The low property taxes are attractive to residents, especially retirees, of other states, especially the stateâs neighbor, New Jersey, which has the highest property tax rate in the country.\n\n\n\n\n","frontmatter":{"title":"States With No Property To simplify, when you make a purchase, the sales tax is added to the cost of your purchase. For example, if a state has a 5% sales tax and you purchase an item that costs ten dollars, you will pay $10.50 at the register.\n\nThe amount of sales tax varies from state to state. Some states â 38 as of November 2018 â also have local sales taxes. The highest average combined state and local tax rates are in Tennessee, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Washington, each of which has combined taxes of over 9%. At the state level, California has the highest tax rate at 7.25%. Four states fall only slightly behind with state sales tax rates of 7%. Those states are Tennessee, Indiana, Mississippi, and Rhode Island.\n\nForty-five states plus Washington, D.C., have statewide sales tax. The states that do not have state sales taxes are:\n\n- Alaska\n- Delaware\n- Montana\n- New Hampshire\n- Oregon\n\nEven though Alaska does not have a state sales tax, localities can charge local sales taxes.\n","data":{"states":["Alabama","Arizona","Arkansas","California","Colorado","Connecticut","Florida","Georgia","Hawaii","Idaho","Illinois","Indiana","Iowa","Kansas","Kentucky","Louisiana","Maine","Maryland","Massachusetts","Michigan","Minnesota","Mississippi","Missouri","Nebraska","Nevada","New Jersey","New Mexico","New York","North Carolina","North Dakota","Ohio","Oklahoma","Pennsylvania","Rhode Island","South Carolina","South Dakota","Tennessee","Texas","Utah","Vermont","Virginia","Washington","West Virginia","Wisconsin","Wyoming"]},"sources":[{"name":"The 5 U.S. States Without a Statewide Sales Tax","link":"https://www.thebalance.com/states-without-a-sales-tax-3193305"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"states-without-sales-tax","name":"States Without Sales Tax"},{"article":"A statute of limitations is a law that outlines how long a person has to file a lawsuit. For criminal cases, the statute of limitations dictates how long a prosecutor has to charge someone with a crime. For example, if a person commits a crime but many years have passed, depending on the state and the crime, the accused person may not have to go to trial or face criminal punishment. \n \nFirst, letâs take a look at the statute of limitations for civil cases. This varies not just by state, but also by the type of lawsuit being filed. For example, a property damage suit may have different statute of limitations than a suit filed over an oral contract. Weâll start by first looking at the statute of limitations based on contracts. \n \n- Alabama: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Alaska: Written â 3 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Arizona: Written â 6 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Arkansas: Written â 5 years, Oral â 3 years\n- California: Written â 4 years, Oral â 2 years\n- Colorado: Written â 3 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Connecticut: Written â 6 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Delaware: Written â 3 years, Oral â 3 years\n- District of Columbia: Written â 2 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Florida: Written â 5 years, Oral: 4 years\n- Georgia: Written â 6 years, Oral â 4 years\n- Hawaii: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Idaho: Written â 5 years, Oral â 4 years\n- Illinois: Written â 10 years, Oral â 5 years\n- Indiana: Written â 10 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Iowa: Written â 10 years, Oral â 5 years\n- Kansas: Written â 5 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Kentucky: Written â 10 years, Oral â 5 years\n- Louisiana: Written â 10 years, Oral â 10 years\n- Maine: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Maryland: Written â 3 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Massachusetts: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Michigan: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Minnesota: Written â 6 years, Oral â 6 years\n- Mississippi: Written â 6 years, Oral â 3 years\n- Missouri: Written â 10 years, Oral â 5 years\n- Montana: Written â 8 years, Oral - Other felonies â 3 years. \n- Alaska: No statute of limitations for multiple sex crimes, murder, or kidnapping. Other felonies â 5 to 10 years. \n- Arizona: No statute of limitations for homicide, falsifying public records, misuse of public money, or violent sexual assault. Other felonies â 7 years. \n- Arkansas: No statute of limitations for multiple sex offenses or murder. Other felonies: 3 to 6 years.\n- California: No statute of limitations for multiple sex crimes, offenses punishable by life in prison or death, or embezzlement of public funds. Other felonies: 3 to 6 years. \n- Colorado: No statute of limitations for treason, sex offenses against children, murder, kidnapping, or forgery. Other felonies: 3 years. \n- Connecticut: No statute of limitations for Class A felonies or murder. Other felonies: 5 to 30 years. \n- Delaware: No statute of limitations for murder, Class A felonies, or multiple sex offenses. Other felonies: 5 to 13 years\n- District of Columbia: No statute of limitations for 1st or 2nd degree murder. Other felonies: 3 to 9 years. \n- Florida: No statute of limitations for perjury, capital or life felonies, or felonies that result in death. Other felonies: 3 to 5 years\n- Georgia: No statute of limitations on certain crimes against children and murder. Other felonies: 4 to 15 years. \n- Hawaii: No statute of limitations for 1st or 2nd degree murder or attempted murder or solicitation to commit murder. Other felonies: 3 to 10 years\n- Idaho: No statute of limitations for murder, rape, sexual abuse or lewd conduct with a child, or voluntary manslaughter. Other felonies: 3 to 5 years\n- Illinois: No statute of limitations for involuntary manslaughter, 1st or 2nd degree murder, reckless homicide, treason, arson, child pornography, or forgery. Other felonies: 3 to 7 years. \n- Indiana: No statute of limitations for murder or Level 1 or 2 felonies. Other felonies: 5 to 6 years. For some sex crimes against children, statute of limitations is until allege victim turns 31 years old. \n- Iowa: No statute of limitations for 1st and 2nd degree murder. Other felonies: 3 to 10 years. \n- Kansas: No statute of limitations for terrorism, rape, or murder. Other felonies: 5 to 10 years. \n- Kentucky: No statute of limitations for felonies. \n- Louisiana: No statute of limitations for crimes punishable by death or life imprisonment. Other felonies: 4 to 10 years\n- Maine: No statute of limitations for incest, rape, gross sexual assault on a victim under 16, homicide, or murder. State"},{"article":"The statute of limitations on debt is a rule limiting how long a creditor can sue an individual for payment on a debt. All consumer debts have limits on the number of years creditors have, and each state has its own limitations. \n\nDebts that have passed the statute of limitations are known as time-barred debt. Even after the statute of limitations passes, these debts still appear on credit reports and your credit rating is still affected. Furthermore, having time-barred debts does not mean you are no longer responsible for paying the debt back. \n\nEvery state has its own statute of limitations on debt, and each varies depending on the type of debt you have. There are four types of debt. An oral agreement is a debt made based on a verbal agreement to pay back the money. A written contract is a debt that came with a contract signed by you and the creditor. A promissory note is a written agreement to pay back the debt in payment at a specific interest rate by a certain date and time. An open-ended account is an account with a revolving balance that you can repay and then borrow again such as a credit card.\n\nIt is important that you establish which type of debt you have when looking at each stateâs limits. \n","sources":[{"name":"Statute of Limitations on States has its laws surrounding crime. Whether it is whether or not marijuana is legal or the maximum penalties for committing a particular crime, state laws vary. In some states, local governments have enacted âstop and identifyâ statutes.\n\nWhat does âstop and identifyâ mean? Itâs a simple concept. In states where this statute is enacted, a person suspected of committing a crime is legally obligated to identify themselves to authorities. However, even in states where this statute is in place, a person is not required to provide identification to the police unless there is a reasonable belief that:\n\n- A crime has been committed\n- A crime is currently being committed\n- A crime was committed\n\nIf any of the above conditions are met, a police officer may also temporarily detain the suspect and can conduct a patdown if it is believed that the suspect is carrying a weapon. Unreasonable searches and seizures, however, are banned, and a warrant must be issued after showing probable cause to conduct searches of vehicles, homes, or other property.\n\nAny states that are not on this list are not required to show their ID to police officers.\n\nEven though all of these states have some form of âstop and identifyâ laws, these laws vary by state. For example, in some states, name, address, and what a person is doing is all that needs to be disclosed. In other states, such as Indiana, date of birth is required. According to the laws of Nevada, all that is required to be disclosed is a personâs full name. In seven of these states, there is a criminal penalty imposed for anyone that does not comply with identifying themselves under âstop and identifyâ laws.\n","frontmatter":{"title":"Stop and Identify States"},"data":{"states":["Alabama","Arizona","Arkansas","Colorado","Delaware","Florida","Georgia","Illinois","Indiana","Kansas","Louisiana","Missouri","Montana","Nebraska","Nevada","New Hampshire","New Mexico","North Dakota","Ohio","Rhode Island","Utah","Vermont","Wisconsin"],"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["sanctuary-states",{"link":"stop-and-id-states","title":"Stop and Identify States"},"cost-of-illegal-immigration-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Do I Have to Show the Police My ID?","link":"https://www.thoughtco.com/show-the-police-my-id-970889"},{"name":"ACLU of New York","link":"https://www.nyclu.org/en/know-your-rights/what-do-if-youre-stopped-police"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"stop-and-id-states","name":"Stop And Id States"},{"article":"The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, or CDC for short, compiled [extensive data](https://www.usatoday.com/list/news/depression-suicide-by-state/346e182d-d439-4448-b8d9-a0233a45f598/) on the suicide rates of each state in the US. But something to take into consideration regarding suicide rates in the United States of America is that many suicides are the result of circumstances that were beyond avoidable. One thing that is a heavy commonality among people who die by suicide is an unshakeable feeling of dread, despair, loneliness, and hopelessness. These adjectives can be said to be overused in the discussions revolving around suicide, but they need to be taken seriously in order for suicide rates by state to decrease.\n\nAs you can tell by viewing the University of Washingtonâs collective data on the depression rates nationwide, people in 2017 were reportedly very unhappy with life in general. Depression rates are one factor that hold serious importance, but other factors to take into consideration areâ¦\n\n- Academic performance\n- Physical condition\n- Mental health and well-being\n- Economical standing\n- Financial struggles\n- Workplace performance\n- Overall life satisfaction\n\nThe list truly goes on and on, but one factor that holds true is that the United States could be working more intuitively and intentionally to decrease the suicide rates by state in the nation. United States, a president is elected every four years. Some states in the U.S. are known as blue states, meaning that the Democratic presidential candidate will most likely win. There are also red states, which means that the Republican presidential candidate is most likely to get the majority votes. However, there are a handful of states that are known as swing states. \n \nSwing states, which are also called purple states or battleground states, are states that donât lean toward one particular party. In these states, all major parties campaign heavily to get votes during competitive elections. In these states, it is often a very close race across the major parties. \n \nThe battleground states may change during different election cycles. Polling data, the ideologies of nominees, and demographics can be looked at to determine which states are considered swing states during any given election. \n \nHowever, there are a few âperennialâ swing states, meaning that election results have been close multiple times throughout the last several campaigns. States"},{"article":"Taxes are a necessary evil when you live in the United States. Not only do you have to pay federal taxes, but you also have to pay taxes to your state. While it can be a burden, these tax dollars are critical to the stateâs revenue, which is used to build and repair critical infrastructure, fund state programs, and for other important purposes. \n\nNot only do state taxes cut into your household income, but understanding how much you have to pay can be confusing. Each state has its own rules surrounding different types of taxes and each taxpayerâs circumstances (i.e., is the taxpayer married or does the taxpayer have dependents?) To make it easier to understand how much a person has to pay in each state, we can look at a ratio known as the tax burden. \n\nThe tax burden is a measure of all of the total income that residents of a state pay in state and local taxes. For this article, weâre going to take a look at the states that have the highest and lowest tax burdens based on data compiled by WalletHub. Each tax burden listed here takes into account property taxes, income taxes, and sales and excise taxes. \n\nThe state with the highest tax burden based on these three types of taxes is New York. The total tax burden of New York is 12.97%. Hawaii isnât too far behind with a total tax burden of 11.71%. Maine comes in third place with a tax burden of 10.84%. \n\nOther states with a total tax burden higher than 10% are Vermont, Minnesota, and Rhode Island.\n\nThe state with the lowest tax burden is Alaska at 5.1%. Delawareâs total tax burden isnât much higher at 5.55%. The state of Tennessee has the third lowest tax burden at 6.28%. \n\nWhen breaking down tax burdens by category, New Hampshire has the highest property tax burden in the nation at 5.45%. Vermont and New Jersey also have property tax burdens that exceed 5%.\n\nThe lowest property tax burden is in Alabama, where the rate is 1.39%. Oklahoma, Arkansas, Delaware, Tennessee, Kentucky, and New Mexico also have property taxes that fall below 2%. \n\nWhen it comes to the individual income tax burden, New York has the highest at 4.81%. Oregon also has an income tax burden that exceeds 4%. Several states have no income taxes. These states are Nevada, Washington, Florida, South Dakota, Alaska, Texas, and Wyoming.\n\nWhen looking at the sales and excise tax burden, Hawaii has the highest in the nation at 6.56%. Nevada has the second highest at 6.02%. The lowest sales and excise tax burden can be found in Oregon, where the rate is 1.09%. \n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":[{"header":"Overall Rank","field":"overallRank"},"state",{"header":"Total Tax Burden","field":"totalTaxBurden","format":"percAlt"},{"header":"Property Tax Burden","field":"propertyTaxBurden","format":"percAlt"},{"header":"Indiv. State"},{"article":"A tax is a compulsory financial charge or some other type of levy imposed upon a taxpayer by a governmental organization. Taxes are used to fund a number of public expenditures, such as roads, public transportation, education, and others. When expenditures exceed tax revenue, the government goes into debt.\r\n\r\nTaxes have two effects:\r\n\r\n-\tAn income effect because they reduce purchasing power to taxpayers (income tax)\r\n-\tA substitution effect when taxes cause a substitution between taxed goods and untaxed goods (sales tax)\r\n\r\nFederal income tax is the tax levied by the United States Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on the earnings of individuals and legal entities. However, most states collect state income and sales taxes in addition to the federal income tax. State taxes are given little attention compared to federal income taxes.\r\n\r\nStates take one of three approaches when it comes to state income taxes:\r\n\r\n-\tThe state does not collect income tax\r\n-\tThe state imposes a flat tax, taxing all income (or only dividends and interest) at the same rate\r\n-\tThe state imposes a progressive tax which taxes higher income at higher rates\r\n\r\nFirst, there are seven states that do not collect a state income tax. While these states do not have an additional income tax, other taxes, such as property or sales taxes, could be higher in these states. The seven states are:\r\n\r\n-\tAlaska\r\n-\tFlorida\r\n-\tNevada\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tTexas\r\n-\tWashington\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nSecond, there are eleven states with flat income tax rates. In New Hampshire and Tennessee, the tax rate applies to dividends and interest income and regular income is typically not subject to state tax. These states are:\r\n\r\n-\tColorado (4.63%)\r\n-\tIllinois (4.95%)\r\n-\tIndiana (3.23%)\r\n-\tKentucky (5%)\r\n-\tMassachusetts (5.05%)\r\n-\tMichigan (4.25%)\r\n-\tNew Hampshire (5%)\r\n-\tNorth Carolina (5.25%)\r\n-\tPennsylvania (3.07%)\r\n-\tTennessee (2%)\r\n-\tUtah (4.95%)\r\n\r\nThe remaining states and the District of Columbia have state income tax brackets. The higher an individualâs income, the higher the tax bracket he/she will be placed into. California has the highest potential state income tax bracket of 13%.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table with each stateâs lowest and highest state income tax bracket. \r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["alcohol-tax-by-state","corporate-tax-rates-by-state","income-tax-by-state","sales-tax-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-pensions","states-with-lowest-taxes","taxes-on-lottery-winnings-by-state","capital-gains-tax-by-state","gas-taxes-by-state","property-taxes-by-state","state-tax-rates","states-that-tax-social-security","states-with-no-income-tax","tax-burden-by-state","car-sales-tax-by-state","highest-taxed-states","retirement-taxes-by-state","states-that-dont-tax-military-retirement","states-with-internet-sales-tax",{"link":"states-without-property-tax","title":"States With No Property Tax"},"taxes-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"taxes-by-state","name":"Taxes By State"},{"article":"Thereâs no doubt that winning the lottery is exciting and can significantly help the winner financially; however, the winner must not be too quick to spend all of his or her winnings. Like other income in the United States, the IRS taxes lottery winnings. \r\n\r\nLottery winnings are considered ordinary taxable income for both federal and state tax purposes. Winnings are taxed the same as wages or salaries are, and the total amount the winner receives must be reported on their tax return each year. Before the winner receives any of the money, however, the IRS automatically takes 24% of the winnings. The rest of the winnings are expected to be paid by the winner when filing the return. \r\n\r\nWhat is the tax rate for lottery winnings? For federal taxes, lottery winnings are taxed according to the [federal tax brackets](https://www.quickenloans.com/blog/federal-income-tax-brackets). Federal tax brackets are progressive, so portions of the winnings are taxed at different rates, and could be as high as 37%. State income taxes vary by location. Some states do not have a state income tax, while others may withhold up to 8.82%. \r\n\r\nThe states that do not levy an individual income tax are:\r\n\r\n-\tFlorida\r\n-\tNew Hampshire\r\n-\tTennessee\r\n-\tTexas\r\n-\tSouth Dakota\r\n-\tWashington\r\n-\tWyoming\r\n\r\nSix states do not have a lottery: Alabama, Alaska, Hawaii, Mississippi, Nevada, and Utah. Two states, California and Delaware, do have a lottery but do not tax winnings.\r\n\r\nIf the winner buys a winning ticket in a state that they do not live in, most states will not withhold the winnings. Out of the 43 states that participate in multistate lotteries, only Arizona and Maryland tax the winnings of people who live out of state.\r\n\r\nThe ten states with the highest lottery withholding tax rates are:\r\n\r\n1.\tNew York (8.82%)\r\n2.\tMaryland (8.75%)\r\n3.\tDistrict of Columbia (8.50%)\r\n4.\tNew Jersey (8.00%)\r\n5.\tOregon (8.00%)\r\n6.\tWisconsin (7.65%)\r\n7.\tMinnesota This isnât just a small difference either. In some states, salaries are thousands of dollars higher than in other states. \n\nIn this post, weâre going to look the pay for new teachers by state. As a teacher gains more experience, they can earn higher pay but we are going to focus solely on the salaries of teachers that are just getting started. \n\nThe highest pay in the nation for new teachers is in Washington, D.C. In this area, the average salary is $55,209. New Jersey isnât far behind with an average salary of $51,443. These are the only two states in the nation where new teachers can make a salary of over $50,000 annually.\n\nThe third highest salary for teachers can be found in California, where teachers make almost $47,000. Pay By State"},{"article":"The teen pregnancy rate in the United States has been declining in the past 20 years. As of 2018, the United States teen birth rate is 17.4 births per 1,000 females between the ages 15 and 19. Despite these lower rates, however, the U.S. continues to have the highest teen pregnancy rate of all developed nations.\n\nTeen pregnancy has substantial health, economic, and social costs. Pregnant teenagers are more likely to experience miscarriages, maternal illness (preeclampsia, hypertension, etc.), stillbirth, and neonatal death. Teenage mothers are also more likely to drop out of school and never return in order to raise a child. Teen mothers, therefore, often lack a high school diploma, let alone a college degree, and will likely face unemployment and poverty. Children of teen pregnancies are sometimes forced into foster care if the mother cannot care for them, where teenage females are twice as likely to become pregnant, creating a cycle. \n\nOne of the best ways to prevent teen pregnancies is the use of birth control methods, such as condoms or oral contraceptives, and providing easy access to such things. Comprehensive sex education in and outside of schools has been proven to be very effective, and sex education courses must be given to both boys and girls. Additionally, mentorship from peers or older teens tends to be more comfortable and impactful then from parents. Some communities have set up mentorship programs to help encourage healthy sexuality discussions among teens. \n\n[Research](https://www.livescience.com/5728-teen-birth-rates-higher-highly-religious-states.html) suggests that âU.S states whose residents have more conservative religious beliefs on average tend to have higher rates of teenagers giving birth.â Of the ten most conservatively religious states in the United States, eight are among the states that have the highest teen birth rates. \n\nTeen birth rates are measured as the number of births per 1,000 women between the ages of 15 and 19. \n\n## Ten States with the Highest Teen Pregnancy Rates\n\n#### 1. Arkansas\n\nArkansas has the highest teen birth rate of 30.4 births per 1,000 women. Arkansas is one of the most conservatively religious states in the country. Despite being the highest in the country, Arkansasâs birth rate has seen a significant decline in recent years, dropping from 59.1 in 2005, to 39.5 in 2014, and finally to 30.4 in 2018. \n\n#### 2. Mississippi\n\nMississippi has the second-highest teen birth rate of 27.8 births per 1,000 women. The Arkansas-Mississippi Delta area has the highest birth rates, [a study](https://www.mathematica.org/our-publications-and-findings/publications/accelerating-teen-pregnancy-prevention-in-phillips-county-arkansas-and-coahoma-county-mississippi) found, pointing to community norms and socioeconomic factors in the area that could compound to contribute to higher teen pregnancy rates, such as poverty, discrimination, lack of comprehensive sex education. \n\n#### 3. Oklahoma\n\nOklahomaâs teen birth rate is 27.2 births per 1,000 women, giving it the third-highest teen birth rate in the United States. In Oklahoma, 1-in-5 births to girls ages 15 through 19 is not the motherâs first child. One issue seen in the state is some of the school districts, such as the Oklahoma City Public Schools, fail to provide sex education at any grade level for its students. \n\n#### 4. Louisiana\n\nLouisianaâs birth rate of 27.5 births per 1,000 women is the fourth-highest in the country. About 75% of teen births in Louisiana are to mothers who were in their late teens, (age 18 ad 19) and 18% of teen births were to teens who already have a child. Pediatrician Scott Hamilton explained that sec education isnât a part of school systems and itâs not something discussed at home with parents. \n\n#### 5. Kentucky\n\nKentucky has the fifth-highest teen birth rate of 27.3 births per 1,000 women. Kentuckyâs urban counties have seen a larger decline in teen pregnancies than in its rural counties, likely because teens in rural areas have little access to health care, including access to contraceptives, are more likely to live in poverty, and have fewer educational opportunities. The disparity in these pregnancy rates is largely explained by the lack of healthcare and lack of education in rural areas. \n\n#### 6. West Virginia\n\nWest Virginiaâs teen birth rate is 25.4 births per 1,000 women. Some counties in West Virginia experience exceptionally high teen birth rates around 48 births per 1,000 women, likely due to being in rural areas. About 79% of West Virginiaâs teen births are to older teens (age 18-19) and about 19% of teen births are to teens who already have a child. \n\n#### 7. New Mexico\n\nNew Mexicoâs teen birth rate of 25.3 births per 1,000 women is the seventh-highest in the United States. 55.1% of female teens ages 15 to 19 in New Mexico are Hispanic and 81% of the teens that gave birth in 2017 were Hispanic. New Mexico has a child poverty rate of 25.9%, which is a large contributing factor to teen pregnancies. New Mexicoâs teen birth rate is still declining, however, and in 2015, the public savings due to the decline in the teen birth rate total $38 million. \n\n#### 8. Texas\n\nTexas is tied with New Mexico for the seventh-highest teen birth rate in the United States of 25.3. Every year, around 35,000 women in Texas get pregnant before the age of 20. It is difficult for women to access reproductive services in Texas, which contributes to not only the high teen birth rate but also contributes to the reason why Texas has the highest rate of repeat-teen births. Other factors that researchers believe are contributing to this are a lack of sex education and abstinence-only programs.  \n\n#### 9. Tennessee\n\nTied with Texas and New Mexico with a teen birth rate of 25.3 is Tennessee. Unsurprisingly, the rural counties in Tennessee showed higher teen birth rates. The Tennessee Department of Health has made reducing the teen birth rate a priority and their efforts are being seen. The Tennessee Adolescent Pregnancy Prevention Program (TAPPP) is one of the programs implemented that aims to educate and mentor young teens and adults about healthy sexual relationships. \n\n#### 10. Alabama\n\nFinishing the top ten states with the highest teen birth rates in the United States is Alabama with a teen birth rate of 25.2 births per 1,000 women. About 74% of teen births in Alabama are to older teens (ages 18-19) and 16% of teen births are to teens who already have children. Like other states with high teen birth rates, Alabama has its fair share of rural areas and is also one of the most religious states in the country. Despite this, Alabama has seen significant improvements in its teen birth rate in the past few decades, which has decreased by about 63% since 1991. State"},{"article":"Adding tint to car windows can prove to become beneficial in the long run. This statement is especially true for people living in areas with plenty of sunshine. However, there are laws that each state abides by to ensure that an individualâs tint isnât too dark. To provide more insight on this topic, here are the rules surrounding tint on cars. \n\n## Windows \nTypically, the tint on a personâs car is too dark if they are unable to be seen by anyone else while in the car. However, other states go into more detail regarding different parts of a vehicle, such as the:\n\n## Windshield\n- Front and backside windows\n- Rear window\n- Side mirrors\n\nThere is only one state that allows people to tint their windows to any tint percentage: Michigan. On the contrary, there are seven states and one district that only allow a lighter tint on car windows (California, Iowa, Alaska, Pennsylvania, New York, Rhode Island, Delaware, and Washington D.C.). Three other states do not allow tint on cars at all (New Jersey, Vermont, and New Hampshire).\n\nThe remaining states vary their tint laws based on a tint percentage between 10% and 60%. To see the rates in each state, check out the chart that goes into more detail about tinting.\n\n## Colors\nAs with tinted windows, the color of the tint depends on the state that a person resides in currently. Nonetheless, some states are more lenient when it comes to colored shades, and some are more strict.\n\nThe states that are more lenient on tinted colors, meaning that they will allow some colored tints, include, but are not limited to:\n\n- Montana\n- Colorado\n- Arizona\n- Florida\n\nOther states, on the other hand, are more strict with this rule and will only allow lighter colors on car tints. Some of these states wonât allow any color at all. These are some of the states that carry this law:\n\n- Michigan\n- New Hampshire\n- New Jersey\n- Washington D.C.\n\n## Exceptions\nDespite each stateâs law regarding tints, there is one main reason why someone is allowed to have tint on their windows: for medical purposes. Some of the medical conditions that entitle individuals to add tint to their cars include:\n\n- Albinism\n- Bloom Syndrome\n- Solar Urticaria\n\nAlthough having any disease that prevents people from being exposed to light is severe, many states still do not allow tint on cars for medical reasons. Still, they have a certain percentage that individuals can have their tint set to and always be within the legal limit. While many Americans still have that dream, more people are going in the opposite direction. Instead of buying a huge, expensive home filled with lots of stuff, some people are downsizing, cleaning out their clutter, and living a simpler life in a tiny house. \n\nA tiny house is exactly what it sounds like â a house that is very tiny. Weâre not talking about a one bedroom home thatâs 1,000 square feet, either. A residential structure under 500 square feet is considered a tiny home, although there isnât a set definition so some homes may be slightly larger. \n\nThere are many different types of tiny houses. Some have wheels so they can be moved from place to place â perfect for the traveling homeowner. Others are stationary. Throughout the nation, there are tiny house communities. In other areas, some tiny house owners live completely off the grid. \n\nThe interiors of these homes are creatively designed to get the most out of such a small space. Built-in storage, no bathtubs in bathrooms, smaller kitchen appliances, and lofts that serve as bedrooms are just a few of the ways that people are comfortably living in tiny houses. \n\nBecause these are dwellings, in most areas in the U.S., building and zoning laws apply. These laws vary by state, county, and even city. Many areas do not even have tiny house laws yet since this is a relatively new idea, but laws may be implemented in the near future as popularity grows. In all states, though, the proper building permits must be acquired and builders have to follow all zoning regulations. \n\nSome states have outlined specific laws for tiny houses. The state of Michigan has seen an increase in pop-up communities with efficient dwellings that have been helpful in cities such as Detroit. Based on Michiganâs law, tiny houses can be built provided they follow codes and are not less than 500 square feet. \n\nIn the state of Nevada, most areas will issue a building permit provided the tiny house has at least 200 square feet of living space. \n\nIn some cities and towns in Colorado, there is no set minimum square footage for houses, making this a very tiny house-friendly state. \n\nTo get a building permit in the state of North Carolina, the tiny home must be at least 150 square feet. However, for every additional occupant, 100 square feet must be added. This means that a couple must build a structure of 250 square feet, while a family of four is required to build a tiny home of at least 450 square feet. \n\nLaws are similar in South Dakota. A building permit can be obtained for a dwelling of at least 190 square feet, but 50 square feet must be added for each additional occupant. \n\nIn Maine, you can build a tiny home provided that the home is less than 400 square feet and there are proper sleeping arrangements for all occupants.  \n\nWhile laws vary across the nation when it comes to tiny homes, this growing movement could push lawmakers to create more specific laws in the future. \n\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-laws-by-state","blue-laws-by-state","child-discipline-laws-by-state","clothing-laws-by-state","common-law-marriage-states","filial-responsibility-laws-by-state","final-paycheck-laws-by-state","gun-laws-by-state","helmet-law-states","homeschool-laws-by-state","incest-laws-by-state","late-fee-laws-by-state","magazine-capacity-laws-by-state","marijuana-laws-by-state","mushroom-laws-by-state","pepper-spray-laws-by-state","seat-belt-laws-by-state","states-with-stand-your-ground-laws","tiny-house-laws-by-state","voter-id-laws-by-state"]}},"sources":[{"name":"Tiny House Laws in the United States","link":"https://www.tinysociety.co/articles/tiny-house-laws-united-states/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"tiny-house-laws-by-state","name":"Tiny House Laws By State"},{"article":"Tornado Alley is the name commonly use for the corridor-shaped region in the United States Midwest that sees the most tornado activity. While it is not an official designation, states most commonly included are Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Nebraska, Missouri, Iowa, and South Dakota.\n\nFlorida, while not geographically part of tornado alley, sees more tornados than any other state, especially when accounting for how large the state is. The following list, reported by theÂ National Climatic Data CenterÂ shows the seventeen U.S. states with the highest average number of tornadoes per 10,000 sq. miles each year. Figures are for the years 1991 through 2010.\n\n- Florida: 12.2\n- Kansas: 11.7\n- Maryland: 9.9\n- Illinois: 9.7\n- Mississippi: 9.2\n- Iowa: 9.1\n- Oklahoma: 9\n- South Carolina: 9\n- Alabama: 8.6\n- Louisiana: 8.5\n- Arkansas: 7.5\n- Nebraska: 7.4\n- Missouri: 6.5\n- North Carolina: 6.4\n- Tennessee: 6.2\n- Indiana: 6.1\n- Texas: 5.9\n\nThe average tornado only stays on ground for 5 minutes, and approximately 77% are considered between EF-0 and EF-1, with about 95% below EF-3. Only .01% of tornadoes reach the highest category of EF-5. Even so, they can cause many fatalities and significant property damage. \n\nWith information available as recently as 2013, tornadoes cause an average of 94-110 fatalities per year, depending on the source of data. Property damage caused by tornadoes is incredibly difficult to calculate, and as such, little current information about damages per state exists. \n\nThe best estimation we have about property damage is from insurance claims, and it is still unclear how much damage was caused by tornadoes rather than coterminous weather. Alley States"},{"article":"Roads in the United States are regulated in a number of ways, one of them concerning the weight of trucks and semis. Regulations are set on both the federal and state level and must be adhered to. It is common to see weigh stations along interstates for the purpose of weighing trucks to make sure that they are within the limitations.\r\n\r\nThere are a few reasons that trucks have weight limitations on roads and need to be properly weighed. The main reason is safety. Roads can only handle a certain amount of weight, especially in weaker spots such as bridges and overpasses; therefore, no vehicle can be over the weight limit of the weakest point on the road. Additionally, cargo that is too heavy can be dangerous to both the driver and other vehicles on the road. A truck that is carrying too much weight can make it difficult to brake and maneuver, posing a danger when trying to slow down or go down a hill. \r\n\r\nThe other two reasons for weighing trucks are taxes and profitability. Carriers pay taxes for the amount of stress put on the roads, and the weight of the trucks is used to calculate the taxes owed. As for profitability, many goods are valued based on their weight; therefore, weight is important in ensuring fair trade and increasing profits.\r\n\r\nThere are three different weights for trucks regulated by each state. The first is the maximum gross vehicle weight is the weight of the vehicle specified by the manufacturer including its chassis, body, engine, engine fluids, accessories, drivers, passengers and cargo. The maximum single axle weight is the amount of weight allowed on any one axle. The maximum tandem axle weight is the weight allowed on any tandem axle. \r\n\r\nTrucks can be weighed by using wheel-weighers, concrete decks, portable truck scales, digital scales and more. Trucks that are found to be overweight at a weigh stations can face several consequences including paying fines up to $65 per pound overweight and, in some states, arresting the driver. It is important that each truck is weighed before departing on its route to avoid these repercussions.\r\n\r\nThe federal vehicle weight limits are 80,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, 20,000 pounds on a single axle, and 34,000 pounds on a tandem axle group. States, however, often have different limits. \r\n\r\nThe table below has each stateâs maximum allowed weight for gross vehicle weight, single axle weight, and tandem axle Weight Limits By State"},{"article":"While itâs not very common, there may come a time when you feel the need to record phone or in-person conversation. Maybe your child is being bullied over the phone, and you want to gather evidence to take to the police. Possibly youâre pursuing a divorce, and youâre seeking proof of an affair or illegal activities. Perhaps youâre working with creditors, and you want to record your conversations. You might not think twice about hitting record on your recording device or mobile app, but did you know that what youâre doing might be illegal?\n\nEach state has its laws surrounding the recording of phone calls. In some states, there are single-party consent laws. This means that just one party has to consent to the recording. In other words, as long as one person knows the conversation is being recorded, it can be recorded without alerting the other party.\n\nIn other states, however, there are two-party consent laws. The name of the law is a bit misleading, however. Under two-party consent laws, every party must consent to the recording, even if there are more than two. This prevents you from recording someone without their knowledge. Itâs important to note that recording police officers or other public officials may have different laws based on the state in which you are recording.\n\nAs of January 2019, there are 11 states with two-party consent laws in place. These states are:\n\n- California\n- Connecticut\n- Florida\n- Hawaii\n- Illinois\n- Maryland\n- Massachusetts\n- Montana\n- New Hampshire\n- Pennsylvania\n- Washington\n\nIn some states, there are exceptions to the law. In Hawaii, for example, two-party consent is only required if the recording device is installed in a public area. In Connecticut, two-party laws do not apply if the person doing the recording is involved in the conversation.\n","data":{"states":["California","Connecticut","Florida","Hawaii","Illinois","Maryland","Massachusetts","Montana","New Hampshire","Pennsylvania","Washington"]},"sources":[{"name":"LAWS ON RECORDING CONVERSATIONS IN ALL 50 STATES","link":"https://www.mwl-law.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/RECORDING-CONVERSATIONS-CHART.pdf"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"two-party-consent-states","name":"Two Party Consent States"},{"article":"The Uniform Bar Examination (UBE) is s standardized bar exam in the United States, developed by the [National Conference of Bar Examiners (NCBE)](http://www.ncbex.org/). The UBE offers portability of scores across states lines, and consists of three parts: the Multistate Bar Examination (MBE), the Multistate Essay Examination (MEE), and the Multistate Performance Test (MPT). The MBE is weighted at 50%, the MEE at 30%, and the MPT at 20%.\r\n\r\nThe bar exam is an examination administered in each state to assess a candidateâs knowledge and skills to determine whether or not the candidate is competent to practice law in that jurisdiction.  It was created in Delaware in 1738, and soon other states followed suit. Like the bar exam, the Uniform Bar Exam is administered twice a year over the course of two days, once in February and once in July, and is uniformly administered and scored. The UBE differs in that it can also be used to apply in multiple jurisdictions that have adopted the UBE. \r\n\r\nThe Uniform Bar Exam was first administered in 2011 in Missouri and North Dakota. Other states began to use the UBE gradually, with a total of 33 jurisdictions (31 states, the District of Columbia and the U.S. Virgin Islands) using the UBE. These states are:\r\n\r\n- Alabama \r\n- Alaska\r\n- Arizona\r\n- Colorado\r\n- Connecticut\r\n- District of Columbia\r\n- Idaho\r\n- Illinois\r\n- Iowa\r\n- Kansas\r\n- Maine\r\n- Maryland\r\n- Massachusetts\r\n- Minnesota\r\n- Missouri\r\n- Montana\r\n- Nebraska\r\n- New Hampshire\r\n- New Jersey\r\n- New Mexico\r\n- New York\r\n- North Carolina \r\n- North Dakota\r\n- Oregon\r\n- Rhode Island\r\n- South Carolina\r\n- Tennessee\r\n- Utah\r\n- Vermont\r\n- Washington\r\n- West Virginia\r\n- Wyoming\r\n- U.S. Virgin Islands\r\n\r\nThree states will soon adopt the UBE: Arkansas will adopt the UBE in February 2020; Ohio in July 2020; and Texas in February 2021. \r\n\r\nSome of the largest legal markets in the United States, including California and Florida, have not adopted the UBE, for reasons such as concerns about the lack of questions on state law. \r\n\r\nA person who passes the Uniform Bar Exam can transfer scores to another jurisdiction within a certain number of months of passing the exam. The transfer eligibility time varies between jurisdictions, ranging from 24 to 60 months. \r\n\r\nThe [American Bar Association](https://www.americanbar.org/) endorsed the Uniform Bar Exam at its 201 mid-year meeting. \r\n","sources":[{"name":"Which States have Adopted the Uniform Bar Exam (UBE)?","link":"https://www.jdadvising.com/which-states-have-adopted-the-ube/"}],"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"ube-states","name":"Ube States"},{"article":"Article is currently in progress, please check back soon.\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Max. Benefits By State"},{"article":"\nOne of the main indicators of the state of the United States economy is the unemployment rate. The unemployment rate is reported every month by the [U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS)](https://www.bls.gov/web/laus/laumstrk.htm). \n\nThe unemployment rate is not only a measure of the economyâs strength but also a measure of the overall happiness and wellbeing of U.S. citizens. Long-term unemployment is a burden for many and can cause financial, emotional, and psychological ruin. A personâs ability to provide for themselves and their family, pay their bills, and contribute to society are key factors in maintaining a happy life and cultural wellbeing. \n\nThere are three types of unemployment, all of which help explain why there is unemployment at a given time. \n\n-\tFrictional unemployment is caused by temporary transitions people make when moving to a new location, entering or re-entering the workforce, or switching from one job to another in search of better pay or a better fit of their skills. Frictional unemployment is also caused by employers laying off or hesitating to hire employees for reasons unrelated to the economy.\n-\tStructural unemployment happens when there is a mismatch in the demographic or industrial composition of a local economy. This happens when new technology causes a decline in older industries, which must then lay off workers to stay competitive. Outsourcing is also a part of structural unemployment. \n-\tCyclical unemployment occurs when there is not enough demand for goods and services in the economy at large to provide jobs for everyone. This is a natural result of capitalism.\n\nAs of December 2019, the national unemployment rate is 3.6%. The unemployment rate varies between states, ranging from 2.30% to 6.10%. In general, the current unemployment rates in the states are lower than they were in 2018, with only a few exceptions. \n\nAlaska has the highest unemployment rate of 6.10%. This, however, is lower than its 2018 unemployment rate of 7.30%. Alaska is in a statewide recession and has seen the fastest rate of job losses since 2015. The higher unemployment rates can be attributed to the seasonality of jobs, the natural frictional unemployment, and the population that lives a subsistence lifestyle.\n\nMississippi and the District of Columbia also have considerably high unemployment rates at 5.3% and 5.0% respectively. While Mississippiâs unemployment rate has dropped over the past few years, its labor force participation rate is only 55.9%, meaning that a little over half of the stateâs eligible workers are active in the economy. In D.C., black residents are six times as likely to be unemployed than their white counterparts, with unemployment rates for each group being 11.3% and 1.9% respectively.  \n\nSouth Carolina, Utah, and Vermont are tied for having the lowest unemployment rate of 2.30%. South Carolinaâs unemployment rate hit four historic lows from September 2019 to December 2019, decreasing from 2.9% to 2.3%. In addition to seeing a low unemployment rate, Utah has also seen the fastest rate of job growth in 2019 of any state, which was up 3.2% vs. the national average of 1.5%. Vermont business owners, like business owners in other states with low unemployment rates, consider the low unemployment rate to a problem as they are quickly growing and will have trouble finding qualified workers, resulting in lower production and cutting back on business hours. \n\nBelow is each stateâs unemployment rate for December 2019. Rate By State"},{"article":"During the American Civil War (1861-1865), the existing states divided between the Union and the Confederacy. The Union, also known as the North, referred to the states that were part of the United States under President Lincolnâs government. The Union was also referred to as the âFederalsâ and the âYankees.â\r\n\r\nThe Union was made up of the 20 free states at the time and five Border states that supported the Union. Free states were states in which the slave trade was illegal. \r\n\r\n#### The Civil War\r\nThe Civil War would answer two questions about the United States: if the U.S. would be a collection of divided sovereign states or of unified states with a sovereign national government and if the country would continue to be the largest slaveholding country in the world. \r\n\r\nThe war started because of the free states and slave states were uncompromising in their differences on whether the government should prohibit slavery in new territories. When Abraham Lincoln was elected in 1860, he pledged to keep slavery out of the territories, which lead seven slave states to secede. These seven states formed the Confederate States of America: South Carolina, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, and Texas.  \r\n\r\nThe war began on April 12, 1861 when the Confederate army opened fire at Fort Sumter. Following this, four more slave states seceded and joined the Confederacy: Virginia, Arkansas, Tennessee, and North Carolina. \r\n\r\nThe Union Army was a new formation comprised mostly of state units. The Border states were essential for winning the war, acting as supply bases for when the Union Army would invade the Confederacy. The Midwest states provided soldiers, horses, funds, and training camps. The Northwest and upper Midwest states provided industrial resources, such as large quantities of munitions and supplies, as well as funds for the war. \r\n\r\nBy 1865, all of the principal Confederate armies surrendered after the Union Army captured Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Following this, the war ended and the United States began rebuilding as a unified nation free of slavery. \r\n\r\n#### Union States\r\nThe term âUnionâ is used in the Constitution, ratified in the name of âWe the People of the United States, in Order to form a perfect Union...â Using the term âUnionâ carried a sense of legitimacy for the non-secessionist states in contrast to the Confederate states. The Union never saw the Confederate statesâ secession as legitimate and always considered them to be a part of the United States throughout their secession and the war. \r\n\r\nThe Union states had more size and strength than the South. The Union states included the Northeast, which was industrialized and urbanized, providing more vital resources and manpower than the Confederacy.\r\n\r\nUnion states in the West/Northwest:\r\n-\tCalifornia\r\n-\tNevada\r\n-\tOregon\r\n\r\nUnion states in the Midwest:\r\n-\tIllinois\r\n-\tIndiana\r\n-\tIowa\r\n-\tKansas\r\n-\tMichigan\r\n-\tMinnesota\r\n-\tOhio\r\n-\tWisconsin\r\n\r\nUnion states in the Northeast:\r\n-\tConnecticut\r\n-\tMaine\r\n-\tMassachusetts\r\n-\tNew Hampshire\r\n-\tNew Jersey\r\n-\tNew York\r\n-\tRhode Island\r\n-\tPennsylvania\r\n-\tVermont\r\n\r\nBorder States:\r\n-\tDelaware\r\n-\tKentucky\r\n-\tMaryland\r\n-\tMissouri\r\n-\tWest Virginia\r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["job-growth-by-state","at-will-employment-states","employment-rate-by-state","right-to-work-states","livable-wage-by-state","minimum-wage-by-state","nursing-compact-states","mpre-scores-by-state","union-states"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"union-states","name":"Union States"},{"article":"The literacy rate is the total number of literate persons (people able to both read and write) in a given age group, expressed as the percentage of that age group. The adult literacy rate measures literacy among persons age 15 and older. \r\n\r\nAccording to the [National Center for Education Statistics](https://nces.ed.gov/datapoints/2019179.asp), about four out of five U.S. adults (79%) have medium to high English literacy skills. These levels of literacy are sufficient enough to compare and contrast information, paraphrase, and make low-level inferences. This means that about one in five U.S. adults (21%) have low literacy skills, which translates to about 43.0 million adults. \r\n\r\nOf those who have low English literacy skills, 35% are White, 2% of whom are born outside of the U.S.; 23% are Black, 3% of whom are born outside of the U.S.; 34% are Hispanic, 24% of whom are born outside of the U.S.; 8% are of other races/ethnicities. Non-U.S.-born adults comprise 34% of the U.S. population with low literacy skills. \r\n\r\nLiteracy rates [vary greatly by state](https://247wallst.com/special-report/2018/09/07/most-and-least-literate-states/6/) and are affected by several factors. \r\n\r\nNew Hampshire has the lowest percentage (5.8%) of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills, making New Hampshireâs literacy rate 94.2%. About 36.6% of adults in New Hampshire have a bachelorâs degree or higher, the seventh-highest rate in the country, and 60.8% of the population are registered library users, also the seventh-highest in the country.\r\n\r\nMinnesota has the second-highest literacy rate of 94.0%, with only 6% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills. About 69.9% of Minnesota residents are registered library users, the second-highest in the country. \r\n\r\nNorth Dakota has the third-highest literacy rate of 93.7%, with 6.3% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills. North Dakota, however, has the lowest percentage of registered library users of 35.9%.\r\n\r\nVermont has the fourth-highest literacy rate of 93.4%, with 6.6% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills. Vermont has the highest number of libraries per 100,000 people of 29.8 and has the eighth-highest bachelorâs degree or higher attainment of 36.4%.\r\n\r\nSouth Dakota has the fifth-highest literacy rate of 93.0%, with 7.0% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills. South Dakota has 16.4 public libraries per 100,000 residents, the fifth-highest in the country.\r\n\r\nCaliforniaâs 23.1% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills make California have the lowest literacy rate of 76.9%. The state of California and the state Department of Education are being blamed and sued for the failing literacy rate, as families and students believe that they are not receiving a quality education in reading and writing.    \r\n\r\nNew York has the second-highest percentage of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills of 22.1%, equaling a literacy rate of 77.9%.  Despite this, New York has the ninth-highest percentage of adults with bachelorâs degrees or higher of 35.7%.\r\n\r\nFlorida has the third-highest percentage of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills of 19.7%, equaling a literacy rate of 80.3%. Florida has the lowest number f public libraries per 100,000 residents of 2.6.\r\n\r\nTexas has the fourth-lowest literacy rate of 81.0% with 19.0% of adults lacking basic prose literacy skills. Texas has the fourth-lowest number of libraries of 3.2 per 100,000 residents.\r\n\r\nThe fifth-lowest literacy rate in the United States is in New Jersey, where 16.9% of adults lack basic prose literacy skills and 83.1% are literate. Despite this, 38.6% of adults have a bachelorâs degree or higher, the fifth-highest in the country. \r\n","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["abortion-rates-by-state","autism-rates-by-state","birth-rate-by-state","cancer-rates-by-state","circumcision-rates-by-state","corporate-tax-rates-by-state","crime-rate-by-state","depression-rates-by-state","employment-rate-by-state","flu-rates-by-state","infant-mortality-rate-by-state","labor-force-participation-rate-by-state","maternal-mortality-rate-by-state","murder-rate-by-state","obesity-rate-by-state","smoking-rates-by-state","state-tax-rates","suicide-rates-by-state","teen-pregnancy-rates-by-state","unemployment-rate-by-state","us-literacy-rates-by-state","vaccination-rates-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"us-literacy-rates-by-state","name":"Us Literacy Rates By State"},{"article":"","data":{"customMeta":{"relatedArticles":["civil-war-casualties-by-state","wwii-casualties-by-state","va-benefits-by-state"]}},"lastModified":"2020-04-06T20:09:05.176Z","path":"va-benefits-by-state","name":"Va Benefits By State"},{"article":"Vaccination is the administration of a vaccine to help the immune system develop protection from disease. Vaccines contain a weakened microorganism or virus, or proteins or toxins from an organism, not strong enough to infect someone but to help build a tolerance to the disease.\r\n\r\nUnlike in some countries around the world, vaccines are easily accessible in the United States. The seasonal influenza vaccine, or flu shot, is often offered for little to no cost at clinics across the United States every year during flu season. Many of these wide-available vaccines are for some of the most aggressive contagions that can be particularly harmful to children, the elderly, and people with autoimmune disease. Vaccines not only protect the individual receiving the vaccine, but also the community preventing the spread of these diseases.\r\n\r\nAround the world, more and more people are receiving life-saving vaccines. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has a thorough [list of vaccines](https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/vaccines-list.html) used in the United States. An emphasis is placed on children between the ages of zero to 10 to receive a specific list of vaccines: hepatitis A (HepA); hepatitis B (HepB); diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP); Hib, PCV13; inactivated poliovirus (IPV); inactivated influenza (IIV) or live-attenuated influenza (LAIV); measles, mumps, rubella (MMR); and varicella (VAR). \r\n\r\nWhile there are no federal laws regarding the requirement of vaccinations, all 50 states have legislation requiring children attending public school to be vaccinated against diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP); polio (IPV); measles and rubella (MMR); and varicella (chickenpox). All states and the District of Columbia, however, allow medical exemptions for children who have a medical condition preventing them from receiving a vaccine. \r\n\r\nAccording to the [American Academy of Pediatrics]( https://www.aap.org/en-us/advocacy-and-policy/aap-health-initiatives/immunizations/Pages/Across-America.aspx), routine immunizations for children are vital for both individual and society health. Because immunization rates vary from state to state, some communities have recently experienced outbreaks of preventable diseases due to a lack of vaccinations. Low vaccination rates can be affected by medical exemptions, parentsâ choice (anti-vaccination movement), or by lack of health care or health insurance.\r\n\r\nThe ten states with the highest rates of childhood vaccinations are:\r\n\r\n1.\tMassachusetts (92.60%)\r\n2.\tVirginia (92.10%)\r\n3.\tMaine (88.30%)\r\n4.\tNew Hampshire (87.80%)\r\n5.\tRhode Island (87.50%)\r\n6.\tDelaware (87.20%)\r\n7.\tTennessee (86.70%)\r\n8.\tNorth Dakota (86.10%)\r\n9.\tNebraska (85.70%)\r\n10.\tNew Mexico (85.70%)\r\n\r\nMassachusetts has the highest vaccination rates in the United States. [According to the director](https://www.wickedlocal.com/news/20160922/vaccination-rates-in-massachusetts-among-highest-in-us) of the Massachusetts Department of Public Healthâs immunization program, it is likely attributed to the facts that the state has a strong provider network and most children receive care in a primary care practitioner office. Additionally, âMassachusetts has had essentially universal healthcare for children longer than whatâs been happening nationally.â\r\n\r\nAlaska has the lowest vaccination rate in the United States.  Officials say that vaccination rates in Alaska are improving, but that more efforts are needed to maintain herd immunity.\r\n\r\nBelow is a table of each stateâs vaccination rates.\r\n","data":{"states":[],"customMeta":{"columns":["state",{"header":"Vaccination
